reviewText:
2 1/2 strickly for cenematic detail and photography . Otherwise don't waist your time if your looking for originality . This Movie is a " Full Remake " of the film ( Man in the Wilderness ( 1971 ) http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0067388/ .
What no one has mentioned is that its a true story of  ( Some True Adventures in the Life of Hugh Glass, a Hunter and Trapper on the Missouri River  ) (1857) Kindle Edition http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0190QJE1A?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=nav_timeline_asin .
When i realized i had seen this all before ....verbatime ( as in almost a total remake of the old film ) and adding to the truth of the book by changing a few detail things ....i walked out , the story was a sham after you read the book .

This film transports you to the 1820's American wilderness where the mountain men carved out a living trapping for furs.  This movie has captured that time and place like no other I've ever seen including the 70's classic "Jeremiah Johnson".  You feel the fear as the arrows
from Indians pierce men's heads and bodies and a bear attack leaves Hugh Glass for dead. Blizzards, avalanches, and storms are common place, and men have little time for anything but survival in this cold, brutal hell they have found themselves.  The beauty of the untouched wilderness is breathtaking to behold and this film captures it like no other.  The language is rough as are the men here but so is the life
they are experiencing.  Eating raw, and often rotten meat was commonplace for these men back then.  It was just a game to stay alive...

This film is by itself a well rounded masterpiece, inch by inch. Based on a single story, but supported by an undeniable artistic ambition, dazzling visuals, frantic script, superb locations, first rate performances, doesn't leave aside any detail. It's built keeping in mind the legendary masters of the Western genre (Ford and Hawks). It's an epic journey, where the nature is a restless actor, always challenging this untamed will; who step by step reaches the redemption through this amazing experience.

But there's still more: I guess Leonardo Di Caprio really deserves the coveted Academy Award and Golden Globe as Best Actor, because I think this has been -until this date- the role of his lifetime. Tom Hardy should have been nominated as Best Supporting Actor in the Golden Globe Awards. But I guess the Academy Award won't ignore him.

And finally kudos for Alejandro Gonzalez Iarritu's unlimited talent. My bet is for Best Movie, Best Cinematography, and probably Best Director.

Don't even blink and go for it!

What an incredible movie experience. Not only is this movie truly remarkable in its scope, but you have to hand it to the director and actors to be able to withstand the harsh conditions of the locations, weather, freezing water, etc...
Not only is this movie beautifully filmed, but the sheer savagery of the times is showcased to their most believable.
This movie will make you feel freezing cold in July, it is so masterfully shot.
Personally, this movie was much fuller, richer, and all around BETTER than the new Star Wars movie.
Simply speaking, this movie has Oscar written all over it! From best actor, much deserved, yet again, by Leonardo DiCaprio, and supporting actor, Tom Hardy. And Oscars for cinematography and screenplay are in order. I actually read the book, and the movie was actually BETTER! (Now, how often does that happen?)
I cannot wait to see and own this spectacular movie achievement.
Jeremiah Johnson movie has FINALLY been outdone in the 'Mountain man - Sheer survival' movie genre.
Ive been looking forward to this film for a while. It didn't dissapoint. I wasn't expecting it to be as good as I thought it was.
another wonderful movie by dicaprio I may have to watch it again. I just dint get why he didn't get an Oscar that's just a pain in the head. I guess I love it

For a movie about surviving against all odds in the wilderness after you've been incapacitated and torn apart, The Revenant delivers the goods and doesn't hold back on the gore and brutality, with DiCaprio giving a believable performance of the pain and agony he was going through as this character, where one disaster is followed by another, yet somehow he persists with what little strength he has, motivated by his son.
Nicely crafted survival movie and the scenery and natural sound effects were beautifully portrayed. The story unfolds at a slow but steady pace. Enjoyed it. The Revenant is not for the faint of heart. Or maybe it is, as repeated views can inspire courage and the drive to survive.

Simply put, The Revenant is a masterpiece. Cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki (Gravity, Birdman) succeeded, once again, in creating a beautiful work of art. In my humble opinion, I believe he deserves his third Academy Award in a row.

The Revenant has been largely promoted as a revenge tale. However, it's more than just a revenge tale. It's a story about a father's love for his son, and his determination, through many intense hardships, to bring justice to his son's killer. It's not a happy tale, but it's still full of beauty. It certainly would not have had the same effect without the captivating performances of both Leonardo DiCaprio and Tom Hardy.

I don't think this movie appeals to everyone. It's long, dark, and slow at times. If you want happy endings and continuous action, you may not enjoy the film. However, if you are a stickler for great acting, cinematography, and story telling, do yourself a favor and watch this movie.

Parents Guide: As you should expect with an R-rating, The Revenant does contain some content that you may find offensive. There is a scene in which a captive woman is raped (no nudity), but the man is stopped mid-way through. DiCaprio is briefly seen nude in another scene (none sexual). Profanities include several uses of f***, n*****, as well as some mild swear words. Violence ranges from extreme to moderate depending on the sequence. Even I had to cringe at times.

All-in-all, the content is used realistically, and is not enhanced like in many Hollywood productions.
This film has many excellent visuals and superb acting. The movie is 2 1/2 hours long and plods along. Music score and cinematography are superb. Highly recommend.

A group of American fur hunters who use Hugh Glass (Leonardo DiCaprio) as their guide are attacked by Native Americans. A small group escape by boat, but they know they are being tracked. Unknown to the fur hunters the Native Americans are looking for the chief's daughter who was abducted. Glass devises a plan to throw off the trackers. Unfortunately he gets mauled by a grizzly in a very realistic scene of which the trailer only gives you a glimpse. Near death, Fitzgerald (Tom Hardy) a crusty untrustworthy man, is left behind to tend to Glass and give him a proper burial when he dies. Events happen that turns Fitzgerald into the film's antagonist as Glass pulls out all the stops to survive in the dead of winter and seek justice.

This is not a lone man survivalist film as Glass meets people along the way. There is also a subplot involving Fitzgerald and his group that make it back to the fort. Very gritty film.

DISGUSTING Movie !!!
This sick and sickening movie wallows in the grossest implausibility and subhuman degeneracy.
Virtually no thinking, college-level individual would like this movie at all.

Leonardo Dicaprio portrayed a great many of the GROSSEST of implausibilities:
1) no hunter with the slightest common sense knowingly chooses to stop in the woods next to bear cubs; let alone choose to REST his rifle toward the bear cubs! And:
2) No one can survive plunging into an icy river in winter (let alone shortly after having been mauled by a mother grizzly and left for dead) - especially without having the means to quickly dry himself and warm himself!

And I could go on, and on, and -  about the implausibilities and historical inaccuracies of Leonardo Dicaprio's supposed portrayl of the experiences of the frontiersman: Hugh Glass.

First,  this moving is about two and a half hours long.  There is a lot of filler in it that really is not needed.  Second,  the story of Glass may be true but even the early version of it seemed to be embellished.  This movie could not even stick with that,  they had to go give Glass a son,  have three guys stay behind instead of two,  etc.  If you know the story you will be put off by the inaccuracies and further embellishments.  If you do not know the story you will be bored because it is way too long.  I got the standard definition version and it worked OK,  but my advice is to wait until the movie is free,  then watch it.  That way you will get your money's worth.

GRANTED, there are a few wonderful moments in this sadistic tale of vengeance, betrayal, mutilation, rape, etc ..... it's an accurate reflection of early nineteenth century 'pioneer' life ... but Award Worthy?  Eliminate, the extensive and laborious 'cringe-worthy' make-up ... and just what is left?
  Performances over the past decade or two seem to be solely rewarded for, err .... 'transformation' .... ["The Hours" / nose; "Monster" / contacts, bad teeth and weight gain ... etc. etc.  I guess we have to blame Shelley Winters - "Poseidon Adventure"] .... Rare ones like Spencer Tracy could actually act ....

However ...  we've seen this all before - Cate Blanchett's "The Missing" [graphic too - but better] .....  Here ... once more the Good Guy is betrayed by 'best friend' [who also bumps off the son]  .... Good Guy is almost mauled to death by a Bear Mama .... suffers through a hellish winter, oozing pus from slowly-healing  wounds [he MUST have an amazing immune system!] , is befriended by a soul-mate ... they share 'zen-like' moments .....

DiCaprio is just too young for this role and and still far too glam as well in the role  [perfect teeth, a very youthful body,  pristin ehands - impervious to the harsh elements, etc.]  Crowe would have been a better choice ... even Tommy Lee Jones ["The Missing"] broughts that weary, gnarled psyche to his performance.  IF anything - it was a 'Sympathy Award' - since he is so much better in other earlier movies - excluding 'Gatsby' ...

Tom Hardy?  NOW here's something of note -  a brilliant Oscar Worthy performance since he is totally unrecognisable - and creates a memorable 'bad dude' ......  Art Direction is stellar.  Costumes?  Perhaps more ageing - especially the soles of the boots ... far too 'new'.

It's an oddity ......and quite a long-long movie ...... if one's into pain and quasi-spiritual mumbo-jumbo  .. by all means ...
If you're not this type, I would not recommend it. Too depressing with one trauma following another. Took me some time to shake it off. Leo was superb though!

From what I can read in the other reviews, most people don't get out into wild spaces very often. When you are out in the woods, far from any city, things slow down. It gets very quiet, time seems to stand still and you are overcome with a sense of time and how nature moves in a rhythm all it's own. From that standpoint, I think the movie does very well. (This is written here mostly for the slack-jawed idiots on Amazon that think there "were too many pretty tree/nature shots" in the film.) The director is obviously setting a sense of place and a vast wilderness is that place.

Go into viewing this movie knowing that it's partially fiction. It will help you suspend disbelief when the main character survives a myriad of things that would kill most people. Starvation, hypothermia, bleeding out, infection, bear attack, falling off a cliff, drowning in a frozen river, knife wounds, gunshot wounds... it's a long list. I may have even missed a few.

If you can get over that, then sit back and enjoy a good revenge movie.  The acting is solid, the plot is believable, the cinematography is wonderful.

A few things that bothered me:

First, it's a historical film, more or less. So please set us up with some kind of text over the picture at the beginning that says "Missouri Territory, 1823" or whatever. Without that, we're left to think it's much later for a few reasons, the mention of Texas twice, being one. The only thing that clued me in was the fact that there were some Lakota Souix costumes and language used, so I figured "middle of the country somewhere" and the French still being here as trappers.

Steamy breath on the lens of the camera: Bad, shouldn't happen. As well, going to fisheye viewpoints twice killed the otherwise fine job of shooting. And WAAAAAYYYY too many "selfie" stick shots and far too close up into the faces and action in far too many scenes. That's headache inducing. Myself and the group I watched this with were all bothered by that. But hey, what do we know? That got an Oscar, right? Oh well.  It was like there were two or three people shooting this thing. Nature shots: one guy, Fight scenes, another guy and survival scenes, one more.

All in all, it was worth watching and I had been waiting a couple of years to do so. So, four stars. And by the way, great CGI bear.

Simply the best steadi-cam cinematography.  Period.  The film is rugged.  It's brutal and violent and possibly an accurate representation of frontier life.  I was suspicious about the likelihood of surviving the injuries depicted, but that only exhibits my willingness to believe the other elements of the narrative.  The direction and cinematography is simply stunning.  It is unique.  There is one scene of violence towards a woman that I simply wish was cut.  Maybe it fills some role in the tale, but it moves the film into a category of depictions of evil that I am reluctant to embrace.  Still, the beauty of the rest of the camera work is amazing.

Also - for those of us who spend our summers in a tent deep in the backwoods of grizzly territory, there is a scene with a bear that will never leave your memory.  Tremendous film.

I wonder if it's a "western" if there are no cowboys in it? 'Cause this is not really a cowboys-and-Indians story. It's a trappers-and-Indians story, set in the 1820s out in Montana and Dakota. A nail-bitingly harrowing tale of survival and revenge in the dead of a brutal winter. And it's excellent in almost all respects. Gorgeously shot, well acted, well written. However, I'm angry that it includes ZERO extras. Not even director's commentary. How I would have liked to see something about how they shot this thing in extreme winter weather; I would have liked to see something about the actual historical events the movie was based on. That's why, without extras, it gets 4 not 5 stars. I bought the DVD, not the Blu or 4K, so they may have extras I didn't have.

Dicaprio actually ate raw bison liver for a scene although he is vegetarian, because the fake liver they had was very unrealistic looking. The fact that it is based on a true story is only icing on a already very impressive cake.

This was a fair movie, 3 stars at best.  Nowhere near as good as people claim, and I wish I hadn't bought it.  Clearly a vehicle for Leonardo to get the Oscar.  And when you look at his body of work, this is definitely one of the weakest.  The film itself was weak.  Sure, it had lots of gore and guts, but the characters were shallow and the film seemed to drag on forever.  Especially since the outcome was so obvious from the first 30 minutes.  After that, I could barely get through it.  Worth a watch, perhaps.  But 3 stars is being generous.  I will probably never watch it again.

Stunning cinematography - decent storyline based on Hugh Glass's real life story/legend  of survival against the elements, kind of brutal and harsh story but well-made;  but then the director Inarritu has to depart from the legend and the novel and turn the film into YET another Hollywood lecture on racism by completely making up a sub-plot about a bi-racial son and marriage to an Indian woman - never happened. So the epic journey becomes not so much a battle against a beautiful  but merciless Nature as it is a battle against racism - the hero becomes the protector and vengeance-seeker  of minorities and the villain is - you guessed it - an evil murderous racist white guy with a southern accent. Maybe one day Hollywood will come up with an original  theme

This movie was shot in 6.5k and 3.5k.  The digital intermediary (DI) was done in 4k.  The video, although creatively darker, is reference quality. The audio is Dolby True with excellent sound design. The rear speakers are in constant use.  No Dolby Atmos track but the TrueHD track is excellent.  If you calibrate your 4K setup to this disc, most of your others should look good.  Remember to make sure any receiver you're using has HDMI 2.0a and upgrade to 18GB HDMI cables. Don't use your old high speed cables. They likely max out at 10GB.

The Revenant is a remarkable story in a film that crafts survival and adventure into a bleak season in North America. Leonardo DiCaprIo stars as the tough, frontiers man, Hugh Glass  -and along with a group of fur trappers of beaver, the story will challenge the trappers with the terrible forces of wild nature and hostile Indians to pursue their trade in harshness of landscape.

After a ferocious attack by a grizzly bear, and left for dead by a treacherous member of the team ( played by Tom Hardy, ) Hugh Glass will defy the forbidding odds to struggle to survive, and return home to take revenge ..the revenant is the man who comes back from the dead....

In many ways, the lengthy film prompts my thoughts to some very classy films  I keenly name them: 'The Black Robe' ; 'The New World' ( Colin Farrell ) ; The Russian film 'Andrei Rublev' ;  Akira Kurosawa's 'Dreams' ; and the beautiful and visual revenge western 'One Eyed Jacks' with Marlon Brando:. Although, maybe not as outstanding ( in comparison ), the film is very close as an epic: of a cinematic journey of a masterclass of film making?

The filming may not appeal to those who are reluctant to watch a snowbound wintry forest in slowness of motion in its character of nature -exquisitely slow, in thoughts and in masochism- but I found it to be exciting in a harrowing, but brutal, true tale to reveal the heart and spirit of mankind in survival, and to search for that wonderful compassion that will arise in sanction of mercy.

The film was directed by Alejandro G. Inamitu ( Birdman ), and cinematic vision by Emmanuel Lubezki .in blizzard white, I embrace winter's grace.....

In reality the French got along famously with the natives and intermarried with them so often that a new ethnic group was created: the Metiz. This director is blatantly bigoted. The story of the main character and his life is innacturate as all hell.  I would go so far as to call this movie a propaganda piece. So sad people are unable to see it for what it is.

Wow. This movie is like Jeremiah Johnson meets Iron Man. It's a strange juxtaposition of really horrible violence against the most beautiful natural backdrops. The sun, sky, and snow are just stunning. There isn't a whole lot of plot. The main character (Glass) is a tracker and trapper who is leading a group of trappers away from the Ree tribe when he's attacked by a bear. Hopelessly mauled, they leave three trappers (one of whom is Glass's son) with him until he dies so that he can be buried. One of these guys doesn't want to hang around so he kills the son (whom he hates anyway because he's half Native) and leaves Glass for dead. Big mistake. The rest of the movie is about Glass's survival and quest for revenge.

One of the worst movies, relative to hype, that I have Ever seen. Its not just that the movie is bad, I mean, yes it really sucks, but mostly it is just a criminal waste of resources for unclear aims. It fails at the narrative level, at the level of historical accuracy, fails on realism and the only level that it succeeds is with regards to its cinematography.

The most obvious criticism is the most glaring, namely that it takes its title, The Revenant, completely literally: I mean DiCaprio's character gets into recurring impossible situations and comes out alive. If this is some kind of narrative device, it fails utterly and just looks stupid. The worst of all is probably the Grizzly attack. Grizzlies are many times stronger than humans and the only defense against them at close range (short of a grenade launcher) is playing dead and praying like hell. But our idiot protagonist repeatedly fights back, gets repeatedly gets chomped on, and STILL comes out alive, kicking and jumping off cliffs while riding horses. Oddly, not a few personal acquaintances/friends pointed to this scene as an example of how "realistic" the movie was. It isn't.

And it is full of idiotic stock American tropes. I mean the French were among the only early settlers who intermarried with the natives and lived in relative peace and harmony (in modern Quebec). Every single British origin colonialist fought with or attacked the natives for Just being them, including the New Englanders. Yet here, the French are vile and terrible to them, and have No saving graces. In the real world, Dicaprio's character would be French, and dead, about 15 minutes into the movie, and 15 seconds after encountering the Grizzly.

All this to say, a total and utter waste of time. If you haven't already suffered this movie, Kudos! Ignore the positive reviews/Oscar and do something useful with two hours of your life (plus an hour of ranting to your friends and 15 minutes of writing this rant!).. Watch paint dry. Or dig a hole and fill it up. At least those activities are meditative and of Some value.

4K Quality: 5/5
HDR Quality: 5/5
Audio Quality: 4.5/5

You are almost immediately plunged into the action, in a similar way to the opening of 'Saving Private Ryan', with a Native American attack on a group of fur trappers. DiCaprio even does that momentarily deaf thing that Tom Hanks does. Lots of bows and arrows and gore and excellent photography that is really immersive. Great opening scene.

There there's the scene where DiCaprio is mauled by a grizzly bear. Again, really believable, exciting and up front and personal - you can almost smell the bear's stinking breath. Brilliant.

And then there's ... well ... not much really. Photography and scenery are by and large excellent but you do get the feeling that better use could have been made of them. Iñárritu often seems to chop scenes around for no particular reason, although you do get the occasional sense of the vast wilderness that comes over well on the big screen.

Dialogue is scarce. Most of it goes to Tom Hardy who tries to put on a Texan accent but succeeds in sounding as if he has a sock in his mouth (does he specialise in being inaudible? remember him as the mumbling Bane in 'The Dark Knight Rises'?).

Then there's the storyline. You know the ending, right? (Just look up the definition of 'revenant'.) Leo is up against it and he suffers a great deal. But you know he is going to survive. So when, to top everything, he falls off a cliff on his horse you realise he's actually become Mr Indestructible. And two and a half hours of crawling, grimacing and wincing does not a very entertaining film make.

There are also several non-credible plot twists. Like when Tom Hardy (a.k.a. The Mumbler) somehow cracks an impressive-looking safe and makes off with the garrison money and just two guys go after him, including the garrison commander. This nicely sets up the final confrontation between Mr Indestructible and The Mumbler .... but really?

We also develop little or no emotional connection with the main character. The silent dream scenes are a clichéd way of trying to do this and they don't work in my opinion - they're just puzzling and boring. Nor do we see much of the relationship between Leo and his son to set up the emotional links between them - just Leo being harsh and dishing out tough love a couple of times.

The pacing is also poor. Once you've passed the opening scene and the grizzly scene, feel free to go and refresh your popcorn - you won't miss much.

Overall, the film is self-consciously bleak and overdetermined and is unevenly paced. A better director might possibly have made this a good film but Iñárritu is clearly not David Lean..

DiCaprio delivers an outstanding performance and Tom Hardy is fantastic as the antagonist. Of course, DiCaprio battles more than just Tom Hardy in this both beautiful and heart pounding film. The cinematography was stunning with incredible work by the director, A.G. Inarrritu. I have not read novel yet, but the script based on the novel was excellent!

Glad I had this on DVD so I could fast-forward through most of it.  Lots of gratuitous gore.  Question: Hugh Glass gets mauled not once, not twice, but three times, by a grizzly, dragged around and stomped on and then becomes the cushion for the 700 pound grizzly when they go over a ledge.  He loses lots of blood, apparently doesn't go into shock, and somehow gets patched up.  He gets tossed into a grave and he -- and all his open wounds -- get covered by dirt.  He lives.  Yet, in the opening scene, men are felled and killed by one arrow in the shoulder.  Also interesting from the opening scene, the accuracy of the arrows is amazing.  Fast forward to when the Indians are chasing Hugh on horseback.  Why can't anyone hit him?  What happened to their marksmanship?

All in all, a terrible movie.

This was epic in terms of battle scenes, action, and man's battle with nature as well as between man and man. Glass, (DiCaprio) is the scout for fur trappers. Tom Hardy plays the main fur trapper Fitzgerald, who is obsessed with money to the exclusion of almost all else. His actions trigger war with the Indians,who are allied with the French. The perils are depicted very well and Glass barely seems able to catch a break as he seeks revenge for all that has been done to him. Some of the scenes are truly horrifying. The bear scene was appallingly real. Hats off to whomever created it, and the aftermath of what happened seems incredible were it not for the fact we know this is based on a true story. The real winner here is the scenery-spectacular. I am glad I saw it and I could say I enjoyed it, but it requires afair amount of endurance to watch DiCaprio go through living hell.  Hisbest performance to date.

I was excited to see it for this reason, but this movie is an entire fiction merely inspired by a few hard facts surrounding Glass and his ordeal.  Almost nothing in the movie actually happened in real life.  In the real story there was no murdered son, he was just ditched by guys who truly thought he would die, and not maliciously like they make out in this movie.  Glass sought revenge but let them both live.  The true story would have been better than what they made up.

BEWARE... these type UHD movies do NOT have Dolby Vision capabilities.  Of course, there are very few DVD players capable of Dolby Vision, yet.  I bought a OPPO UHD-203... and it promises Dolby Vision, but only through a firmware update, to be announced.  OPPO promises, any day now for downloading or updating via online auto firmware updates.

I bought 6 of these type movies and most disappointed... because I will never be able to play them in Dolby Vision.  They are in HDR-10.  The Dolby Vision encoding must be made on the movie as it is encoded and can't be added later through more codec, etc.  And, your player must be capable, then your UHD TV must be capable.  I went all-out for it by upgrading my TV to LG OLED B6P and my DVD player to OPPO UHD-203.  I'm ready, but the source materials are not, yet.  BUMMER.

First "Birdman", and then "The Revenant".  Director Alejandra Inarritu gives his viewers some very specific and memorable scenes and characters that burn themselves into the cranium.  For my money "Birdman" is the better film being far more layered and multi-faceted.  "The Revenant" character story arcs are pretty standard revenge fare.  What makes this film stand out are the long, icy, rugged visuals and terrain and the sheer stark deathrattle survival of star Leonardo DiCaprio's character Hugh Glass, himself being the "animated corpse" of the title who tracks down Tom Hardy's cold blooded killer character, John Fitzgerald, who offed among others Glass' Native American son.  Fitzgerald himself is essentially a walking dead man so he too could be considered as another titular revenant; it's only a matter of time before Glass catches up with him and kills him, or seen another way it's only a matter of time before his sins catch up to and condemn and consign him to death (a dictionary definition of the word, which I was completely unfamiliar with, is: a visible ghost or animated corpse that is believed to have revived from death to haunt the living).

While "Birdman" was a feast for the senses in many ways "The Revenant" is mainly a feast for the eyes though it will likely make your heart race and perhaps your legs a little weak at moments.  For fans of westerns where much more is said without a word being spoken.  4.5 stars.

Let me start with the good: Dicaprio is fantastic, I think he did his finest acting in this movie.  He has said this was the most challenging role of his career, but he was up the task and portrayed a man of that era in the wilderness perfectly.  The scenery, which can often steal the show, almost does it here as well, the locations were perfect for the story.  The camera work, wow just so different, so new, really outside the box in the way it's done and it works here.  The close-ups, the camera following Dicaprio as he's chased across a field is amazing.

Now the bad: if the movie had simply followed the story in the book I would have gladly given it 5 stars, but the movie makes up entire story arcs and characters out of whole cloth.  I won't give away any spoilers here, but I'd just read this book about 7 weeks ago and was looking forward to seeing it portrayed on film, this wasn't it.  Much of the book is here, but entire sections are missing, important sections too.  And people are simply made up that aren't in the book at all, I've seen a character dropped or added before going from book to screen, but I don't recall the last time a movie has differed this much from the book it's based on.

My summary would be that the acting and camera work are incredible, well worth seeing just for the craft alone.  If you're a stickler for movies following the book this movie might irk you, but even so I'd encourage you to watch it and enjoy the movie making skill on display here.

Talk about beautiful cinematography... JEEZE! Leonardo DiCaprio's acting in this movie was STELLAR, hes a great actor all around, but this is my favorite performance of his. Very dark, very gritty, this film reveals the cruel and relentless punishment that mother nature can dish out. The physical pain and suffering in this film feel very VERY real, I couldn't help but gasp and cringe at a number of scenes. The action scenes are very focused and harsh, and the struggle of survival is depicted in perfection. Not everyone will like it because its not brimming with action scenes, there is a decent amount of downtime where the film slows a bit and reels you in to the inclement environment, but for those of you who don't mind 2 and a half hours of great acting, breathtaking shots, and the harsh reality of nature, this is a MUST WATCH.
Fun Fact!: All of the shots in this film use NATURAL LIGHTING, thats right, no extra lights, spotlights, anything like that, just what the sun and the clouds gave the directors, and what they could create with actual fire and torches, nothing else.

Inarritu has plenty to say about our national origins and the resilience of the human spirit, but the ultimate appeal of this movie will be its astonishing visual and aural palette. The movie's slow pace gives Inarritu and his team ample opportunity to explore and savor the detail and ambience of every location and event. He does this not to create pretty images but to show that the human imagination--no matter how battered and assaulted--still retains the ability to wonder and ponder the staggering beauty of an otherwise indifferent environment.

A variety of devices--photographic, digital FX--are deployed with astonishing taste and judgment. I think it's great that ILM is doing more these days besides laser battles and superhero movies. Inarritu uses recurring images of trees, running water, falling snow--the usual art-house crap--but he invests them with fresh and personal meaning. I felt like I was watching something inspired and heart-felt during every frame of the movie.

Cynics might claim that Di Caprio has less than 100 lines during the whole movie. Nonetheless, his performance is excellent. He connects with the audience using body language, facial expressions, and the occasional grunt. Hardy is a very menacing presence. His frontier accent and speech rhythms are spot-on.

Isolation is perhaps the movie's ultimate theme. All of the characters do things they must do to survive while in the wilderness, and all then have to return to society to account for their actions. Di Caprio looks directly at the screen in the last shot. He seems like he's about to die or collapse, and his entreating stare seems like a plea for someone to understand his side of events before he's gone for good. The gap between who we are and how others see us remains unbridgeable.

Semi-fictional tale of Hugh Glass, a frontier explorer and mountain man.  He was recruited to guide an expedition to trap or trade for furs in the early  1820's.  Barely alive after being mauled by a grizzly he is attended by his son and two others.  When his son is killed in front of his eyes by John Fitzgerald, he is abandoned and left for dead by Fitzgerald.  the remaining part of the movie is the tale of his walking 200 miles back to the fort and his gradual healing.  He is helped by some on the way and by luck finds enough supplies and food to survive.

When he does finally return to Fort Kiowa, Fitzgerald had learned of Glass's survival, and ran away.  Hugh track him down and there is a final showdown,

I've watched many movies. I'd say Godfather, Drive, Scarface, Kill Bill, Star Wars, Aladdin, Jurassic Park, Aviator, The Dark Knight and E.T. are my favorite movies ever made. I now add The Revenant to that list. It looks better then any movie I've ever seen as far as camera angles and scenery. I've never really felt as much inside a movie as when I watched The Revenant. I didn't see it in 3D or in the theatre, just saw it on blu-ray on my old Vizio 46inch. I don't know if they used a new camera or technology for this movie but everything looks so clear and real. You almost feel like you're outside in the elements when you're watching it. The sound is really good and it has maybe the best score I've heard in years. The score speaks words through its music. Leonardo DiCaprio has greatly improved as an actor, I remember feeling he was outclassed by Daniel Day Lewis in Gangs of New York. The acting in The Revenant is very good but so is the story. The story is perfect for our time. It's what everything about: THE PELTS aka money.  Really the movie has everything: Story, Visuals, Sound, Acting. The Revenant is a master work of art that should be considered for all time. I don't say things like that much anymore.

Bad writing.  It's simply outside the realm of reality.  Someone that can only shuffle a few feet with the greatest of pain, suddenly jumps from a cliff, swims the rapids, survives a giant waterfall, only to be magically able to walk great distances.

The laws of hypothermia are also constantly defied.  Ask Bear Grills if a survivalist would wander into freezing streams out in the middle of nowhere without some plan for warming up.

Seriously? If you make a movie about survival, at least go beyond the comic books for advice.

Once again, The Academy is in their own little world.  Martian is FAR more realistic, well acted, and inspiring.

Excellent work, Leo. Can see why you won and Oscar for this role. This movie, which was out last year, maybe longer, is a must see. I recently decided to download HBO to catch up after the holidays with some binge watching. So happy this is one of a handful of movies I chose. Set in late 1800s upper west snow/wild animal country. Just when you think this character has had the worst of the worst done to him, to betray and kill him multiple times, it keeps getting worse, full of surprises right from the get-go. A true story of survival and lessons to be learned. The power of love for one's child and how far a parent will go in any generation to avenge their child's murder. I'm a lone survivor myself of multiple horrific events throughout my life but Leo's character really helps put things in perspective living in our digital world and EMT help at the push of a button compared to what men and women went through in the 1800s (and earlier) without medical attention for bullets, arrows, spears, getting buried alive, falling off mountains, drowning, staying alive and warm inside a dead horse, bear attacks, you name it. It was either live or die. Nature and the will to survive prevailed. Thanks Leo, cast and crew, for such an excellent, edge of my seat, nail biting, thrilling movie. Will watch multiple times.

I majored in directing in my hat is off to this man.

What a movie !!!  It is an absolute work of art. The people who say it is dark, moody and depressing should not be watching it at all. It does an excellent job of portraying life in the wilderness in the 1800's of men who trapped furs for a living and lived a very raw life just to survive. I honestly do not know how Leonardo DiCaprio ever managed to live through this movie while it was being made - I was frozen the whole time and felt like I was right there with him & the other trappers and Indians. Life back then was horrible and for the men that chose trapping in the wild during the time that Indians stalked everywhere; they really had a rough life. Eating raw fish & meat and even rotten food was just the way they had to take it sometimes, to survive. The Cinematographer Lubezki and the Director Alejandro certainly deserved awards for their skills and talents. I am going to look up the movie "Man in the Wilderness" with Richard Harris just to compare how the story was portrayed differently. This is an incredible movie, which certainly entertained me, even if it was hard to believe that the main character could survive so many unbelievable threats to his life!

The average rating for this movie is four stars, and indeed that's my rating as well.  This is a good and worthwhile movie, but not a great one.

The positives are the stunning natural scenery, and the depiction of knowledge and perseverance needed to survive in this environment despite both natural and human challenges.  The ebb and flow of the movie is pretty good, and the acting is solid.

The negatives are that the characters aren't well developed, and the story lacks richness and depth.  We don't learn much about the individuals and cultures depicted in the movie, despite wanting to, and I didn't come away from this movie with much to reflect on.

While I can recommend this movie, I would much more strongly recommend the movie "Black Robe", which has similar natural settings and a few similar themes, but is a much more expansive and profound movie.

Even though Leonardo is a whacked out commie, he's still a decent actor. This is probably his best role yet. Love the movie, but if they actually spent that much time in the water in those temperatures in the Rocky Mountains they all would have died from hypothermia pretty quickly. It is great to see an old mountain man story on the big screen, albeit very Hollywood style. The real Hugh Glass story is a bit different and the "ree" or Arikara Indians never lived in the mountains. They tried to bring in some popular mountain man names like Colter and Bridger, but they don't fit in the real life context of Hugh Glass, but it's still an incredible movie.

The book "Hugh Glass" is so much better than this movie.  It covers his entire life starting with his time as a merchant marine, being taken hostage by pirates, escaping and eventually finding his way to the Midwest where he was nearly killed, and then befriended, by Indians where he learned his survival skills.  The movie focuses entirely on is time shortly after being attacked by the grizzly bear, is short on dialogue (two hours of grunting and mumbling) and ends with his catching and killing the person who killed his Indian son.  He never had an Indian son nor did he kill either of the two who were charged with staying with him but instead left him for dead after the bear attack.  Skip the movie and read the book!

I saw this in the theater.  I haven't watched the blu-ray yet.  This movie has a different feel from what you're used to.  They avoid switching cameras, which makes it feel more like you're really there, experiencing everything there live as it happens.  The movie has a lot of realism and brutality and violence.  But it's not the lame fake violence you see a lot where they just shoot things up for no reason.  This is more like things happen for good reasons, and there's a real plot to follow!  I felt like I was transported back in time and I was actually there experiencing what was going on. / Also check out Leonardo's documentary about climate change.  They had to change shooting locations thousands of miles in the middle of the movie because it was too hard to find snow.

The movie was pretty good but suffered from some weird artsy direction in a few scenes.  Also the changes made to the actual history were a bit over the top but they didn't hurt the film in any significant way.  In the end I think what killed the movie for me was the strange placement of sound effects that didn't match the scenes such as a running brook that played in the background over about 10 minutes of film featuring various scenes that had no running water in them while some woman whispered.  It felt like the sound director went and got one of those native american sounds CDs at a strip mall, popped it in his 90s boom box and let it play over half the movie.  I'm sure many found it to be artistic and meaningful but to me it just came off pretentious and distracting.  There were some visual shots that were confusing here and there as well.  Anyway, good movie bogged down by dull, meaningless artsy drivel

Not for the squeamish, but visually stunning. Based on a true (but embellished, according to historians) tale of survival, this film is truly the director's vision. The American West depicted here is unrelentingly bleak, treacherous, and brutal, as are the French coureur des bois, American fur trappers, and vengeful Indians who inhabit it. There is no romanticism here.

The camerawork and photography are sublime, with many haunting images. The opening Indian attack is a tour-de-force of swirling action and brutality. Ditto the mauling of DiCaprio's character by an angry momma grizzly.

At times the camera is uncomfortably intimate with the characters, moving and turning with them in closeup, dragging us into the story so much that you almost feel the cold and the pain.

A couple of quibbles: The Tom Hardy character is a one-dimensional villain whose accent sounds like a parody of Billy Bob Thornton in Slingblade. The changing landscape is jarring, considering the journey depicted is less than 200 miles, reflecting that the movie was shot in multiple locations on different continents to achieve the visuals the director wanted

Not a date movie.
Good show

Not for everyone.  It's nature, raw nature, and history, raw history.  His encounter with the bear is utterly realistic...informative and troubling to an old hiker like me.  He gets separated, without giving anything away, from his team and encounters everything man and nature can throw at you.  As history, it has a simple, genuine feel to it.  The characters aren't exaggerated and unbelievable.  The movie doesn't explain itself, with the same tone as Cohen Brothers' "True Grit"...but it you look intently, you'll see that everything rings true.  LASTLY, the best part, is the photography.  I've travelled most of the nation during many different times of year, and am nonetheless STUNNED by the photography.  It's worth watching for that reason alone.  And...make two bowls of popcorn instead of your usual one...it's a little long.
What can one say after all of the awards... this was a most disappointing movie... watch at your own risk of being bored to death...love Dicaprio... but not his....How much boredom can you take?

Given all the hype, I expected this movie to be very engaging, exciting and, at least somewhat intellectually satisfying.  Unfortunately, I  had to wade through two hours of shallow plot, unnecessarily excessive visceral violence and undeveloped character lines before I finally felt engaged.  My girlfriend left the couch within the first 15 minutes but I felt obligated to get some value out of my eight dollar purchase.  The plot was shallow and formulaic. It had the requisite violence in all the gory detail that today's technology can create. It also had the predictable components of sexual misconduct, Indian exploitation and faces slopped with the blood of raw meat and organs. On top of that, the various challenges the main character endures were presented in fabulously unrealistic extreme.

I would have rated it a 1 if it turned me off to the point that I turned it off. It didn't quite take me that far down hill because the scenery, the supporting characters and the prospect of something more kept me on the couch...or maybe, it was my dog cuddled in my lap that kept me seated.

Genius. Pure genius. As a director of corporate videos and documentaries I was stunned to learn that no artificial light was used in this film, no telephoto lenses; everything is either a camera close up or breathtaking landscape.

All of that would just amount to pretty pictures but there's so much more to it. Dicaprio and his fellow actors are so real, that the film delivers a visceral feeling of what it must have been like in those 19th century days of fur trading out in the unsettled west. It's first time I've ever seen that era depicted in a way that truly takes you back to that time in American history.

I think he's deserved Oscars for several of his movies but if he were to only win one, this was it.

I can't truly say I "like" this movie, but I admire it for just that reason: it doesn't want to be liked, it only wants to tell its story. Due to the film's stark bleakness and graphic violence, to "like" it would be the equal of liking a masterful painting of a child being skinned alive: though one can admire the artist's skill at painting, one cannot feel similarly about the subject the artist chose. What is admirable about the Revenant is at no point does it try to become more palatable to me or to anyone except maybe a sadist. I guess...I guess I admire the film's relentless pursuit of itself--in other words, the story knows where it is going and is only concerned with getting there.

While the visuals were fairly well done, the theatrical trailer showed all the most impressive scenes. While the actors played their parts well, the writing was simply awful. The plot was thin, the historical accuracy dubious, the attempt to portray native americans in a sympathetic light (depending on the perspective they're both the heros and the villains) came across as colonialist and patronizing at best. The story (what there was of it) dragged on indefinitely - it was a movie that just wouldn't die. By the end I was rooting for anyone that tried to kill off the protagonist to get it over with sooner. If I could give it one and a half stars, I would. It merits that much only by virtue of the setting (the time period and impressive landscapes) and the casting, otherwise I'd have given it none at all.

This film is yet another example of how Hollywood is getting better at making trailers than it is at making movies.

I read through some of the 1&2 star ratings trying to find some good reasoning but I could not find any. The common theme amongst the 1&2 star voters is that the movie is boring and has bad acting, both of which I strongly disagree with.

The only conclusion that I could come too for the poor ratings is that we have grown so used to movies that do not build the characters or the elements that formed them. In short anything requiring an extended attention span is boring.

Is the Movie long yes... However, it is a visual masterpiece that immerses you into the time, conditions and situations people faced at the time.

I really appreciate how this movie brought to life to the reality of the time. Providing an unapologetic view of how people thought to how people survived. We also get a beautiful glimpse of what our beautiful wilderness looked like before industrial pollution.

A "copy" or remake (some would label it a "rip-off") of the superior original "Man In the Wilderness" with Richard Harris and John Houston (1972).  Same overall theme - the original Revenant by definition (sans the pseudo-intellectual comments made about Revenant).
Typical Hollywood, except this time they scored a home-run in their plagaristic endeavors - it should be known that there was very little original about this movie it was so liberally borrowed from the aforementioned film (also based on a true story, probably the same one).
So Revenant was an ok movie, but don't get so excited, flowery and full of yourselves in describing its merits, technical prowess, story line, etc. - a masterpiece it ain't...and as to Oscar, well we all know what appeals to the average public, translated into Box Office, generally appeals to the Oscar Committee (though in all fairness not always).
See "Man in the Wilderness" first and you can avoid needing to see the Revenant

The Revenant film stars Leonardo DiCaprio as Hugh Glass. The beginning of the film opens with Glass and other men around them fighting for their life. One of the reasons that is given in the movie why such a war broke out relates to one of the daughters named Powaqa (Melaw Nakekho) of an Arikawa leader named Elk Dog (Duane Howard)being kidnapped by someone andor some people affiliated with the French hunters. Hugh Glass, his son Hawk (Forest Goodluck) and other men are able to survive and get away. However, things take a tougher turn for Glasss character when he is attacked by a grizzly bear and his life is eventually left in the hands of John Fitzgerald (Tom Hardy) and Will Poulter (Jim Bridger). It is tempting to mention more details and characters mentioned in the film yet I must take care to keep details brief for other people who have yet to see Revenant. I also became interested in watching the Revenant after finding out that the author whose book this movie is based on also works a day job. This inspired me because deep down I would like to still maintain a career/job while balancing the dual role of being a writer regardless of how my writing dreams turn out.

It baffles me that this film won Oscars. Are the people giving out these awards totally clueless? If anything, Hardy should have gotten the prize. He's pretty much the only enjoyable part of the movie. I'm not saying Leo's performance is bad. It just seems like for 75 percent of the film, all he's doing is crawling around and grunting. This fits with the story, but Oscar-worthy? Hardly. I also found the bear attack very disappointing. This seems to be the scene everyone is talking about, but I just don't see it. The Edge, starring Anthony Hopkins, did it much better. And that film is about 20 years old. Practical effects trump CGI any day. Another thing I noticed was how stuff was always getting on the camera. If you're filming a water scene or something like that, it's understandable. But in this movie, it seems to happen every 10 minutes. Must have been a deliberate choice the director made. But it doesn't work. It takes you out of the film whenever it occurs. Ever think of just zooming in? Apparently not. Overall, it's probably not as bad as I'm making it sound. It's just that, with all the awards and hype, I expected much more. Keep your expectations low, and maybe you'll think it was better than I thought it was.

The Revenant is one of the best movies I've ever seen!  I'm totally serious.  I remember all the awards and attention it got earlier this year showing Leonardo DiCaprio alone in the wilderness and fighting for his life.  I wasn't sure at the time what he was fighting.  Looked like a very different role for Leonardo but let me tell you, it's a *very good* role and he should continue doing these kinds of movies in the future.

When Leonard DiCaprio's attacked by a bear, his hunting team carries him along the trails in 1823 America because he knows the trails very well whereas his team would be lost without him, however pretty soon Leonardo's health deteriorates to the point he becomes more of a hassle and inconvenience for the team.  Tom Hardy's character, who's the lying ruthless member of the hunting team, even thinks about shooting Leonardo on a couple occasions to end his misery, but Leonardo's son (played by Forrest Goodluck) intervenes and Forrest ends up stabbed and killed.  Let me tell you, this scene is VERY graphic.  Leonardo is forced to watch his son being stabbed and he's too injured and helpless to do anything about it.  You can see the anger and saliva dripping from Leonardo's mouth to express how much he wants to stop/kill Tom Hardy.

Leonardo's life is almost taken a second time when Tom Hardy tries to kill him yet again, but his partner (a young kid played by Will Poulter) intervenes to save Leonardo again.  So Tom drags Leonardo into a ditch and covers him with a little bit of dirt.  And these aren't even the most graphic scenes!  Let's talk about the actual bear attack.  Let's just say this is why I'm absolutely terrified of bears.  I fear bears for this very reason- they're unpredictable and attack without mercy.  The way they can tower over people very easily is another terrifying thing about these animals.

When a mother bear catches Leonardo by surprise, he turns around and tries to shoot but it's too late.  The bear is already attacking.  It's crazy that Leonardo was able to come up with a strategy to shoot the bear when she came back again, but despite his gun pointing directly at the bears head, somehow he misses the shot so it's round two of Leonardo getting chewed and beaten on.  This is when Leonardo's hunting team has to carry him around and eventually gets frustrated about it.  I've never seen a bear attack this graphic in all my life.  I imagine technology was used to make it look like the bear's attacking him, but isn't actually there.  I highly doubt the movie directors brought in a REAL bear and allowed it to pretend to attack Leonardo!

The Revenant is also not without several more violent moments.  Realistically violent perhaps I should say.  Since it takes place in 1823, you can probably guess it involves Americans invading the country and shooting/killing the Native American people.  Both sides are portrayed as violently as one could imagine.  While this isn't the ultimate movie that shows the British invading and taking over America (I'm still searching for the most accurate movie in that category) the first 20 minutes are truly violent, not to mention intense with the feeling of dread and uncertainty looming in the air.  It's a scene that shows Native Americans sneaking around and shooting Leonardo's hunting team one by one, and I must say their strategy was quite clever because for the longest time nobody could figure out where the arrows were coming from.

Also the French/Canadians are part of this movie. I actually didn't even stop to think they'd probably be a part of all this back in 1823.  Then again maybe not.  Not sure if any of the events taking place in the movie are accurate.  They're portrayed as ruthless rapists, liars and party animals.  Not sure if that's accurate or not.  The scene that shows a French/Canadian having sex with a woman behind a tree, and Leonardo sneaks up and grabs the man which enables the woman to break free and defend herself is a great moment of the story.

Basically the story is that Leonardo has to take revenge on Tom's character for not only killing his son, but leaving him for dead.  I don't think I remember if they stated why Leonardo's son is a Native American.  Then again thinking about the very final moment of the story, the constant female voices Leonardo hears throughout the movie while on his journey across the snowy mountains and lakes, and another scene earlier with a woman's voice expressing how when a thunderstorm moves in it looks like the branches aren't stable... I think I can put the pieces together and figure out why his son is Native American.

Tom Hardy does a tremendous job playing the villain, but I can't help but notice how much older he looks than he really is.  Some amazing make up was used to make him look *that* old!  And the same kind of amazement can be expressed for the way Leonardo DeCaprio looks.  He looks authentic like he was not only made for the role of a frontiersman who's acclimated to the mountains, but also the way he looks is just so different and yet so fitting for him!  Leonardo should do more movies like this!

I can't help but wonder if Leonardo's character was either the luckiest or unluckiest person on the planet.  How many times did he find himself in a life or death situation?  And how many times was he able to *escape* from a life or death situation?  That bear should have killed him and yet he survived.  However the fact he was attacked so aggressively is hard to watch.  Tom should have shot and killed Leonardo on at least two occasions, and yet the other hunting mates and/or his son just happened to be around to intervene and save his life.  Even leaving Leonardo for dead with snow falling on top of him, he's able to recover just enough to slowly get back on his feet and continue on.

Later on Leonardo's hiding behind rocks as Native Americans approach the mountaintop.  Though detected, Leonardo is able to get away just enough to swim the nearby river and barely avoid their gunshots... but it's unlucky that he had to ride the strong current down the river.  He should have been shot and killed when he approaches a Native American by a fire eating a dead animal who's also out for revenge looking for the ones who shot his family, and points a bow and arrow at Leonardo's head.  But... the man holds back.  He doesn't shoot.  These two become temporary partners by sharing animal meat and riding horses together.  Or when Leonardo wakes up to an arrow hitting the tree behind him- he quickly jumps on his horse, runs for a little while and jumps off a cliff and lands in a pine tree.  If he'd never fallen down that cliff, he would have been shot and killed (I think it was the French/Canadians doing the shooting in this scene- can't recall at the moment since it happened so quickly).  Just so many unlucky situations leading to luck playing a part in his escape!

You just want to see Tom Hardy get what's coming to him.  You know it's going to happen!  To think he went back to his fellow frontiersmen and lied saying that Leonardo was no longer alive and upon finding out that he is, Will Poulter's character gets the blame.  You're terrible Tom Hardy!  Overall, this movie's amazing.  The definition of revenant- someone who comes back from the dead.  Yup, knowing that pretty much describes what is not only the best movie in Leonardo's entire career, but one that has an extremely good story behind it to assure that even at 2 hours and 25 minutes, you won't be bored at all.  Really strong characters too, and most of them are fully developed which doesn't happen often in today's movies.  Awesome movie.

If you have a UHD HDR setup, I highly recommend this title. I watched it with the Panasonic DMP-UB900 on the LGEF9500 and the experience is truly spectacular. The cinematography of this film is beautiful and the camera work is very visceral. The quality is so good, I felt as if I was physically present at many of the scenes. If you have a good surround sound system, I now believe films such as this are better experienced at home than in the cinema (even IMAX, which is way too loud for my liking), a true testament to the benefits of the UHD HDR technology. If you are wondering whether to invest in physical UHD media, my advice would be absolutely, as long as you appreciate high quality. The quality of the experience with UHD HDR Blu-ray is an order of magnitude higher than the 4k streaming content currently available through Netflix and Amazon.

It would possibly have been more interesting if the plot had been woven into a broader historical context.  As it was, we are mostly left with  a lot of violence and gore taking place during a protracted chase with the intention of seeking revenge.  If that's your thing, you'll probably like it. Wow, this is a long film; it would benefit from having 30 minutes or so removed but since I am not a professional film-maker I can't tell you which 30 minutes or so, alas.

Afterwards I wondered what Leonardo had done to deserve the acting Oscar. At no stage did I get a sense of the depth of Glass' mental or physical pain although I did see when and how I was supposed to. Having found the list of nominees for best actor I can see why he won it (lack of competition or perhaps it was just his turn) but throughout the film I had the impression that he was a student actor 'doing' pain, rather than a character who was actually in pain. I think he has done better work in Wolf of Wall Street and The Aviator to name but two.

The imagery was great, reminiscent of The Big Country with wide and long shots, mountains and rivers. After a while though there was just a little bit too much of it - I was surprised to be slightly bored by yet another sunrise/sunset through trees from a low angle. One can have too much of a good thing and in the end I became satiated - even to the point of uncharitably thinking that in such great natural scenery one sometimes needn't aim the camera, just turn it on and wave it around because there are great vistas everywhere (a tribute to the director of photography and location scouts, presumably). The scene with the bear was quite excellent.

The main problem I have with the movie is the rapid accelerations in Glass' physical recovery. In a matter of minutes he went from a jibbering wreck to a wreck who could crawl many yards and perform other work; overnight he recovered from being down and out to being able to fight an able-bodied man. I couldn't help but suspect that there had been some telescoping of the original events but that together with my lack of buy-in to the character meant that for me the film was simply a photo-journal of facial expressions, grunts and great vistas.

The Revenant is savage, and gruesome, and somehow so very beautiful. Leonardo DiCaprio stars as Hugh Glass in this genuine cinematic masterpiece that could easily be described as another revenge movie, but that's not doing it any justice. The Revenant is so much more. There is a deeper story about survival here, and at times it feels incredibly spiritual; with Native American Indians playing a big part, and the mystery of mother nature doing the rest.  There is a minimum of dialogue during much of The Revenant, but it never feels boring or dull, and the use of such stark silence only increases the visceral sense of awe and wonder when Glass is being confronted with nature at her most brutal. The  Revenant means one who comes back, and this is a film that you will want to return to.

The Revenant is directorial masturbation at it's finest.  Beautiful cinematography, but the gore is just disturbing and the lack of a clear ending make it feel ultimately anti-climactic and hopeless.  If you don't like shoot 'em up revenge stories that make you feel sick to your stomach, do not even bother watching this.  I need more from a story than beautiful shots and special effects.  Yes, DiCaprio gives a remarkable performance and you do root for him.  But the ending is so anti-climactic that you can't help feeling a little dirty and cheated for wasting 2.5 hours on all of that gore and hopelessness.  I don't know about you, but I want a movie to restore my faith in humanity.  Might as well just watch the news or a period crime reenactment show.  If you don't watch it and skip the buzz around it, you won't be missing much.  Except maybe nightmares and haunting thoughts of tragedy.

OMG!!!-this movie is one wild river rush of nail biting suspense, horror, desolation, heartbreak and dark beauty all in one. First, there is the story, and that is enough to make the movie, but then, the utter bleakness and fierce nature colliding with an unmistakable raw beauty, that pulls the movie into what I would call a true Masterpiece of Art. This really isn't just a film about revenge.

I have never been so aware of all of the human senses coming out of the movie and literally forcing the viewer to feel those same senses; Leo wading into ice cold water to catch a fish with his bare hands, then, biting into it. His sheer force of will to keep going, to get up that icy hill after eating the fish. It's a defining moment that says, by God, he WILL live!!!-and of course, if bows and arrows and ambush weren't enough to worry about, now there is a devil amongst the group, his name is Fitzpatrick(Tom Hardy). His wrath has no end.

I was reminded a bit, during the heartbreakingly beautiful forest and landscape scenes of Jim Jarmish's "Dead Man", with Johnny Depp. Of course only a bit of similarity.

When Glass's wife is killed and the bird flies out from her, is truly original and mezmerizing. And proof that love lives on in the spirit world. The church scene with his son spoke more than any sorrowful dialogue ever could.

Leonardo DiCaprio has truly accomplished something very few actors can ever lay claim to. This film cannot be eclipsed!!

You would be hard pressed to get worse conditions. I LOVE the aliveness of Nature and the Spirits. I felt the Native Americans true suffering was portrayed, as was their ability to survive insurmountable conditions.

The scene where the "Tracking" Native American says something like, What do I have to lose, you white men have already taken everything from us, is SO TRUE and shown in great clarity.

Whenever I think of this film, I will always remember Leo's remarkable grit and determination; the lone Warrior who helped him, and the best scene for me: his son returning to him one more time in the torn down church; the dreamscape that one finds amidst great suffering, if lucky, and one to holdfast to. Alejando's best movie by far. Mucho mucho Bello!!

It is a decent film, but I don't think it was worthy of an Oscar. The story seems compelling enough, but I couldn't get into it enough to really care about the character. Leo did a good enough job, as did the other main characters.
I do think that the over-the-top ludicrous things he endures end up taking away my interest...simply because he would not survive. The numerous times he walked, fell, floated in the icy mountain streams (including the time for several miles)...he would have had hypothermia in about 3 minutes in reality. Lying inside a dead horse would be warm for a few hours, then it would turn into a block of very cold meat/ice. And his clothes were wet and outside the horse so they would be ice as well. so many things in this movie would have been the end of him in reality. That just made it more difficult to watch IMO. I actually thought the other actors had more believable characters.
The true story, as near as anyone knows, is basically a guy who was mauled by a bear and left for dead by his fellow trappers. He somehow lived, and found his way back some 200 miles to the Fort, mainly by building a raft and floating downstream for 6 weeks.. There was no Pawnee wife or child. He was just a guy who wanted revenge for being left behind.

ake the direction of Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu, combine it with the stunning cinematography of Emmanuel Lubezki and toss in Leonardo DiCaprio and Tom Hardy for their acting charms and what do you get? An extraordinary and masterful film.

Fresh off of 'Birdman,' Irritu moved straight on to 'The Revenant,' a western-epic inspired by the true-life experiences of frontiersman Hugh Glass in the winter-struck landscape of 1820s America. The film gained some notoriety in mid-2015 for its production problems and has thus been regarded one of the most challenging film shoots in the history of cinema. Rightfully so. The film opens with the soothing sound of running water, thrusting the audience into an almost meditative state, and then it strikes, an action-packed sequence ensues with a near single sweeping take. Now this is a spoiler-free review, so I'll leave the pleasure of viewing that scene to you.

This film heavily evokes reactions from the audience and does so well, whether it's staring at the screen in awe or gasping at the visceral violence, if you face this film with the right attitude and expectations, it will be a thrill ride like no other. Lubezki has proved that he is one of the most fantastic cinematographers of modern cinema, and the extensive use of natural lighting over artificial supports that statement even further, the film is beyond stunning. Supporting this is the score from the relatively unknown composers, believe me, when the sudden orchestral boom strikes your eardrums, it's mesmerising.

The makeup, the direction, the editing, the visual aesthetics, and of course the performances from a hopefully soon-to-be Oscar winning DiCaprio, 'The Revenant' is a visual treat for those who appreciate cinema and for those who wish to just get absorbed by the immense landscapes and poetic justice Irritu has given it. This is, for me, a modern masterpiece.

3) G. Inarritu pulled some of the best acting I've seen from Dicaprio, if not the best.

My wife and I went into this movie exciting excitement, entertainment and, perhaps, amusement.  This is the epitome of drama.  If it isn't bad enought to be left for dead and return for revenge, the film makers felt it necessary to add components to the movie which really had no need being there.  Those being the voice of a non-existant wife and the sidebar story of a son which defies facts of Glass' life.

This is an incredibly long movie clocking in at nearly 150 minutes  You know how a movie speeds by when you're engrossed in it?  Don't expect that to happen here.  In fact, some of those minutes are painfully slow.  Don't expect witty banter between characters.  What dialog there is sounds as if the actors stuck a plug of chaw in their gobs before saying their lines.

Does all that mean it's not a good movie for others?  Not at all.  It just wasn't one for us.

I agree with Archmaker...though the cinematography is beautiful and the acting so real it makes the viewer struggle with the combatants in the fight scenes, this movie isn't for everyone. It almost wasn't for me with its graphic portrayals but I managed to stick with it to see if Glass did indeed get his revenge.

The scenery is beautiful but cold and appropriately hostile and its beauty is juxtaposed with the violence going on in it, suggesting that to survive in this environment one must become brutal, cruel, vicious, and more than a little insane.  Though no mention is given as to where the trappers are, I've read the story is supposed to take place in Montana and South Dakota. It was filmed in Alberta, BC in apparently the dead of winter if the vapor released when dialogue is spoken is authentic.  There are a few scenes where people do things for no apparent reason, such as during the first attack when a trapper selects one horse out three and calmly shoots it...and the success of the chief's search for his daughter is suggested visually but never actually spoken. Her abduction isn't shown but apparently happened before the film began and it appeared to me that the men abducting her were the same one the chief was trading with...but then, all white trappers look alike...

I'm certain there will be comparisons between the scene in which Glass eviscerates his dead appaloosa and climbs inside to protect himself from the snow and a similar scene between Luke Skywalker and his dead tauntaun in The Empire Strikes Back...which copies which?

A good portion of the movie is without dialogue, other than harsh panting and the sounds of struggle, again emphasizing the isolation in which the trappers find themselves.

While I agree di Caprio deserved every award he got for this movie, and all the others commendations are well-earned, I didn't really like the movie. It was  too brutal and violent with no lessening of tension at all.  I also felt it was a little too long and could've been edited a bit to shorten it without harming the storyline. After the two hour-point, I found myself wondering when it would end. I managed to see it through to that ending, however, which was rather abrupt when it arrived.  I wouldn't call this story entertaining but rather a look into the past where life was cheap and the only way really to survive was to be as harsh and cruel as the environment in which one lived. It's definitely a monument to the will of Man to survive, however, and that revenge is a great motivating force.

This is the film that landed Leonardo DiCaprio his first Oscar award.  He does an excellent job acting here.  The story revolves around true events in the life of early 19th century trapper Hugh Glass.  Glass is attacked by a bear and the other group of men leave him to die with two other men to watch him and give him a proper burial.  Glass is abandoned by the two men and then proceeds to begin his search for the men to take his revenge.

The movie was good.  The book was much better.  Others will probably disagree.  The movie changes several things including giving Glass a half Indian son who is murdered by one of the men who is to guard him till Glass dies.  I can see the point of adding the son for the revenge purposes but the book doesn't go like that.  Glass, in the book, does hunt down the men but he finds that revenge is best left in the hands of God.

Overall this movie is worth watching but the book is better.  I recommend reading the book and making your own judgment.
good but long

As a hunter and a woodsman I can tell you right now anyone who has an inkling of what it's like to walk up on a bear let alone a grizzly with 2 cubs will have that same fear flow through your body while viewing this film.  What is hard for many to understand, is during that period in time, men were men and their fear and pain were replaced with callous. I remember my grandmother tell us kids how her father (my great granddad) broke his leg while hunting in the mountains of WV. He set the break himself, split it and hobbled on home as if it were nothing but a mild setback. Today's men request a nurse for a paper cut.  This character goes thru hell and back & the story does reveal how many men survived those harsh conditions  which fortunately none of us today will ever have to endure...if we're lucky. So sit back in your easy chair, throw another log on the fire and count your blessings wherever you are that you're safe, warm  and out of harms way.

In this film we have disjointed nonsense hung upon the framework of adventure, something like a drunken housewife hanging laundry all akimbo upon a clothesline. Rarely, expect in B-movies, have I seen so many improbabilities and inconsistencies.

Hugh Glass, played by Leonardo DiCaprio, is a scout for a fur trading expedition that ostensibly is organized like a military unit, expect that whenever there is a crisis, anywhere in this film, good military discipline does not prevail. This coincides with left-wing belief systems about the uselessness and ineptitude of anything military, so this worldview is presented to the audience and is nonsense.

Here is an example - central to the plot is the conflict between Glass and his antagonist John Fitzgerald (played by Tom Hardy) in which Hardy essentially blames Glass with being a dangerously (even treasonously) incompetent scout. Of course, this charge has to be false to maintain the hero status of the protagonist. In fact Glass's job IS security (and scouting) for the fur trading expedition. While he is away (within hearing distance of a rifle shot) hunting meat for the expedition, the expedition is attacked, and the majority of the party is killed. Straight-forward enough except that in the attack it is clear that the Indians have infiltrated into the treetops the night before, so Glass really is culpable of incompetence (or at least negligence). Later, as Glass leads the survivors of the massacre on an escape route, one morning he again goes out to scout, this time alone, and is almost mortally wounded by a bear. Anybody with any knowledge at all of basic military procedure (or common sense) would understand that for the key leader of the party to be out scouting alone in hostile territory when they know they are being pursued be enemies is ridiculous or utter incompetency. Oh yes, men do get mauled by bears but it becomes a bit more difficult for the bear when there are two or three armed men in the group than one. So really, Glass is an incompetent scout, but in this film he is the hero, and Fitzgerald is the deranged, despicable cad.

Then there is the whole business in this film about white race relations with Indians. In this film, everything the white man does to the Indian is bad,, but everything the Indian does to the white man, no matter how barbaric, is neutral at worst, since the white man allegedly deserves what he gets. For this reason, it is "understandable" when blacks kill white cops in our society today, because at the end of the day the cops allegedly deserve it.

In short this film serves up a confused mish-mash of politically correct vignettes in the framework of backwoods adventure.

And by the way, apparently in the 1820's nobody lived beyond 40 because everyone in this film is 40 years old or younger, much younger, even the senior commanders of the fur trading expedition. This film was targeted at the millennial generation who actually believes the nonsense this film serves up.
