Before this movie came out I read the true historic account of Hugh Glass contained in the Kindle book: Some True Adventures in the Life of Hugh Glass, a Hunter and Trapper on the Missouri River (1857) With this historical background I was able to appreciate the movie more than I think I would have otherwise. Another short historic account of Hugh Glass from 1902 provides additional background on the events in the movie: A Brief Account of Hugh Glass the Mountain Man Legend and His Amazing Story of Survival (1902) One interesting character introduced in this movie is Jim Bridger who was a young man in the movie. It seems Jim Bridger was to later become one of the greatest mountain men and a noted explorer---as can be read in these historic accounts of Bridger: Jim Bridger "The Grand Old Man of the Rockies" (1922) Biographical Sketch of James Bridger: Mountaineer, Trapper, and Guide (1905) For a general background on mountain men in general try: Mountain Men of the Rockies: Adventures of Colter, Bridger, Bill Gordon, Peg Leg Smith, Old Bill Williams, Bill Bent, J.S. Smith, the Sublettes, and Other Trappers in that Remote Region (1883) Overall the movie was very entertaining, although it varied somewhat from historical reality--the movie is highly recommended.

Another strong performance by DiCaprio.  This is a well acted, well executed arctic wilderness drama.  You'll find yourself asking, "How much punishment can one man absorb?" watching this. The engine of this drama is the parental bond -- whether it is the grizzly mama who attacks DiCaprio when she perceives him as a threat to her cubs; the Arikara warrior chieftain who confuses DiCaprio's hunting party with a French group of trappers who have kidnapped his daughter; or DiCaprio himself, who is driven by the spirit of revenge.

The British actor, Tom Hardy, plays a convincing frontier bad guy, driven by ruthless expediency to commit acts of pure evil.

This is an incredibly bleak film. You will not be happy after seeing it. However, you will be astonished, awe-struck, and sublimely impressed with every bit of craftsmanship that created this brilliantly artful tale of human tragedy and struggle. It is a work of art in every way: a visual experience that is both subversive and overt in its being man-made while illustrating deeply personal truths about being human. "Amelie" is one of the best films ever made and speaks of humanity's spirit, so is "Mary Poppins," so too is "The Revenant." Why compare these films? Because they are all profoundly beautiful and it must be recognized that even painful beauty can be made into must see cinema.

Alejandro Inarritu is a movie-making-madman-genius. Forget "Bird Man," that was only a test. His stunningly nuanced and seemingly effortless style of continuous camera motion through multiple scenes is a new mode of story telling. Somehow every flow works to convey more detail than cuts could ever accomplish. His technique seems made from the medium of dreams, memory, and to-the-second experience of the now: permanent yet always fleeting. Ignoring the amazing performances, story and writing, the setting's landscape is perhaps the star of the show. Every texture is felt, every shot a moving landscape painting full of ambiance, mood and power. Earth is the crucible from which we came and it has always been the confinement within which we play out our lives. It is grand, and within the scope of this film, largely impervious to even the worst of life's struggles.

This is one of the best films ever made and possibly one of the most bitter, however, it transcends that pain to leave one with a deeper sensation and understanding more akin to revelation.

I will not reiterate what everyone who has posted a 5-star review has said about this movie already. They are absolutely correct! So why on 4 stars?

The main character, Glass, had far too little dialogue and emotion concerning the deaths of his family. Moaning constantly in physical pain doesn't convey emotion. Staring off into the ether with a tortured expression isn't grief. That isn't to denigrate Dicaprio's performance....I'm sure he did exactly what he was Directed to do. However, the point of acting is to connect with the audience on a level they can understand and relate to. And I had a great deal of trouble relating to Glass as a character and no sense of connection with his supposed emotional state. Even up to the final scene I had no sense that he was actually "feeling" anything. The final scene could have been shot with a character who was a stranger to Glass and he only a hired gun to hunt him down---and nothing would have changed for me. I'm sure this puts me in the far, far minority but having recently lost two close family members back to back, I couldn't relate to the way Glass' character.

Tom Hardy Stole this movie! If anyone deserved an award, he did, not Dicaprio.

violent, great cinematography, well acted, musical score very atmospheric, enveloping movie.  could have actually done without the ending as contrived-the ol' "hunt the man down like the animal he is" type ending.  according to what history there is of the person depicted, it might have been more interesting to see what allegedly really happened.  it is very good as is... also, see it on as big a screen as you can and read the backstory of how it was produced...a real life struggle between man and man and nature in and of itself.

It a fancy movie for the sake of being a fancy movie. This movie just simply tried to hard to be a gritty death filled portrayal of blood covered men trying to survive in bloody times. In all of that, it lacked a ton of reality. They camped in places no one would camp, Glass fired multiple times from muzzleloading weapons without reloading, the land scape was all wrong for the area of NA where this would have taken place. So much great work went into the acting, special affects, cinematography, and audio, it's hard to believe they forgot about the story. The place it would have happened and the details about it would have happened were lost to or just not important to the director.  Jeremiah Jonson and Valhalla Rising both have whatever it is that this movie is sorely missing.

It is laughable that an trapper would put an uncocked flintlock in another trapper's face and threaten him with it.

In one scene, the head guy at the fort pays the trappers who return even though they have no pelts.  In a later scene the same head guy tells the same trapper that no one gets paid until the pelts are retrieved.  Whoever wrote this seems to think trapping was like a job like cashier at 7-11.

Why does Mr Revenant make a fire and camp on a riverbank where anyone can see him?  Why does he do it, almost get caught and killed by the Sioux and then do it again?

One of the most realistic movies I've ever seen. My wife is not into westerns or cowboy/Indian movies (except for "Deadwood"), but she loved this movie. We missed it when it was in theaters, but got to see it on our 60" big screen. What an amazing movie. Even more so after I saw the documentary about how it was made. Leonardo DiCaprio was totally believable, no "no pretty boy" in this movie. I usually wait for movies to show up after they are "free" to watch, but this time (and with its competitor "Spotlight") we made exceptions. Two of the best movies ever, but "Revenant" was the big winner in my book. Be sure to see it full length and uncut - DO NOT wait for it to show up on free TV (if it ever does) or else you will surely want to kick yourself. By the way - actor Tom Hardy plays the "villain" to DiCaprio's "hero" - an amazing performance. Hardy played the infamous "Bane" in perhaps the best of the "Batman" movies - perhaps the nastiest villain performance in modern cinema. Two words for "The Revenant" - SEE IT!

In a way it is a film for nothing, except an Oscar for the main actor.

We are in Pawnee country some time in the 18th century, at the divide where the French and the English more or less meet. With the Indians in-between, around, behind and in front, at times under (a couple of feet under) or even over (from their horsebacks).

The French are trying to play it commercial and buy pelts and other Indian natural products but they cant always have their terms and at times are obliged to give some horses, even when the season is advanced and the horses are the guarantee to survive. Some will die.

The English are more in burning the Indian villages and looting whats left and evenkilling the survivors, even when there are none. Kill them twice for bood busqiness.

Add to this the fact that some Indians, especially those who have managed to get horses can become a real permanent pressure and an arrow is silent, efficacious and reloading is easy. Think of an arrow sniper in the trees.

Then you have the unhealthy, sick, vicious, criminal minds on the European sides. On the French and English sides they may consider an Indian woman is like a pet you take away without asking for permission. And the film widely shows how the English with their forts are rotten from the inside by the thieves, the immoral beings who take advantage of the frontier to realize the worst trends in their personalities: they can kill, rape, steal and many other things as much as they want.

This film is the fight to the finish between two such English pioneers, one being on the sinning side and the other on the punishing side. They call that vengeance, and vengeance;, as is well known, is always on Gods side, and sure enough the assassin, murderer, thief and a few other things, among them rapist, will be finished by the Indians who will pass on their horses leaving the good one to die in the snow since he is wounded and his horse, if it is still there, has been left behind several miles of deep snow away.

No salvation, no real vengeance. Just violence for the sake of surviving and for the pleasure of shedding blood. That shows the resilience and the viciousness of human beings. They love destroying, killing and a few other things like that.

Really a film for nothing, except an Oscar for the main character, oops! Sorry actor.

This film might be worth watching, but only if you have absolutely nothing else to do for about three (long) hours. I am glad I didn't pay to watch it at the theater with teens behind me kicking my seat and chatting and giggling all through it, but even in the somber oak woods of my home theater ambience, I was almost - almost - bored. It's not that it isn't a finely crafted film (the bear attack scene is pretty good if you can hack the kind of screams and squeals that only L.D. is capable of emitting) but it's so predictable. In fact, the entire film is predictable. It is a composite of better films like, "Jeremiah Johnson", "Kill Them All and Come Back Alone", "The Patriot", etc.  It's a formulaic screenplay that copies dozens of screenplay's before it, and they always - always - turn out the same.... Bad man kills good man's son. Good man needs to overcome overwhelming odds and obstacles to take revenge on bad man who killed good man's son... I'm actually boring myself as I write this. To sum up, 1) not a bad way to spend 3 hours if you've nothing better to do, 2) the CGI is unforgiveably noticeable - especially the bear attack scene, 3) if there is ANY good reason that I can think of for you to watch this movie, it's because of Tom Hardy. First of all, you will never, ever know that the antagonist, "Fitz", is Tom Hardy - this guy is a phenomenal actor - but the screenplay is at fault; it's perfectly predictable and though Hardy does an outstanding job (an I do mean, OUTSTANDING JOB) with what he has to work with, the role he plays is nothing special. In summary, think, good guy vs. bad guy - with a sort of half-way decent bear attack scene in the beginning...

This is a dark and brutal movie, but beautifully shot. The cinematography is simply stunning. I live in Montana so the beautiful scenery and brutal winters resonates with me. The winters here are hard enough in the modern world, I can only imagine how harsh and unforgiving it must have been back in the hey day of the fur trapper. This movie does a good job of transporting you back to time of the mountain man; a time when the land was untamed and only the strong survived. You can feel the frigid temps, and the impending doom of an indian attack. Though Leo doesn't really have much dialogue, he gives a strong performance as Hugh Glass, a man who comes back from the precipice of death, fuelled by vengeance and freaky surreal dreams of his dead wife and son. Tom Hardy gives an equally great performance as the despicable Fitzgerald, who murders Hugh Glass's son, and leaves Glass for dead after he is mauled by a grizzly. The bear attack was well done and very intense, as is the beginning sequence where they attacked by indians. Suspension of disbelief is definitely needed to enjoy this movie however, because Leo goes lives through some scenarios that would have surely killed him (like floating down an icy river or riding a horse over a cliff), but that is just a trifle easy to overlook. Overall, I found the movie to be very good, and better than most of the crap Hollywood puts out these days.

Proof that the director has reached the level of master craftsman. This movie is two and half hours and is a true experience. You will leave exhausted. Don't go because you have a free Sunday afternoon. I saw this on the big screen and was speechless. I then waited ten months until I watched it again on my big screen tv. Also, don't pull out your big brain and try to figure it out. There's nothing to figure out. The message of the movie is stated within the first five minutes and, if you forget, is repeated in the last few seconds--- survive.  The rest is spectacle and imagery. Suck up every minute of it. You will be hypnotized and then violently shaken out of your hypnosis every fifteen minutes or so.  You will watch scenes that you know do not exist anymore but somehow you're watching it. FEEL do not THINK,or this movie will mean nothing to you.

If you're fond of history, this film is not for you.  Hollywood has taken some names from the mountain man era, combined them with a nearly imperceptible whiff of an historical event and crafted a dark, violent fantasy/adventure/ordeal story.  Of course if you prefer a fantasy/adventure film thats on the dark side of dark, complete with a massive overdose of subtitles, this movie might just be your tub of buttered theater popcorn.  The film deserves ZERO stars for historical accuracy, and Ill reluctantly elevate it to 2 stars as a fantasy/adventure tale, splitting the difference for my overall 1 star rating.

If you decide to watch this film, youll soon hate (or at the very least, greatly despise) trapper John Fitzgerald, played by English actor Tom Hardy.  In spite of the negative feelings Hardys despicable character invites from the audience, hes clearly the standout player, mastering a Yankee accent and employing it to deliver more dialogue than any other member of the cast.

A far better fantasy/adventure/ordeal motion picture is the Tom Hanks classic, CASTAWAY.  But don't stop there.  Another excellent but not as well known fantasy/adventure/ordeal film is THE SNOW WALKER, inspired by acclaimed Canadian writer Farley Mowat's short story of the same name, and directed by Charles Martin Smith.  If you have somehow missed this one, treat yourself!

Exquisite cinematography and acting. What a painfully wonderful recreation of the life of Indian wars and loss, and the triumph of pathetic and brutally immoral white self-aggrandizement. Unfortunately the film's overall statement has been done many times and much more originally or informatively (Dead Man, Black Robe, Fargo, Clearcut, Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee, Little Big Man -- and in novels, especially Leslie Marmon Silko's "Ceremony" & James Welch's "Fools Crow"), so this story really should have had something more and it would have been a triumphant film. The father (DiCaprio) lives the blending of the two cultures, the only sensible and moral way to deal with the cultural clash, but the one way that we know never happened due to the Andrew Jackson way to be white. There's a moving father and son love and loss scene that says it all. Otherwise, there is no character development really (purposefully, one could argue), and the plot is so predictable that it's flat boring. (We've been told that only God should take revenge & we know that the canteen will show up, etc.) Happily, the filming of the gorgeous expansive and powerful wilderness fills that content void for pure filmic pleasure (and a poignant reminder of what more might be lost) and if you just want to appreciate the top-notch acting of DiCaprio in slow motion, the film will satisfy. If you want to watch a painfully realistic mauling of a human by an angry mother bear, wow.

Remember Lawrence of Arabia? Well, imagine a fresh update of the grand sweeping classic for a new generation of filmgoers. Except this one doesnt take place in the hot deserts of Arabia, but the brisk forests of North America. Its not as much about the story of a single man standing up to an entire rival army, but a single man as he survives in the wilderness for the safety of his own home. Also, the lack of a Hays Production Code today means that further opportunities are made to present the cinematic experience in gritty realism that only the toughest of the tough can sit through.

The journey starts in 1820s North America, where a group of White tribesmen hunt after a defenseless deer, until they hear of their tribe getting terrorized by a rival tribe of Natives. The leader of the hunters, Hugh Glass, played expectantly by Leonardo DiCaprio, fights to get his son away from the chaos of flying arrows and bloodcurdling cries. From there, he and his clan of huntsmen are out alone in the forest, in need to get home. That is, until Glass is mauled almost to death by a grizzly bear, and later abandoned by his own men. From there, its just him in critical condition fighting against the little resources available in the wilderness. It doesnt help either that his son had been murdered, leaving his temptation for revenge against the murderer in strong demand.

Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu, did not create something as innovative or as imaginative as the impressive Birdman, but what he does succeed at this time around is immersive visual storytelling. His usual cinematographer, Emmanuel Lubezki, takes all the right turns in transporting the story into us with subtle yet effective techniques. Water and blood gets sprayed onto the camera lens, entire scenes last one continuous take with no edit cuts, the lens gets breathed on, and every single frame is worth posting on Pinterest. You could practically smell the cedar in the forest without the use of Smell-O-Vision. Irritu proves his power as a director by commanding the greatest out of both the visuals on screen as well as the realism of the actors. Seriously, check out more of his past work.

Similar to Birdman, The Revenant proved to be an extraordinary risk that was well worth taking. Wish the same could be said about the screenplay. Unlike the bird movies satirical take on our entertainment industry, this newer feature brims an over told message about the reality of revenge: is pursuing somebody out of vengeance really worth it? While the best stories ever told may have taught us this valuable lesson that could prevent all of our worlds problems, The Revenant does not add anything different or unique about the concept of revenge.

Honestly, this entire movie should have just been about Hugh Glasss survival in the wilderness after getting mauled by a bear. The other subplots between the people back at his tribe were not anywhere near as engaging nor as powerfully told as Glasss.

Yet the lacking power of the story really was the only fatal flaw in this otherwise perfect feature. Not once in the near three hour run time did I see Leo DiCaprio trying yet again to wow everybody. Instead, I saw a wounded man wandering through the wilderness as he suffers ungodly agony on his way back home. Everything DiCaprio did, from launching a bullet to gnashing his teeth to sparking a fire to eating a live fish to grunting the few words of dialog he had, went way beyond simple acting. The amount of physical and mental preparation that Leo went through to pull this role off never screams, Hey Oscars, remember me? Im the one who told Rose not to let go! But rather, Being an actor is hell; the preparation it takes to make the role real for yourself and the audience.

Caution beware: Alejandro shows us all what he learned from attending the Mel Gibson school of movie violence, that is, enough gore to constitute an NC-17 rating. Arrows are seen flying into mens foreheads, a dead horse gets its inner organs ripped out, fingers get chopped off, deep flesh wounds are revealed, ears get bitten off, and the main protagonist gets his flesh ripped clean off the muscle by a bear. So prepare to constantly be covering your eyes and going, ooh!

The Revenant will last as a classic piece of cinema that those of any knowledge of film can find significant value in. The casual comic book fanatic will get a kick out of the gritty action and tale of survival, and the greatest of cinema artists will be spellbound by its majestic cinematography, poetic visual language, and the performance of the century by Mr. DiCaprio. This should very well be Lawrence of Arabia for the 21st century!

Overall Grade: A

Although I am giving this movie five stars - and it fully deserves that rating - I don't think I could ever watch it again. In fact, I'm not even sure I could recommend watching it to others, because it's actually kind of traumatic - a description I don't think I've ever applied to a movie before. Every aspect of this movie is stunning, particularly the cinematography, which uses very, very long, uncut sequences that put you right into the setting. In short, I sort of "became" the main character, Hugh Glass, instead of simply observing him.

Therefore, I felt his pain - of which there is a tremendous amount. During the now-infamous bear attach (not a spoiler, as it occurs early and is in the movie synopsis), I felt as if I was getting mauled and clawed and chewed upon. That scene is like five minutes long, and I think I might have held my breath for most of it! This is not a movie that is big on special effects, but the effects that do exist are absolutely stunning. At no time did I think "that bear is pretty good CGI", I was thinking "that's a real bear!"

DiCaprio's performance is everything it's been hailed as - positively stunning and one for the ages, and Hardy is just as good. This is not a feel-good movie by any means, but it's quite possibly the most impressive one I've ever seen.
I went into this movie not sure what to think.  Not normally my type of movie but the cinematography drew me right in.  This is the best made movie I have seen in a long time.  Top notch directing.

Wow! Very realistic view of times during the early 1800s for pelt trappers with beautiful cinematography of the landscape throughout. Leonardo DiCaprio really did a great job portraying such an extreme character; fighting for his life after being attacked by a Grizzly bear and being left behind by his comrades, then turning around to seek revenge. This is a very graphic movie, not for kids, there's a lot of violence and graphic fights between the characters with graphic realistic views of fingers being chopped off, ears bitten off etc. Not for kids....not that they would most likely have the attention span to sit through the 2.5 hours of it all to begin with, but in case they come in and out of the room, the entire movie has scenes constantly throughout that are too much for a child. The fact that this is based on true events of what an explorer experienced is horrifying, its definitely a story of how strong the human spirit can be!

Also that someone can just push there way out of frozen solid meat was laughable. The movie also ignores (or doesn't show you some things) like how a guy who can't move his legs got down from a cliff top to the river below, so you've got to live with that. You could rate it lower for these sort of things, but ultimately if a movie (and especially a slow one) can keep you glued to the screen for two and a half hours, how can you not rate it five stars?

The Reverent is based on the true story of  Hugh Glass, a trapper and frontiersman in the wilderness of what is now parts of Montana and South Dakota.  The setting is the vast wilderness of this beautiful area in 1823 where Glass was hired to lead his friend  Captain Henry and several trappers through the vast and dangerous wilderness.  Glass brought his half Indian son along with him which alone brings  a lot of tension in the camp.  Glass is mauled by a grizzly bear and manages to survive, but barely.  Rather than stay with the group, Captain Henry offers to pay anyone who will stay with Glass and give him a proper burial if he should die.  Fitzgerald and a young man who is rather gullible agree to stay.  Fitzgerald hates Glass's son because of his heritage and tries to kill Glass not long after the Captain leaves with the other men.  Glass's son, Hawk, tries to call for help and Fitzgerald kills him and hides his body.  The two men abandon Glass in the wilderness and set out for the Fort with Glass's gun and equipment.  When they arrive, they inform Captain Henry that Glass died and that they gave him a proper burial.  The story follows Glass as he makes his way alone in the wilderness.  His thoughts of revenge against those who killed his son and left him to die is all that keeps him going.

The movie does a great job of capturing the amazing scenery and Leonardo DiCaprio, as Glass, does an amazing job of acting in this movie. Although, it was very interesting there were times when it was difficult to hear what the actors were saying and the movie seemed to go on an on. I do recommend the movie, however, because the acting and the scenery were enough of a reason to watch!

A powerful film that defies the "old Western" genre of cowboys and Indians, such as "Shane" or "The Treasure of Sierra Madre." Leonardo DiCaprio is outstanding in this film in his roll as trapper and fur trader Hugh Glass, a real explorer in the 1830s fur trapping years when hundreds of adventurous men sought out opportunities to trap beavers and trade pelts. There are a few disturbing scenes, most notable is the grizzly bear attack on Hugh Glass, who had inadvertently come between Mama grizzly and her cubs. Left for dead by his comrades, Glass suffered severe wounds to his head, back, arms, and most every part of his body was shredded. The Revenant is ultimately about vengeance as Glass stumbles his way back to the nearest fort on the Missouri River, encountering wandering tribes of Native Americans, some of whom helped heal the wounded trapper.  Overall, the movie depicts a time when opportunists flooded the Missouri River to hunt beaver, and for many it was survival of the fittest. The trapping years anticipated the gold rush in the late 1840s and early 1850s. Glass's real target is John Fitzgerald who is among those who leave Glass for dead. Fitzgerald had promised $70 for each trapper to stay by Glass, though virtually all of the assigned to watch Glass eventually gave up and started digging a grave for Glass. Glass literally rises from the dead, and motivated by his resurrection he returns to Fort Bridger to kill Fitzgerald and exact his revenge.

I absolutely love the cinematography, the story, all the characters, the music, and the editing. If you loved it in theaters, then you'll love it again on Blu-Ray. But for me, what makes a movie worth buying is not only the movie itself but the bonus features where this movie lacks a lot.

So don't be looking for extra goodies. If you're ready to simply buy this movie based on how much you liked or loved it, then that's the way to choose if you'll buy this or not.

I borrowed the dvd from my family and decided to give this film a watch just to see if it would live up to the hype. It is 2hrs, 36mins of sheer cinematic torture. I grew up watching similar films from the '60s & '70s that made more sense. (ie: Jeremiah Johnson (1970)) I even researched the main characters lives and got more out of snippet bios than this movie tried/failed to portray. I could spot all kinds of errors (ie: Glass breaking his ankle more than once in the film with it healing in a few scenes; wild animals native to other continents in America; incorrect animal attacks with wrong injuries) Ultimately the film is self-consciously bleak and unevenly paced. I honestly cannot see how it won the awards it did, let alone finally give DiCaprio an Oscar.

While I do enjoy the acting style of Leonardo Dicaprio, I'm surprised that out of all of his Masterpiece films, this is the one that he finally received an Oscar for. While the film is filled with adventure, most of the film depicts Dicaprio (Hugh Glass in the movie) sitting around and groaning in agony after being attacked by a bear. It gets a bit repetitive. Was his acting good? Yes. Did the movie need to be almost 3 hours? Probably not. Was it worth watching; it depends... do you have three hours to kill? To be completely honest, I expected a bit more from the movie. Maybe a bit more of Dicaprio and a little less of him whining around in agony. WE GET IT. You got attacked by a bear!

Parts of the film were downright unrealistic as well. I mean, once you look past the whole getting attacked by a grizzly bear and living, many of the characters (including Dicaprio himself) swim in the icy cold waters of the uncharted (at the time) Dakotas and never once dry off their clothes or sit near a fire to regain their warmth. In short, If this movie were actually taking place, Dicaprio would have died very early into the movie.

I get it. It's a movie. However, I can't pretend some of those things didn't bother me! I think I expected a bit more from this movie.

After being attacked by Indians the surviving trappers make a break for it on their boat, however the Indians wanting
the pelts the trappers were able to salvage for trading purposes will pursue.
The surviving trappers acting upon the advice of 'Hugh Glass' (Leonardo DiCaprio) abandon the boat relying on 'Hugh' s'
knowledge of the territory to continue the long trek back to the fort on-foot.
During a hunt for game to feed them 'Hugh' is attacked and savaged by a Bear, his injuries are severe....his son 'Hawk' (Forrest
Goodluck) along with the ruthless 'John Fitzgerald' (Tom Hardy) and the naive 'Jim Bridger' (Will Poulter) are left to care for
the near-to-death trapper.
'Fitzgerald' believes that killing 'Hugh' would be an act of mercy however, instead following, a turn of events 'Hugh' is abandoned
and left for dead.
Winter is closing in on the territory, barely able to get to his feet 'Hugh' crawls away from the shallow grave 'Fitzgerald' had placed
him in, his chances of survival carrying the crippling injuries inflicted by the Bear are virtually non existent, the pursuing Indians
(The Arikara) a further threat to his plight.
'Hugh' has a desperate desire to survive against the odds needing to exact revenge and serve justice on the man who had killed his
son and left himto die.
A chance meeting with 'Pawnee' refugee 'Hikuc' (Arthur Redcloud) who realizes that the badly injured stranger was no threat, offers
his help, his crude attention to 'Hugh's' wounds will make the difference between life and death for the trapper.
When the treacherous 'Fitzgerald' learns of the possibility that the man he'd left for dead could well be alive he'll have to make plans
to escape justice....but, 'Hugh Glass' will surely pursue.
The film depicting an incredible survival is a tense and often brutal affair, worthy of it's acclaim with an outstanding performance from
'Leonardo DiCaprio' coupled with a backdrop of stunning scenery....quite simply an absorbing watch and a 'must-see'

Irritu would probably make a very talented photographer. If only he were even remotely interested in story, character, pace, or theme, all things that are pretty important to a functioning director. He knows how to put together a gorgeous looking movie using natural light and natural landscapes. While I think this is an awful movie, nature buffs should check it out anyway just for some of the finest nature photography you'll see this decade. And, you know, there's some decently bleak violence in this that should appeal to the survivalists. Just don't come into this expecting anything more than some nice cinematography, because there's nothing else here. Most of the movie is a dull rehash of the same basic "everything goes wrong, Leo gets bodily punished" scenario played with the most minor variations you can imagine - at 90 minutes, this would be a potentially interesting minimalist Western; at 156, it verges on torture - that eventually ends with a whimper that manages to simultaneously neuter the ending of the book completely while also making no sense whatsoever.

There is one undeniably great thing about this movie, though: Tom Hardy and Will Poulter's trek together. Whenever Poulter or Hardy are on screen, suddenly the movie comes alive, turning a grim survival tale that looks like an art school student's take on SAW into a beautifully acted, character driven period drama. The two of them do so much to salvage the lackluster pace, the stiff performance from Leo, and the shoddy editing, it's just a shame the whole movie wasn't about them. And made by someone else.

A great movie and I knew I had seen the story before in a movie. Sure enough, Google provided this:

Man in the Wilderness is a 1971 American Revisionist Western film about a scout for a group of mountain men who are traversing the Northwestern United States during the 1820s. The scout is mauled by a bear and left to die by his companions. He survives and recuperates sufficiently to track his former comrades, forcing a confrontation over his abandonment. The story is loosely based on the life of Hugh Glass. It stars Richard Harris as Zachary Bass and John Huston as Captain Henry.[1]
The expedition in the movie is notable for bringing a large boat with them, borne on wheels.

I was so impressed with Richard Harris' performance as Zachary Bass I named my only son Zachary in 1978.

Where are the 3D movie releases?? Why?? Why??

This is not a review of movie content, plots, twists and spoilers. This can be viewed as an open letter to studios as a lament of the marketing decision to shelve the 3D format. I have seen 4K content, and additionally, I own a fabulous SUHD 65 and a great upscaling blu ray, 3d player. No doubt there some great reasons to support 4K, although there are many tepid reviews of native 4K content. I will say, for my enjoyment, there is no equal to a good 3D experience, the depth of field, the sheer feeling of participation, the sense of presence that cannot be rivaled in a 2D format. There are many movies out there that clearly advertise 3D IMAX in theaters, but no longer appear as a home video option. Additionally I have no intention of upgrading, yet again, my library as I have done since the early days of home theater. 4K is an alternate choice, not an upgrade and lacks the immersive experience of 3D. Now, as you all must know, 2016 HD TVs no longer even offer 3D. What the.???
Not all movies, not even a close majority can be available as 3D. I get it. But I have laid out a tide little sum of high definition equipment and upscaling capabilities and I feel a bit betrayed but this decision clearly motivated by money ( isn't it always) with pretty much no regard to the consumer, who has funded your companys all these years, and this is the thanks we fans can now expect. My contribution goes back many years and many dollars. (who remembers laser disc special editions going for $100? Thats right, $100.!! Fox led that charge, Alien, Aliens. How about the Rocky Horror VHS price years ago. Thank you Fox! But looking forward, I do not advocate the demise or removal of 4K and know it is here to stay, thats fine, but please reconsider this decision 2D will always be 2d, no matter what. I personally would rather feel transported into a 3D realm of presence, and would sacrifice the option of seeing more pores on someones face or more fibers on a suit or how much shinier Iron Mans paint can be in a 2D world. My fellow consumers, please show your support and chime to studios and distributors as I have done to keep this format alive. Dont think your opinion has no value! UNITE!
Thank you for your consideration and support.

I was soooo looking forward to seeing this movie the first time I saw the previews online.  I was blown away and thought to myself, this is going to be a kick butt movie.  The angles, the lighting, the sheer harshness of the environment.

Then I watched it.  I wouldn't classify it as a outstanding movie nor would I consider it a bad movie.  Leo doesn't talk much in the film.  There are great action shots and the camera angles are sweet.  The overall story isn't bad so I won't do any spoilers or anything like that.

What I took from the movie the most was that that environment that they were at was VERY harsh.  I can't even imagine living back then as it seemed like just the sheer treck/living situation was stacked against you in a very large way.  Our forefathers had it rough and this movie made it seem like that was very very true.

Why this film got Leo his award, I'm not sure.  I can name other movies he's done that I think are far superior to this movie in everyway as far as him acting.  Tom Hardy has more talking parts and in a way if I didn't know I would think he was the main character.

You should see this movie but deep down perhaps I made it bigger than what it should have been due to the previews I watched.  It didn't wow me like what the previews did.

Fantastic foray into the world of a Colonial fur trader, full of the raw struggle of man against nature, man against man and man against hmself, where the only prize for winning is another day of life.  This is such an interesting film on many levels.  The cinematography and lighting are spectacular and all the scenery and angles are very authentic with a real feel in natural lighting.  This is something you just don't see (maybe go back to Kubrick's Barry Lyndon).  The best part is there is almost no CGI with the exception of the bear, for which we understand and it doesn't last long.  This is the way movies should be made.  Great acting, strong story, visually pleasing and full of suspense.  It is raw and rough!  If you rent it watch it in high def on a big screen :)

You think the Natives are going to kill him.

You think the river is going to kill him.
You think the French are going to kill him.
You think the fall is going to kill him.
You think the illness is going to kill him.
You think the guy killed him.
You think he's going to get revenge but let's someone else kill the guy.

I could have done without the "Extra" documentary railing on fossil fuel and it being a major contributor of global warming/climate change. It took 5 years to make this film and they stated that they had to leave Canada during the winter as there was a lack of snow and finish filing in Argentina. All the while they show tons of vehicles (some massive to hold cameras, back ground panels for lights, special effects (Green screens), ATV's cars and I'm sure they flew cast & crew to these locations over the 5 year. I guess they don't consider making a movie contributes to this "climate change"  nor enlarged their "carbon footprint". I would have much rather seen how the movie was made and how some of the special effects (Spoiler alert: Grizzly attack) was accomplished. I actually thought Leo had a better Oscar winning performance in the Aviator than this film, but he did a good job in this film and rpobably got the best actor for being snubbed in other films.

I watched this movie since it did seem interesting to me, I love history, and it had won an Academy Award.

The acting was not bad but I found Tom Hardy to be a better actor than Leo. If you have a short attention span or get bored easily, avoid watching this movie as there's a lot of scenes with characters traveling, not talking, and not doing much of anything at all.  So if you get bored easily, don't watch this movie as you'll probably wind up turning it off.

The natural scenery in the film was beautiful and a pleasure to see.  If I was rating only the scenery and cinematography I would give it five stars.

If you are looking for the true life story of Hugh Glass, look elsewhere as this is a made up Hollywood story.  There are way too many plot holes, the plot of the film was extremely predictable, and overall the story of the film is lacking.  It would have been extremely helpful had there been dates or text that explained what year it was, and the location of where the film took place for viewers who are unfamiliar with Hugh Glass and his life.

Basically this is a film about survival and brutality, both on an individual level and also on a group level. It's about revenge. And it's also about the idea of kindness versus cruelty. you could even substitute "surviving" for "cruelty" because the two things are blurred in this film. I thought it was a very solid movie overall (you have to be able to stomach a lot of gore and death to enjoy the film). The only thing I didn't like about it was it took the angle of mysticizing the Indian experience, which is totally fine, except that when white people do it (Hollywood), it invariably comes across as being patronizing.

This film is as near to perfect as filmmaking can get.  From the strong directing and acting that drives the realistic nature of its core elements, to the breathtaking cinematography that poetically reveals the frightening beauty of natural landscapes alongside gritty portrayal of man in his most humbled form.

  Winner of three Academy Awards (Best Director, Alejandro Inarritu; Best Actor, Leonardo DiCaprio; Best Cinematography, Immanuel Lubezki) and nominee for twelve (including Best Picture, Best Makeup Design, and Best Visual Effects), featuring the well-known one-take bear attack, inspirational cinematography that is customary of "Chivo" Lubezki (Children of Men, Gravity, and Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance)), and an underlying theme of the will to survive even in the most trying of circumstances, this is a must-watch cinematic experience like no other.

  Though there are five stars in my rating, I must give warning: this film is graphic in its depiction of life in the rugged West of the early nineteenth century.  Though no visuals are extreme over-the-top violence (in other words, "gratifyingly grisly"); instead, every disturbing image is shown in a realistic manner to express the depravity of man.  Also, some language is present (as a warning to those bothered thereby).  The nudity is brief and not sensual.  One brief disturbing [] scene, cut short by a rescuer.

On a percentage scale, a 94%.

2 hours and forever minutes full of nothing but production mistakes and errors that did nothing but make me remember that it was JUST a movie. From scenes where "fresh" snow was covering up the body of the boy and then 10 seconds later there was NO SNOW on the nearby rocks, to an indian (OOPS, Native American) was in a tree above a camp with 45 armed men in it (just how did he get there, beam me in Scottie?). And then just who was the DUMBA$$ that thinks having the actor fog up the camera lens with his breath is riveting and or getting the fake blood to splash onto the lens in another scene, all that does it make you remember ITS JUST A MOVIE. Movies are supposed to draw you in, suspend reality, The reality here: DO NOT WASTE THE $$ renting or buying this turd. But I should've known, I don't think I've ever seen an Academy Award winning movie that lived up to the hype and this certainly was no exception. The one clever thing in the movie was the dead captain propped upright on the lead horse with Leo on the rear horse playing dead. TTFN

I watched this three times. The story is good. I do have some issues regarding the setting. This incident happened in South Dakota. There are mountains in South Dakota but no where near the Missouri River. Bear skins, like the one Hugh/Leonardo wears were worn with the fur in to insulate and the skin out to keep out the rain and snow. Poor Hugh/Leonardo wears it inside out for this movie. The bear attack is CG but really well done with the exception that when a bear attacks it will go for the neck and break it first. Being between a female and cubs will surely get the bear's and your attention. The Fitzgerald protagonist is just nasty enough in demeanor and voice that he is a great villain in the story. I love the outdoors and have hiked many miles and camped many nights in the area where this actually did occur although Fort Kiowa is now underwater due a dam being built. The buffalo are gone, the grizzly are gone, the wolves are gone, and this review is done.

The plot, outcome, narrative was terribly crude, basic and certainly could have been more clearly demonstrated to the viewer.  The hazards, risks, of weather, interactions with natives, in the '30s continuous battles with tribes and yes the few whites that "went west" for riches and adventure.
The full bear wrap could easily weighed in over two hundred pounds and the "star" wouldn't have been able to stand...the water shots to demonstrate limits or hazards was very incomplete.  I believe nest movie requires an  historian of note and a more accurate view of winter survival...

I have poor vision and my boyfriend wanted to watch this movie so I went ahead and rented it on Amazon but I felt bad because I had to have him read the subtitles to me the whole time. I'm not knocking subtitles and I do enjoy movies that have other languages but just be aware that you'll have to do a lot of reading when watching this movie!

Overall I felt the first half was more exciting than the second half. I heard different responses from people that I know before I watched this movie. A lot of people said it was a good but boring movie. I think overall it was good but there were some "boring" parts. It's a long movie but it's intense at times too. I think it's funny that there were a couple British actors in this movie that were sporting American accents. In all honesty (I might get downvoted for this) I liked Tom Hardy's accent better than Leo's accent. I'm surprised Tom Hardy didn't win an Oscar because I felt his acting was actually better than Leo's but that's just my personal opinion. With that being said though I think the acting was great and I still don't know how they did the animal carcass scene when Leo went inside it to take shelter. I don't know how that was staged so that's pretty amazing prop design.

I'll start by saying that the cinematography is incredible in this film, and if we were going by visuals alone, I'd give it 5 stars. What I found hard to follow was the plot line. Lots of important information is introduced to the viewer with the assumption they'll know what's going on, or if they don't, they'll catch on eventually. And I guess you do, however, this film would have benefitted from either some narration or some fade ins/outs denoting how much time has passed in the story. I realize this was a stylistic choice, and I can respect that while still thinking it takes a little bit of depth away from the rich and incredible true-life-to-film story of Hugh Glass.

The violence in this film was shocking, I thought it was WAY gorier than Game of Thrones or other known-to-show-violence films. I suppose they wanted to depict how tough life was back then for trappers, and they do a great job of it. At times, you're left wondering how in the heck Hugh Glass survived the bear attack when you can see his shoulder bone (?!) after the attack. Surely that would get infected to the point of death? Then again, that's why this story stands the test of time. It's just crazy he survived.

One more thing...my guy and I were joking that this could alternately be titled "Hugh Glass: Worst Wilderness Guide, Ever." And while misfortune fell upon him time upon time in this film, you just gotta ask yourself, why did he sign up for a job he's clearly bad at? Awww.

PS. My favorite character is John Fitzgerald - Tom Hardy's performance is seamless.

I was not familiar with Hugo Glass and didn't realize until after watching this movie that this was loosely based on events with Glass in the 1800s.  The movie did interest me in learning more about the Glass story.  The movie is beautifully done with some breathtaking wilderness scenery.  The filmmakers really do a good job at portraying both the beauty and harshness of the Pacific Northwest with a realistic feel of what life as a fur trader would have been at the time.  Leonardo Dicaprio is very good in his portrayal as Glass but to me Tom Hardy is brilliant in his role as Fitzgerald.  The story, although maybe not historically accurate, is well done and entertaining.  The graphic scenes have a realistic feel to them, especially the bear attack scene, which was one of the most realistic looking animal attacks I have seen in a movie.  The movie is a bit long to me though at nearly 2 hours and 40 minutes and there are some moments that are a bit slow paced and a bit drawn out that could have been shortened a bit.  The excellent story and great character acting by the two main leads more than makes up for the extended length of the film.  It was definitely a worthwhile and entertaining movie to watch.

This movie starts out with the most ridiculous and unrealistic Indian fight for a movie reported to be a cut above the rest.  Men getting killed by arrows from what must certainly be too far a distance, considering that the people being shot at couldn't even see their attackers.  At one point a guy climbing onto a boat gets killed by an arrow and when the camera turns toward the Indians, there was clearly no one close enough to have shot the arrow.  Another Indian gets shot down from high up in a tree.  How did he get up there?  Clearly by a ladder behind the scenes.  And right in the middle of the camp of trappers, too.  And no one noticed him climbing?  It was not a realistic climb anyway unless the climber had superhuman strength.  Junk so far.  I skipped this in the movies but bought the DVD on impulse.  I'm only about 13 minutes into this movie and hating it.  Story first (and plausible!), special effects and action second.

About 50 minutes to go.  They should have named this movie, The Passion of the DiCaprio.  If you're going to make a movie about a real person, at least do honor to the memory of the individual by telling his/her story as faithfully as possible.  This movie is nothing more than inspired by a real event, but the movie itself is pure fiction.  The true story is lost to history, but this doesn't even mirror too well the story that history records.  So change the names and make your movie.  That aside, one could appreciate the movie on its own merits... if it's good.  Is it any good?  The answer here is... no.  It's not that good.  All awards should be returned.  As for Leonardo, this is barely acting.  You want acting, you should see the pained look on my face as I watch this.  No wait, that's not acting.

The movie's strengths: the Man versus Nature theme and nature's cruel indifference, the beautiful nature shots, the incredible natural lighting videography, the amazing action scenes in which you feel completely immersed, the superb acting by the entire cast (Di Caprio' brilliance is very much expected but Will Poulter, Forrest Goodluck and Tom Hardy also leave a lasting impression).

The movie's weaknesses: The revenge plot is almost corny and the end somewhat predictable, including the climactic high-noon face to face combat between the protagonist and the villain, some themes seem to be borrowed and deja-vu, attempts at symbolism are sometimes too obvious and pretentious, and lack of emotional impact due to undeveloped themes (compare for example Braveheart's wife mirage apparition with Glass's). Also, the plot at times seems to stretch the plausibility boundary: Glass survives a brutal Grizzly attack, swimming in freezing waters and a waterfall, an attack by an Indian tribe, an attack by French trappers, a fall from a cliff, and of course, hand to hand combat with the movie's villain.

All in all however, this is a movie well worth watching, despite its weaknesses. I should also put the disclaimer that it is not for the faint of heart, there are scenes that will turn your stomach if you are sensitive to gore, but hey, this is nature at its best and worst!

And if you're expecting much acting from Leonardo, not happening,  He dreams, he fights, he walks, he shoots, he walks, he fights, he dreams,  he walks, he shoots, he walks, It just goes on and on.  I've reviewed 2 movies on here in all these years, despite having rented over a hundred.  This one was terrible, and David and Goliath was the worst movie I've ever seen in my entire life. The storyline is based on a true story of Hugh Glass who was an American frontiersman, fur trapper, fur trader, hunter, and explorer in the 19th century. If you like movies made during that century and can stand to watch/hear the drama of him being pretty much dead then alive... repeat, repeat, repeat... ugg, then OK this movie you'll enjoy!  His acting was good but I don't think I would watch it for a 2nd time around.

Almost superhuman in his ability to survive injuries that would have killed a mere mortal man, the character still lacked depth and the plot was thin and undeveloped.  I'd give it less than one star if I could.  The film seemed to drag on forever.  At one point during one of the many gory fight scenes, fake blood and snow splashes onto the camera's lens.  Really?  why did that not end up on the editing floor?  The whole absurd movie was pointless and depressing.  The bright spot?  I rented it with a free coupon from a brick and mortar video store so only my precious time was wasted.

Finally sat down to watch this Oscar winner the other night and was really impressed with it. I've mentioned in other reviews that if you are going to have a movie where there isn't much dialogue then there'd better be some compelling scenes to watch...this movie shows exactly how to do that. There are large portions of this film where not a word is uttered but you can't stop watching the on-going struggles. Then of course you have characters too that really make you feel something. Tom Hardy plays a man that I found myself on the border of hating, I felt he was selfish and self-serving...and he is, but he's also someone trying to survive and make a living for himself in a very harsh environment.

As for Dicaprio, I know many may not agree with me but I can see why he finally won an Oscar for this performance and I feel he deserved it. Yes, there were other really good movies out there (some nominated, some not) but I do feel he did an outstanding job given the story, character, environment....and lack of dialogue. You saw so much and he said so little, not all actors can do that.

Ok...you may have heard about the bear scene, it's a really tough scene to watch! I found myself cringing due to the reality of it so of course...there's violence in this movie. It's man against nature and man against man....that's going to have violence and language, so if you have little ones save this movie for when they aren't around.

I rarely purchase movies anymore but this is one that's going in my video library as I know I'll watch it again.

3 hours of Leo giving birth to himself.
There is very little to like about this film. A few well staged fight scenes, but even they feel forced and gimmicky.
I'm at a loss understanding why Leo won for this, maybe it was just finally his time (seems strange to say with someone still young)? He usually has a lot more to work with, but here he is playing himself - Leo on a Dream-quest. Seriously 1/4 of the movie was dreams and hallucinations and they were as pedestrian and rote as the rest of the movie.
This was so much better when it was called Jeremiah Johnson. Redford and Pollack and Milius did it so much better 44 years ago. And that's not just a film snob saying all movies in the 70s are better. If this was exciting or even visually beautiful or well acted or anything really. it's just so mediocre.
This movie brought nothing new, to an now ancient premise. The new camera they used added nothing, in fact this is one of the flattest, no-depth westerns I have ever seen. Could be the transfer, could be whatever they did to it in the Digital Intermediate stage, but this movie looks like Terry Gilliam shot it during a frightening bout with depression, everything is low and wide angle and blue, providing none of the staggering Malick-esque landscapes/nature you were expecting. And at $135m could they not afford film? Hateful Eight was $54m and shot on 65m film. That looked great, not world changing, but definitely leagues better than this. I know it's unfair to focus so much on the look, movies are not just the look, but this was being touted as some great visual masterpiece AND if there is little else to focus on with such dirth of story, acting and actual activity, it should at least be visually interesting. Malick understands this, if you make your images really beautiful, people will put up with all amounts of filmmaking indulgence in other departments. The whole movie was missing something in every department, so it was impossible to really get into the film. It wouldn't let me in, no matter how close the camera was.
Everything about this film is unrelenting and not in a good way. The suffering is so long and intense it becomes ineffective pretty much ten minutes after it starts, so the rest is a slog. You then begin expecting a payoff for your attention and there is none. It then becomes comical by the end and since there is zero humor, it almost dips into Mystery Science Theatre camp. I mean with the amount of abuse Glass survives he should be the hardest MF ever and you want all the characters to recognize this, you want his character to get some recognition, for people to pay for doing this to him, but there is none. If this were a Clint Eastwood movie, oh lord the payoff would have been biblical.
Acting - Leo is good, but he has been so much better, in fact his drug-induced-country-club-escape scene from Wolf of Wall Street is better than his entire performance in this film, in fact that scene would be a great parody of this film. Hardy is so annoying in this with his new mumbly-voice-for every-role-actorly-affectations, I don't even want to see what he does next. For me, he has yet to live up to the promise of his incredible performance in Bronson. Gleeson is terrible as the only voice of reason, not believable in any way. Why they keep putting this guy from and center in movies is beyond me. He nearly ruined Ex Machina. He knows all the beats, but has no rhythm. He is always opposite much better actors and he is given roles that are way out of his range. The rest of the cast is okay, but they are merely scenery for Hardy to chew.
There is some shoddy CGI fauna here and it doesn't gel. it looks like they didn't plan it well enough or just decided to fix it in post. The Edge did bear attacks better, much much better. Although this definitely tries to win the "okay just stop" award.
So again, everything here you've seen before, scene after scene, done better elsewhere. Empire Strikes Back, Rob Roy, The Edge, Jeremiah Johnson, The Duelists.
I'm sure I'll get hating comments, but from the talent involved I was expecting so much more.
I think The Grey or The Edge are great companion pieces to this, showing how to properly do brutal survival in the wild stories, and those had Liams Neesons, and Sir Anthony Hopkins at the top of their game in them.

The Revenant has beautiful scenery, plenty of realistic makeup but the story line is oh so slooooow! If you love to be bored on a rainy afternoon (or evening) then this is the movie for you! I thought it was time for a good script for DiCaprio -  guess not.

Grab the hatchet and give em green river boys!  This film does for the trapper era of the American West what Saving Private Ryan did for WWII.  It brought out the senses of taste, smell, and touch.  It also shows the multi layered characters in a complicated time.  It is relevant for modern era life just as it was then.  Tribe vs. tribe, man vs. man, man vs. beast, kill or die.  As a child this was my favorite era of American history to read about.  Walking off into the mountains with primitive tools, and making it.  It's a much different thing to watch a film like this in contrast to the bite of the cold in your bones, the cold heat of a knife through flesh, and the taste of blood and death.  This takes away the masturbatory element and leaves you with that copper in your mouth, and a growling in your gut.

There were non-speaking scenes where his emotions and body language came through loud and clear...amazing.  The director deserved his "Best Director" award also, and the scenery was breathtaking.  I will watch this Blue-ray disc many, many times.

"The Revenant" is an epic frontier art adventure film, directed by Alejandro G. Inarritu (2014's Birdman) and it loosely retells the story of fur trapper "Hugh Glass" ( and when I mean loosely I mean like at least 1 or 2 percent of the film is truth and the rest is just added for the film.) This movie is not for the faint of heart, it is hands down one of the most brutal, blood soaked films I have seen in a long time. What I loved this most about this film is the sense of utter hopelessness you get once glass,s journey home begins. Its incredibly bleak, incredibly dark and I love every moment of it (mostly). Since this is from the director of birdman there will a lot of art house style imagery most of which works very well  and if you've seen birdman a certain image from that film that makes an appearance which made think what is the relevance of that image? This is an incredibly haunting  film experience and its amazing! SEE IT.

THE REVENANT is truly amazing and mesmerizing on all levels but it is also unnerving and difficult to watch through much of the film. It's totally beautiful on one hand and brutally realistic on the other. One thing is clear. Leonardo DiCaprio is one of America's finest actors who gives it his all-both physically and emotionally-to any role he takes on.  The Oscars for best actor and best director (Alejandro G. Inarritu) were well-deserved.

Inarritu became famous for putting his actors through treacherous conditions for realism and it shows. I was never clear exactly where the film was set but the conditions are harsh in a barren snow-filled landscape. The scenery itself is worth viewing the film. I only wish I had seen it on the big screen.

The story is based on the true story of Hugh Glass who survives a vicious bear and is left for dead by his companions. DiCaprio plays Glass and in this version it seems reasonable that the fur trappers have to leave him for dead or put him out of his misery humanely. Clearly, they can't help him and he won't survive. He is dying and  will only slow them down as they try to evade an outraged band of Native Americans. Glass' son is killed so Glass has every reason to survive and seek revenge.

It's a painful story to watch as DiCaprio is attacked by a bear and brutalized by humans. The pain is clear in his face, voice and body movements. It can be difficult to watch and it gets slow at times as DiCaprio drags himself across the frozen wasteland. It is a story of revenge and redemption. It's brutally ugly at times yet always hypnotically beautiful. THE REVENANT is a fascinating journey into filmmaking. It's more about the story than astonishing visual effects that are so popular now. It's not a family film or for the squeamish but definitely a film to see.

A story that tells a tale we modern people cannot fathom of the brutal life in the wilderness of past generations and the hardships they endured. Yes, its a tale of survival and revenge but it also portrays the life of soldiers, trappers and Indians of the era. Expert cinematography, realism and acting. Dicaprio is a true chameleon, changing personas in completely believable ways with each diverse role he takes. Highly recommended.

This film was great. If you want to tote that the cinematography was defeated by "Hateful Eight" then I think you need to go watch some more film and give a more refined critique other than babbling about nonsense you know nothing about. The film is honestly meant to be a reflection of humanity and brutality. Most of the fact that Leo doesn't speak is because he did something most actors have a hard time with. Characterization is more than just words. Its in the yes and the way we crook our mouths when our wives chastise us for something we know we should've done. It the way we let out that heavy sigh of remorse and hopelessness when we come to find a character was terminated from a job he's held for the last 20 years. In acting its the little things that count and help us to remember the beautiful and or haunting things represented in film. This movie did it perfectly and the music was absolutely chilling and so atmospheric that I couldn't help but cry at some of the scenes with the character and his dead boy as he was lying with him. Can I give this movie a 10/10? No, because the film was not perfect; however, it was a terrific film. 8.5/10 and truly brilliant.

Released in late 2015, The Revenant stars Leonardo DiCaprio as Hugh Glass, a man who in real life survives a mauling by a grizzly bear and makes his way crawling and stumbling 200 miles to Fort Kiowa, in South Dakota, after being abandoned without supplies or weapons by fellow explorers and fur traders during General Ashley's expedition of 1823. Vengeful, Glass then sets out to confront his trapping partners who left him to die. The movie's loosely based on these events, but the locations are far removed from the Missouri River area of South Dakota, which makes for a more scenic experience in light of the locations being spectacular.

The story was first made into a movie as 1971s Man in the Wilderness starring Richard Harris and John Huston. Whereas that movie has the better story The Revenant has the better filmmaking. Its not just that its a more expensive production with outstanding location shooting and quality actors, but also the modern filmmaking technique is superlative. If you like wilderness survival/adventure movies then The Revenant is a must. While the film runs over two and a half hours it kept my attention throughout and didn't seem that long. Its thoroughly realistic except that its marred by Road Runner-like sequences (youll know what I mean).

The film runs 156 minutes and was shot in Alberta, British Columbia, Montana, Arizona, Mexico and Argentina.

GRADE:  B

This has become one of my very favorite movies and I have watched it four times.  "The Revenant" disserved every Oscar it won and probably more. The story is based on the true story of Hugh Glass, who is 1823, went on an expedition into uncharted territory with a group of fur trappers and was actually mauled by a bear, but apparently not to the extent that DiCaprio was in the movie. The difference was that the real Glass was not left behind to die alone in the snow and cold of a northern winter.

The movie is a wonder of excellent acting, cinematography, sound, directing, and DiCaprio tells his story without saying a whole lot throughout the movie.  It is a story of revenge and survival that is told so well by the wrting, co-production and direction of Alejandro G. Inarritu.  The first inkling for making the movie first surfaced with Inarritu in 2001, so it took a long time to finally get it made.  This film is a work of art that plays out in snow-filled, icy and uninhabited beautiful but sometimes deadly land, with Indian raids happening and the poignant  story of a lost Indian daughter.

Tom Hardy did an excellent job of acting, also.  His accent in the movie made me laugh every time I heard it at first.  This is a movie that shouldn't be missed.
Wonderfully executed film- although DeCaprio prbably didn't deserve the oscar. The direction and production skill is what makes this film. Almost every frame of this film is compelling art!

This movie does justice to the life story of the 19th century Rocky Mountain fur trapper.  Hugh Glass was and is still THE MAN.  Kudos to all the actors that participated in this intriguing flick.  One of my favorite movies of all time is "Jeremiah Johnson", and this flick ranks right up there with that mountain man classic.

I do like Westerns, Historical Movies, Movies based on True Stories, Fiction and Science Fiction. I do not quite know where to put The Revenant, though. The movie is quite violent, bloody and gory. There are a lot of cliches, too.

SPOILER ALERT:  DiCaprio's character is a scout with a Native American son. He witnesses his son being assassinated, whiles in a totally immobile state.  Apparently 'seeking revenge' is keeping  DiCaprio's character alive, although I do not feel it (or is it just me?) He oh so miraculously seems to heal a little more every time he goes through new challenges! Every other normal human would have died already after the bear attack! I think it would have even been very tough to survive that specific attack, even with our modern medicine, and having been airlifted to a hospital right away! So, after having been mauled by a bear and buried alive and left for dead, he crawls all the way through the woods to a cliff, and without revealing how he does it, next thing you know he is by the river down below. - He gets torn away through the white water as Indians chase him, and although the water must be just above freezing, he manages to drift and swim for what seems a way too long time not to die of hypothermia! - When he miraculously makes it to the shore and gets out of the water, ta-da he can walk again!

During the movie he repeatedly dreams of how he lost his Native American wife due to an attack on their village and how he saved his son from a fire. The dreams are always slightly different. I wonder, did the movie makers want to show how much his son meant to him and what his dead wife wants him to do, with this? And  justify his revenge, show him which way to go?

There is a also brutal tribe of Indians, who are in search of the Chief's daughter, who had been taken. They shoot and slaughter everybody they encounter in their way. - DiCaprio's character happens to find that lady just when she is being raped by a French Soldier, by a tree, right then and there where he is about to steal a horse. He helps her and they both get away.  Not before she takes "bloody revenge" on the Frenchman, though.

DiCaprio's Character meets an older Native American man, who is also lost his family. He happens to know a lot about herbal medicine too,  and submits DiCaprio's character into a "herbal sauna". And ta-da, when he emerges after spending the night in that miracle sauna, he seems to be nearly totally healed! Like finding the first aid kit in a video game! - Before that nice new Native American Buddy is killed by some evil racist bastards (who might have been those evil French dudes), he mentions to DiCaprio "Revenge is in God's Hands" somewhere in an earlier scene. - These words become like the "final cliche words" of the film. - To me that seems so ridiculous, as these words are definitely not new to us, are they? Romans 12:19 (I usually never recite the Bible!) Here I just had to make a relation to the Bible. Really? What is the point of this story? So it becomes all new and mythical when a Native American, close to earth Healer-man says it? "Vengeance is mine, I will repay, says the Lord", "Do not be overcome by evil but overcome evil with good." That was not the message of this movie either, so what was it?

Hardly anybody in this movie, but one of the commanding officers in charge played by Domhnall Gleeson, who hired DiCaprio's character and his son "Hawk" as scouts in the beginning of the story, and the nice Native American Buddy, are humane or trustworthy! It is a very "cold, wet, muddy" and dark movie, without a real purpose or plot, at least in my eyes!

If you enjoy pointless, pretentious, "artistic" posturing, if you find diversion in trying to invent meaning for visual compositions which contain none of their own, if you like to play "Guess Which Director Or Film He's Quoting From Now" (Adrei Tarkovsky, Akira Kurosowa, Terrence Malick, Francois Truffaut, endless anime, "Rashomon", "The 400 Blows"), if you don't care about story or even plot, but instead feel that whimsy and visual spectacle is what great film making is all about, then this is the movie for you.  If not, then the only reason to watch this movie is to wrack your brain trying to figure out why DiCaprio was given an Academy Award for this performance, which consists almost solely of grunting, rather than for his work in "The Aviator".  That, and the absolutely awful CGI grizzly sow.  I guess Bart the Bear has either retired or passed away without a successor.
Oh, and of course, the snowflake-eating scene.  How cute was that?!
It's hard to believe that this movie was written and directed by grown-ups.

It seems to me lately that the best movies I've watched have been based on really great books. Such is the case with Director Alejandro G. Irritu's award winning film The Revenant. (Based on Michael Punke's book) I always try to read the book first and then watch the movie. The book was fantastic and I hoped the movie would be as well.

The Revenant on Blu-ray and Digital HD is newly released from Twentieth Century Fox Home Entertainment.

And my hopes that the movie would be good were met and far exceeded. Leonardo DiCaprio won an Academy and Oscar Award for Best Actor. The film won numerous other prizes.

DiCaprio portrays Hugh Glass, a frontiersman/tracker in 1823 America with a fur company, who is severely mauled by a bear. With both winter and hostile natives on their heels, the company commander assigns two men, Fitzpatrick and Bridger to stay with Glass until he dies, bury him and then catch up with the rest of the company. Also with Glass is his son Hawk, who is sure his father can survive. Seemingly close to death, everyone figures it won't be long 'til the end.

Fitzpatrick, played by Tom Hardy, decides that he doesn't want to wait around for Glass to die and instead chooses to leave him on his own. Hardy brilliantly interprets the despicable character of Fitzpatrick. I don't know how many times I yelled at the screen.

But it is Leo who steals the show. He has very little dialogue, but his physical acting and his facial expressions (especially his eyes) transmit so much more than words could have. His courage, grit, perseverance and determination to hunt down Fitzpatrick becomes the viewer's goal as well.

Not far behind Leo is the cinematography - the backdrops are simply spectacular - the choice of actual settings instead of green screens brings the wildness and wilderness of the time and place to life. Costuming and physical props are just as believable. The bear attack is also really believable. (and a bit hard to watch)

Irritu has changed some of the events from the book - most notably, Glass's reason for revenge. But it works. This reason is more personal and will have the audience even more invested in Glass's drive for revenge. With every tortured step and obstacle thrown in his way, I was urging him forward, just as determined that he have his retribution. Irritu has also changed the ending from the book. It wasn't what I expected and I watched it two or three times. In the end, it seemed right and fit with the 'extra' character(s) that he had brought to his version of the story.

Brutal and brilliant, The Revenant is a welcome addition to my film library.

While Dicaprio's performance is spectacular, the plot is riddled with plot devices that are horribly under-developed, and under-explained. The viewer has no real reason to care about anyone with the exception of Leo, and then only after his son is killed (an hour into the movie). The side-plots are only used to push the main plot and are completely unexplained and possess no real redeeming quality to them. The only characters who were interesting were the ones who got glossed over. Leo's character is also severely under-developed. Overall it was a real let down.

Looking at the trailers I was expecting much more from this film.  On the plus side it is visually stunning with beautiful cinematography and Dicaprio is his usual excellent self.  That being said, there is much in this movie that defies all credibility so viewers really need to check their logic at the door to get through it.

For example, it's a good thing hypothermia and frostbite didn't exist back in the day with all the slogging around in ice water that goes on in this film.  Or, how falling off a hundred foot cliff doesn't even produce a single broken bone.

There are serious continuity lapses as well.  DiCaprio's right leg that he is dragging while crawling becomes his good leg when he begins to walk.  Oversights like this can really challenge a viewer's sensibilities.

Despite its flaws it's worth a look but know going in there are several reasons why this film didn't deserve or receive the Best Picture Oscar.
