I decided not to be one of the many who were illegally downloading this movie. I saw it in the theaters and was blown away. I waited to buy a dvd copy because I was really looking forward to seeing the extras. A movie of this caliber, I thought for sure that there would be extras covering behind-the-scenes filming in the wilderness, and a spotlight on the local indigenous peoples who featured in the movie. Nope. Be warned, there are ZERO extras on the dvd version. Apparently the blu-ray version has extras with a documentary on the shooting of the film, but the buyers of the dvd did not deserve the same courtesy. I am not impressed. Feels disrespectful.

Much was lost between the thrilling novel by Michael Punke (available here at Amazon) and the movie of it directed by Alejandro G. Irritu. Both were 'based on' the events in the life of Hugh Glass, so variations can be expected and are acceptable, but in the film there is far too much variation - the beginning, the middle and the end of the movie are completely different than the actual story. By giving Glass an Indian wife and son, both non-existent in the book, the whole impetus for his revenge is morphed as if being left helpless in winter without the very basic means for survival wasn't enough for him to seek revenge. I also found the made-up visitations by his dead wife in the movie to be eyerolling and very Hollywood; ditto his rapid healing from such grievous injuries in the movie belittles what he actually endured, such as crawling for a portion of 350 miles before reaching Fort Atkinson, and eliminated completely the life-saving medical help to heal infection given to him by one band of Indians, in the movie represented by a single Indian and some crumpled dry grass applied to his wounds. I tore through the book, so exciting and awe inspiring it was. The movie was to me meandering and mediocre, bordering on boring.
Good Tip: Read the book.

My issue is that the disc was defective. The audio skips and stutters and the video freezes periodically, making for an unpleasant viewing experience. There was no visible damage to the disc. Ok, so I returned it for a replacement disc. Same thing -- skips, stutters, & freezes in the same places even! I doubt very much this is an issue with my Blu-ray player. I have a fairly large collection of DVD & Blu-ray discs and use the player frequently. They all play just fine.
So, I give up. I am returning the replacement disk and asked for a refund, which Amazon granted with no problem. I guess I'll wait until later when another cut of the movie comes out. Hopefully, it will be better.

The Revenant is a long movie, but one I thoroughly enjoyed. As a previous reviewer wrote, "This film is both brutal and beautiful to watch."  Never were truer words written.  The violence is right in your face, and the viewer gets an excellent look at what life may have been like during the early part of the 19th Century.  The beauty of the locations were breathtaking to behold.  It could make you forget just how unforgiving and grueling nature can sometimes be.

I'm not going into details about the story.  Everyone should pretty much know the premise of the movie by now.  I will say that Leonardo DiCaprio definitely deserved his Academy Award for his role.  Another actor who also gives a performance that's worthy of an Oscar is Tom Hardy.  Next time bury Leo deeper in the shallow grave and the Academy Award might be yours.

I have to mention that the sequence where Leo is attacked by a grizzly bear blew me away.  I haven't watched the Extras on the disc yet, but I have to assume most of the sequence was an intricately designed special effect with a green screen.  Still, it looked real to me and had me holding my breath even though I knew Leo didn't die.  .

Since it's Friday, I'm going to watch the film again when I get home from work.  That's how good it is!

There are a lot of parts of the movie that simply do not make sense such as Glass being a supposed great tracker who cannot even find someone walking on fresh snow! There are more similar incidents.
Then there are the parts that require suspending any kind of reality, like nobody getting frostbite?
Then there are the background sounds which seriously detract from trying to follow the movie. Sounds like gunshots where there are none, whistling sounds for no reason and more.
Then there is the supposed father's love for his son which simply did not come across although there were obvious attempts to make it so.
Overall, not a very enjoyable movie and the three of us that watched this movie, concurred.

The Blu Ray presentation of The Revenant is top notch. It may be somewhat light on extra features but the picture and sound are absolutely breathtaking.

When I saw the film in the theater, I sat a little too close to the screen due to our party arriving late so I wasn't really able to take in just how gorgeous the cinematography actually was. Watching this on Blu Ray now, the picture is pretty much pitch perfect, with the reproduction of the visuals a sight to behold. Say what you want about the film but you absolutely cannot knock the film for its looks. This is one beautifully shot film.

The DTS-HD MA 7.1 sound mix is equally impressive, foregoing a more gimmicky presentation for one of quiet, natural ambiance and intelligently employed surround usage. The speakers are constantly active and quite frequently, you'll hear sounds panning across the entire soundstage, with dialogue and effects circling repeatedly throughout your speakers. The sound mix is detailed and nuanced, with a lot going on most of the time but never feeling cheap.

There's a nice little behind the scene featurette detailing Inarritu's vision and reasons for making the film and a still gallery rounding out the disc. If you enjoyed the film, I can't see why you wouldn't appreciate this disc as it's a fine production.

The Revenant tells the (loosely) true story of Hugh Glass, a fur trapper who's life takes a tragic turn in the blistering winter of the 1820s.

Your best bet going in to this one is to go in blind from spoilers and with a true appreciation for film making. A slow and brutal rollercoaster of bleak and raw emotion, the mainstream crowd will most likely find The Revenant "boring". However, if you salivate at nearly impossibly grandiose shots, masterful performances that pick at your heart one scene at a time, a thunderous and moving score and basically every element that makes a film worth owning and watching for the rest of your life, then you'll LOVE this one.

Everyone does a wonderful job here, DiCaprio and Hardy taking center stage. The long takes with entirely NATURAL LIGHTING are awe inspiring. The struggle of man before merciless nature is thought provoking beyond recognition. Sound was excellent as was the transfer of the film footage.  I had pre-ordered it and was thrilled that it arrived on time.

My next comment is about the movie itself, which I had not seen before.  If you plan on watching this as a semi-documentary, you can give that up now. While it was an amazing and heartbreaking story, it was even more heartbreaking to learn that the important part of the story, his deceased wife and his son, was not part of the true story.  I was also disappointed that they did not go further into his life following this incident.  It also did not make the time frame clear as to how long it took him to get back to the fort.

I was also disappointed in the documentary that  came with it.  It was interesting and timely, but had nothing to do with the story and the movie.  It focused on how horribly native Americans have been treated and on how climate change is affecting our world.  It did not focus on the making of the movie including how they created the real life  attack by the bear or the other special effects.

If you have already seen the movie, in the theater, and have been eager to see it on DVD, the cost is reasonable, so go for it.

If you have not already seen the movie and are thinking of buying it, I suggest you wait, see it when it comes on tv, then if you want to purchase it maybe they will have extras in the next dvd issue.

Disappointed - Decaprio's performance was great but the plot suffered from schizophrenia; torn between wanting to be a "historical epic" or just another "adventure flick." Apparently, the legend of Hugh Glass, a survivor of a grizzly bear attack who managed to survive in the wilderness driven by revenge against those who abandoned him, wasn't good enough for the filmmakers. They had to take it to extremes that were truly not believable. Native American portrayals were two-dimensional. There is so much to Native American culture than that which is depicted here; more "cowboys and Indians," more "good guys and bad guys." Suggest "Man in the Wilderness" or "Dances with Wolves" instead.

I was excited to see this movie, knowing it was based on the same story that the 1971 version "Man in the Wilderness" depicted, which starred Richard Harris, the survival story of a fur trapper in the 1820's who was mauled by a bear and left for dead.  Adding to my excitement was Leonardo DiCaprio playing the lead role.  It was extremely disappointing, right from the first scene of the movie.

The opening scene was ridiculously unreal.  It showed two trappers hunting an elk in a forest with large trees flooded with water.  Anyone who lives in a mountainous forested area (like me) knows there is no such thing as a forest of big trees growing out of expansive clear water that's flowing like a river.  In addition, any hunter will tell you that elk would not hang out in such a place.  It was such a fake scene, it was laughable.  There was no such scene in the original.

My second disappointment was it's depiction of Native Americans as violent, brutal enemies, in comparison to the "Man in the Wilderness" where Richard Harris was given a blessing by an Indian Chief when he was discovered lying on the ground after the mauling, then given respect by that Indian Chief later in the movie after he saw that he survived the mauling and was doing well.

My last disappointment was that Leonardo's character was married to an Indian woman, and had a grown son by her.  In M in W, he left a white pregnant wife to spend months away trapping for furs.  The Revenant was an extremely violent film, and I stopped watching it 2/3 of the way through it.

This movie doesn't compare to the "Man in the Wilderness", a much more realistic survival story, one of my favorite classics even though it was a B-rated film.  If you are expecting The Revenant to be the same story as M in the W, you will be sorely disappointed.  The story line was totally different, and was very weak.  I don't know why it received any academy awards at all.

I would call this an Adult Guy Movie, and the male members of our family certainly loved it. I found it to be too dismally gloomy and the violence too chilling & unrelenting to be that enjoyable. Vicious attacks by nature, animal, and human-against-human are disturbing to those sensitive to it--such as children--so be warned. But the acting was indeed superb. Tom Hardy as the villain was my favorite - amazing - as he dances that line between evil, mercenary, and just plain 'I-been-in-these-here-mountains-too-long' craziness; a man who has forgotten his humanity and lives without remorse. Dicaprio didn't impress me as much, but he grinds through this long survival story to win his Oscar, at last. The movie was shot in natural light only, in winter, which colors everything an icy gray. Don't expect a happy story or a just one--or that it is exactly chronicling "history" either. This is the Old West at its most brutal in storytelling.

If you like that sort of thing, then you'll like this.

The credits say this movie is based partly on a novel but there really was a man badly mauled by a bear that was left for dead by his "friends".  Many months and hundreds of miles later he came walking out of the woods so this script isn't that far fetched on that point.  The guy in this movie goes through Indian attacks, a bear mauling, surviving in the winter in the mountains with no weapon or supplies, a run in with some not so good French guys, and a final, bloody knife, hatchet, gun fight.  Whew, five men couldn't survive all that in real life.  The bear attack was well done and looked real to me so you be the judge if you have children as to whether they should watch this.  The acting is as good as it gets by everybody, not just DiCaprio.  The "F" word is used some but it has become so common in movies today that younger people may not be bothered by it.

Hardy is believable, as a 'bad guy' and his performance is so finely honed, you  forget it's Hardy.  Leonardo does a fantastic job capturing the emotion and tragedy he's endured then, and in his previous life.
The portrayal of the Native American's;  their life, and their love for family/tribe/culture was very well done as well.

Well, i know about all the raves, awards, etc. about "The Revenant" , that's why i bought it. The awards are fully justified, Dicaprio's acting was indeed excellent as was the direction. The scenery and  costumes were excellent and period correct. Some of the special effects were extraordinary, others just so so. My big issue with this movie was the Audio and Dialogue. Had it not been for the sub titles at the beginning, i would have had no clue what was happening to whom and why. When the subs dropped off, the English dialogue was at best awful, and at worst totally unintelligible. Whether or not this was by design or other reason, i do not know. In fairness, i did not go to a theater but rather bought the digital copy through Amazon. That being said, i watched on a 42" 1080 p TV with an  above average 5.1 surround system. i estimate i missed almost 50% of the dialogue. To me, this is unacceptable in a movie of this magnitude and tainted my experience with an otherwise excellent presentation.

Inarritu's films are all great and I was looking forward to seeing what The Revenant would be like; with DiCaprio's presence it seemed it might promise to be more 'Hollywoody'. Amores Perros, Babel and Biutiful, for instance, are all strong films about today's culture, looking at how people fit in with the modern world, within whatever narrative Inarritu chooses (global themes). His films withstand analysis on many levels, symbolic, ethical, individual versus the world etc, and are always riveting, but not always easy to watch. I remember Amores Perros opening with its dog fights, I did feel like not watching the film, but those dog scenes at the beginning are critical to the films structure as dogs run throughout the film and it's interesting to later see how Inarritu uses dogs' 'characters' to link in with the human stories.

The Revenant is different in this respect, its 'depth' isn't in a complex narrative, and that is to the film's credit - it's rawer, more in-your-face. Where the other films looked at man in the modern world, this one goes back a bit, and due to what happens in the story, throws Leonardo into the wild - a chance to bear witness to Man's direct strugle with Nature. The result is a beautiful film that makes stark comment on life and what it means to be alive.

The film is deliberately brutal, but at the same time doesn't miss the beauty. It often feels apocalyptic in the sense of 'final destruction', and I guess with the Revenant title that destruction is what is being examined. To concentrate this in two hours of film is, in a way, unnatural, so for me it doesn't properly reflect Nature. I don't believe Nature is as unredemptive as the film pretends (it can also be eternal, dull, light / dark, perfect - it's many things). That said, the film is great in the way it enables you to question this point and possibly disagree with 'on est tous des sauvages'. In fact art is often an attempt to escape savagery, where others would counter art is artifice, I would suggest art signifies something very real . . .

Somebody mentioned in another review there is a lot of mumbling. That is true of the very beginning of the film - it's one of my pet hates that with certain films you can't hear the dialogue properly, it can ruin a film. Thankfully with this film it was OK. It might have been intentional to represent the chaos of battle - that you wouldn't necessarily hear / perceive every detail. It's also done in a later scene when there is some Pawnee prayer or poem (I think) in the background of a storm.

In order to really appreciate the story this movie is trying to relay, you must turn off everything around you that will distract you. This means phones of any kind, turn off the lights and tell the people (if there are any) to sit down and give you four hours of peace. Turn the movie on don't just watch it,but truly absorb the contents of this visual experience. You should not seek instant or rushed gratification; allow your self to become part of the experience and when you have allowed your self to escape your present day to day life happenings time willn't matter . When you are done absorbing the contents of this DVD (the feature film and extras), you should be left with a sense of sadness due to the things lost and what we are losing;consequently,there should also be a sense of shame, because of how we treat each other ,what we are allowing to happen to the only planet we have and the inhabitants on it. It is very hard to find people that care about what they sign their names to, it seems the people involved with this project really understood the big picture. If this doesn't happen for you, I suggest you go and re watch  some reality TV show. I'm sorry if any one was offended during the reading of this review.

Ok I am & have always been a stickler about getting the facts right when Hollywood makes a movie about real life events & books!  But I have grown to learn that for many different reasons such as time constraints I have learned to be less critical.  We may never know the actual details of many tales coming from the old west gunfighters & especially tales of the reclusive mountain men.  This is because the more civilized east coast printing presses had a tendency to glorify the truth to sensationalism for sales reasons.  The tales of men like "Jeremiah Johnson", " John Colter" & " Hugh Glass" have been retold so many times that they come to us far removed from the few reclusive men who may have had a more accurate account of the truth!  That being said I just have to enjoy this wonderful period piece for what it offers.  I have seen very low reviews based on Hugh Glasses" remarkable recovery saying that could never happen!!!  This is far from  the truth you cannot place your own mental & physical limitations on other humans.  I myself walked away from a car accident with a broken neck & my back broke in 2 places as well as both femur heads being fractured.  I have heard of another man who broke both legs & a Arm as well as having many superficial cuts climb out of a cave with nothing but a Bic Lighter!!!  Not only that but they never tell you precisely how long it took Hugh Glass to gain mobility!!!  The cinematography in this movie is spectacular as well as the sets & costume pieces right down to the language.  This movie is a thrill ride of action & adventure & a wonderful addition to anyone's movie library as there seems to be a lack of "Mountain Man" type movies.  As far as acting its great but Leonardo DiCaprio  certainly showcased is acting range & ability far better in "The Aviator" portraying the reclusive millionaire Howard Hugh's.  I don't like to give away to many spoilers in my reviews so I will just say that this movie should appeal to many... even those not into westerns or period pieces.

The Revenant should have won the Oscar for Best Picture. It is a movie experience that is exhilarating, magnetic, sad, and adventuresome all at the same time.  Leonardo DiCaprio finally won the Oscar for Best Actor for this film and it was rightly deserved. It is not a flashy performance in the way of The Wolf of Wall Street (he should have won that Oscar too) or his greatest performance as Howard Hughes in Martin Scorsese's The Aviator (he should have won that Oscar as well) but it is despite the harshness that his character must go through in the film, the subtle performance that captures what acting really is. The story is not told in the grunts or yells of pain and revenge in DiCaprio's voice, but in his eyes. You could just look at his eyes in this movie and understand the emotion this man is going through, especially the last seen with DiCaprio's character Hugh Glass and his son. Leo truly put in a landmark performance in the history of cinema. He BECAME Hugh Glass. The best movie of the year.

"The Revenant" is brilliant. This is how the story goes: In 1823, while on a fur trading expedition, frontiersman Hugh Glass fights for survival after being mauled by a bear and left for dead by members of his own hunting team.

The cast led by Leonardo DiCaprio (superb in his Oscar-winning performance as Hugh Glass) & Tom Hardy (just as superb in his Oscar-nominated performance as John Fitzgerald) is brilliant. The (Oscar-winning) directing by Alejandro G. Irritu (who also produced and co-wrote the screenplay) is brilliant. The screenplay (based on part by the novel by Michael Punke) by Irritu & Mark L. Smith is brilliant.

The music by Ryichi Sakamoto & Alva Noto, with additional music by Bryce Dessner is brilliant. The (Oscar-winning) cinematography by Emmanuel Lubezki is brilliant. The (Oscar-nominated) film editing by Stephen Mirrione is brilliant. The casting by Francine Maisler is brilliant. The (Oscar-nominated) production design by Jack Fisk is brilliant. The art direction by Laurel Bergman, Michael Diner & Isabelle Guay is brilliant. The (Oscar-nominated) set decoration by Hamish Purdy, set dressings by Mike Marston, Rob White, Jacques Larrue, Steve Tex Killi, Prescott Beresh, Matthew Carswell, Chuck Coffman, Shane John, Joelle McLellan, Kevin Kasper, Caitlin Jane Parsons & Sarah Shruger-Thibodeau, set designs by Joe Wolkosky is brilliant. The (Oscar-nominated) costume design by Jacqueline West is brilliant. The (Oscar-nominated) make-up effects by Duncan Jarman & Sian Grigg is brilliant. The stunts coordinated by Mark Vanselow, Doug Coleman, Scott J. Ateah & Brian Machleit and fights coordinated by Adam Hart is brilliant. The special effects coordinated by Steve Riley, Stewart Bradley, Pau Costa, Eduardo Puga & P. David Benediktson and supervised by Ante Dugandzic, John Rosengrant & Cameron Waldbauer is brilliant. The creature effects supervised by Mark Rappaport are brilliant. The (Oscar-nominated) visual effects coordinated by Ashley Manning, Shandy Lashley, Tyler A. Johnson, Elizabeth Leslie, Sarah Moussaif, Kraig Tytus, Tom Barber, Cj Cole, Sherin Padayatty, Raphaelle Weisz & Daniel Charchuk and supervised by Rick Smith, Matt Shumway, Olcun Tan, Jason Smith, Allan Magled, Richard McBride, Peter Nofz, Nicolas Chevallier, Asregadoo Arundi & Jeffrey Charles Higgins is brilliant. The (Oscar-nominated) sound mixing by Jon Taylor, Frank A. Montao, Randy Thom & Chris Duesterdiek and (Oscar-nominated) sound editing by Martn Hernndez, Randy Thom & Lon Bender is brilliant.

This is a brilliant, well-done, well-crafted film that is entertaining and well-made. Leonardo DiCaprio gives his best performance of his career, so far, as does, Tom Hardy. Alejandro G. Irritu has directed another impressively crafted film to his resume. This is (or was) one of the best films of the holiday season (Christmas 2015) and is also one of the best films of last year, as well, too. This is (or was) also a well-deserved awards contender, as well, too.

The only "but" I have is that I felt it used flashbacks poorly and tried to tell the story of the main characters past a little to "ephemerally"... I get it, it was supposed to give depth to the character, but it slowed down the movie to the point that at times I would be pulled out of the experience to think... "what time is it" or "geez, this thing is really long".... and that is the sure sign that the director/editor need to "tighten it up" a little.

That being said... it is a truly beautifully-shot movie that makes you feel the pain and cold and struggle of all of its characters and the land around them.

The Revenant is set during the winter of 1823 on the Great Plains. This Alejandro Inarritu-directed film stars Leonardo Di Caprio as real-life Hugh Glass, a frontiersman hired as a scout to guide a team of fur trappers through harsh territory. The journey is plagued by Indians, bitter cold, and dangerous terrain. Glass keeps watch over his teenage son, Hawk (Forrest Goodluck), who is half Pawnee.

The movie chronicles the obstacles  from nature and man  faced by the trappers as they attempt to get back to Fort Kiowa. Tom Hardy co-stars as Fitzgerald, a particularly untrustworthy member of the party, and Domhnall Gleeson portrays Capt. Andrew Henry, their official leader.

A highlight of the movie is an attack on Glass by a bear rendered with computer imagery. The sequence is incredibly realistic as Glass is tossed about like a rag doll and clawed repeatedly. After the attack and his near-death experience, we focus on Glass struggle to survive alone in the wilderness.

Di Caprio dominates the film. With very little dialogue, he builds his performance on physical action, expression, and pantomime. The films violence reflects the harsh, unforgiving surroundings. The Revenant was filmed in Canada and Argentina under arduous conditions by cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki, who used only natural light, capturing spectacular images of pristine wilderness.

The only bonus extra on the Blu-ray release is the making-of documentary, A World Unseen. A digital HD copy is included.

Lots of really great reviews on this movie and I don't understand why.  The plot was difficult to figure out,  it didn't hardly pull on any emotional cords, and it was unrealistic to imagine even the most hardened man to be able to survive the things he did and keep going day after day.  Anyone familiar with bear attacks,  deep woods survival,  falling in a frozen river,  knows you don't just get up from those things in half a day or two days and travel miles.  I regret that I purchased it and couldn't just rent it from Amazon instant.  The only reason I may ever see it again is to figure out why other people liked it so much.

An Indian attack, a grizzly bear attack. a meteor shower, a hillbilly attack, the evil hook nosed French, an avalanche, going over a waterfall, navigating rapids, riding your horse over a cliff, and all while oozing infected pus from your shredded body - and in the dead of winter! Guess hypothermia wasn't invented yet. This guy makes Superman look like Pee Wee Herman! The story is ridiculous, but well acted and visually satisfying. The antagonist is the bright spot. A hauntingly indelicate man with a great story about when his father found God. Leonardo Dicaprio is good, he is always good, he's an "A+" actor. Thus, 3 stars instead of 1.
in closing; I think it's time to put those old geezers who pick the Academy Awards, out to pasture. Politics (PC) should not trump art, in the movies. "The Revenant" is a powerful and honest testimony on what life was like in the American wilderness of the early 19th century, dealing not only with the Native tribes who were, understandably, not only trying to protect themselves and their way of life, but at times were at war with other tribes.
Leonardo DiCaprio has come light-years from the boyish charm he exhibited in "Titanic" or even the bright-eyed (and coked-up) hedge fund manager he portrayed in "The Wolf of Wall Street." Leo's Hugh Glass is the dictionary definition of a grizzled frontier guide. When he is mauled by a Grizzly bear and left for dead (not a spoiler as this is the frontispiece of the film's trailer) and left or dead by two of his party members who were supposed to be caring for him and tending his wounds, it begins the most epic journey of vengeance since Uma Thurman clawed her way out of a premature burial in the "Kill Bill" duology.
This film is very nearly perfect -- DiCaprio's performance doesn't outshine the film's antagonist, John Fitzgerald (Tom Hardy), nor that of the other characters, including Captain Andrew Henry (Domhnall Greeson), Bridger (Will Poulter) or the supporting cast. Perhaps this is due, at least in part, to the vast beauty and the sheer scale of the wild country in which it was set. The wilds of Alberta, standing in for the frontier
Ands that would become my adopted home of the Dakotas, are every bit as much one of the stars of this film as DiCaprio or Hardy. The snowcapped peaks and the roaring river, the vast dome of the sky studded with a million stars -- this film would have been utterly different without them. If I could, I'd give it SIX stars.

I truly became immersed in this movie. Knowing that it was all filmed on location and in natural light made it a cinematic masterpiece. Leonardo DiCaprio made this so visceral in that you felt all of that pain, etc. he was dealing with. He was truly devoted to this role and making it a one of a kind performance. Alejandro Inarritu is a cinematic genius and that's what made this film work so well. He knew what he wanted and settled for nothing less which turned into an Oscar for him (for the 2nd time) and Leonardo DiCaprio . I've seen it many times , and yes it is gory and bloody, but it is also very poetic. I know quite a few people didn't like it , as they expressed leaving the theater, However, I don't think they appreciated all of the beauty, cinematic effects,  great performances, and what these men had to endure to make this movie.

Currently don't own the movie for my own viewing yet, but saw it twice in theaters. One of my most anticipated movies of last year and one of my absolute favorites I've ever seen.

The cinematography and scenery were stunning. The attention to continuity was inadequate. The only reason I knew the film was not B & W was the copious amount of bright red blood in many many scenes. The plot line was seriously implausible. One example of numerous reality suspending scenes was the hero floating endlessly down a ice encrusted river - apparently hypothermia was not a known phenomenon. Nevertheless several characters were sympathetic and some were heroic.
This movie was a waste of time. Leonard DiCaprio did not deserve an oscar for this movie.

Excellent film, but it focuses too much violence. The cinematography is breathtaking... visuals, sound everything in that realm is perfect. I do feel strongly that there was way too much gore and that that element was overdone in several scenes- the same message and feelings could have been conveyed with a lot less blood and guts. This is especially true in the final scene where Hugh Glass(Leonardo di Caprio) finally achieves revenge for the death of his son Hawk(Forest Goodluck). How are these people  surviving after being stabbed & shot way too many times? In fact we are left wondering how Glass survives everything he does from being mauled by a grizzly bear defending her cubs to falling through rapids and off of cliffs. The only explanation other than artistic license & suspension of disbelief is that his will to survive is driven by his desire to seek revenge.

This is a story of great injustice on so many levels as well as of nature vs society, animals vs humans, native american vs europeans. It's a story of war of vengeance and of loss. In the last scene  Glass repeats a phrase Hikuc(Arthur Redcloud) a man who befriends and saves him on his journey back said: "vengeance is in the hands of the creator, not mine" He says this when his son's murderer John Fitzgerald(Tom Hardy) asks if he enjoyed his revenge since it won't bring his child back.  I have to agree that it won't bring his son back so I'm left wondering what was the real message of the film.

Does Glass absolve himself of the death of his son's murderer or does he realize it was all in vain and decide to let go? Glass says to captain Henry( Domhnall Gleeson): "Fitzgerald took my boy and that was all I had", this is our explanation for his driving force throughout the film. In the end Glass decides not to kill Fitzgerald with his own hands, he lets him float down the river to Elk Dog(Duane Howard) and his warriors who are seeking their own vengeance and who in turn let Glass live.

Things I would change about the film would be as stated above- less violence as well as more scenes of the past of Glass with his wife(Grace Dove) and family. I think when you overwhelm with excessive gore and brutality it takes away from the emotional content and from the character development.
I can only say I'm very glad I wasn't living in this period, it's such a horrible way to live and it's not something I would ever want to experience.

Revenant is a masterpiece.  But Black Robe is better.  I was enthralled by The Revenant from start to finish.  However, anyone who loves this movie would do well to go back and see Bruce Beresford's 1991 gem of a movie, Black Robe, about a Jesuit Missionary who travels through the austere Canadian wilderness, 1500 miles down the St Lawrence River to be exact, in the Company of a reluctant group of Algonquin.  The goal :  to make it alive to a French mission among the Huron in the depths of the wilderness.  A devastating chain of events, including attack by the Iroquois, ensues; Black Robe is, for my money, the best movie depiction of how the Native American way of life was altered forever by the various nations from Europe who settled the North American continent.  It is beautifully filmed, and with a great score.  Both movies are masterpieces; to me, Black Robe is better.
Absolutely incredible film.

Much ado about very little. Basically, the movie is about bad whites being killed off for their bad deeds. In a way, it's reverse racism as this movie tries to convey that only good white man is a dead white man. The ones who play even so called "good character" whites are killed off - every one of them. DiCaprio's character, being not totally white, is allowed to live but must suffer horrifically. The telling moment that basically summarizers the core message of the movie is when an Indian who befriends and saves Leo (who of course suffers a gruesome death at the hands of the whites) tells him that vengeance is not the purview of men but God (or something similar to that effect). Guess who kills off the baddest white dude (played by Hardy) at the end - the INDIANS - who therefore are acting as messengers of God. Hardy basically embodies all the bad characteristics of the whites (as envisioned by the director) - the most prominent being the ability to rationalize all acts of evil. Forget the obvious revenge story about a man seeking justice for the murder of his son, that's totally besides the point. The main point is this director, using his recent acclaim, and using the glorious canvass of the wild (it is gloriously filmed) to stick his middle finger at the white establishment. White Hollywood joyously took his finger and stuck it up their...kneeling before him and honoring him for making them look stupid. Hey, the actors are really good and the cinematography is great but the best part is how white Hollywood got hoodwinked into loving this revenge film without realizing the revenge is on them.

I would give The Revenant a solid 3.5 overall. It's an extremely good looking and well made movie. In my personal opinion, I think Tom Hardy stole the show. I'm by no means a fan of Leo but I don't have a problem with him either. I think he's okay in most movies, and in this, he is also just okay. Tom Hardy is almost unrecognizable. Leo is, well, just Leo. He is far from compelling. There was a lot of hype for his performance but honestly there's not much to go crazy for, aside from like I said, Tom Hardy.

Moving on I felt no attachment whatsoever to the story. You could tell they wanted to throw in all these subplots to spice things up but there's not much of interest going on and therefore nothing to get invested in. Characters come and go, events take place but there's nothing to really take away from these scenes that are supposed to be intense but ultimately lack depth and purpose. All of these subplots feel like padding so we aren't just watching Leo do his thing for 2 and half hours. But Leo fighting for survival is the only thing that could absolutely be paid interest because it appeals to the survival instinct of human nature. Aside from that, there's nothing. The time period is interesting and the fact that these men are fighting for survival and their way of life, but the actual drama going on with Leo's character and the emotional connection we are supposed to feel is just not there for me. Emotionally it's trying but ends up feeling empty. So to sum it up, there's stellar direction, cinematography, and some solid acting here, but not much going on with the story. Certainly worth watching, but it's also very undeserving of the hype.

A beautiful and terrible movie.

I could almost leave it at that, but I suppose it does need more explanation.

First, though:
You know, I'm not going to complain about DiCaprio getting best actor for this. I think a role like this is probably pretty tough. And I don't just mean the rigorous conditions. I mean the not being able to use your voice. There's not a lot of talking in this one. DiCaprio did a more than adequate job of carrying the movie with his facial expressions and stumbling around, much better than Redmayne did last year, at any rate. However, I think Bale would have been the better choice for The Big Short. If he'd been nominated for best actor, that is. What's up with that?

And I don't particularly like Christian Bale.

The movie is beautiful. Even in its terror, it's beautiful. The cinematography is, in a word, amazing.

But, beyond that, the movie doesn't offer much. In that way, you can take "terrible" to mean whatever you want it to. What I can say is that, at the end of the movie, I wasn't left feeling anything. Maybe that's the way Inarritu intended it, but I don't want to watch a movie and then feel nothing. My actual thought when the screen went from DiCaprio's face to the credits was, "Oh... That's it?" There was no joy, no sadness, no nothing. No catharsis. There wasn't even anything to think about as there was at the end of Birdman. It was just over.

Now, this next thing is my own bias:
People talk about this movie as if it is just a revenge tale, but that's not true. It's not even mostly true. Mostly, it's a survival tale. I tend to not like fictional survival tales. They're just... too outrageous. Once you've decided your hero is going to survive, you can do anything you want to the character and, guess what, he survives! I have a hard time with Hugh Glass surviving the trials he went through. A real Hugh Glass, that is. Still, I was willing to go along with it for a while, even the trips in the freezing water, but [SPOILER ALERT!] going over the cliff on the horse was just too much for me. Okay, so was putting gun powder in his wound and igniting it. Clever but too much.

See, if you give me something like 127 Hours, I'm good. That really happened. The things Aron Ralston did to survive were amazing, but it's amazing because it's real. Nothing Hugh Glass did to survive or that he survived was amazing, because it was all a fiction. There's nothing triumphant and nothing to cheer. Then, there's the ending...

Also, there's Tom Hardy. I have nothing good to say about Hardy. Maybe if he takes a role that's more than guttural mumbling.
Perfect

Alejandro G. Irritu's film has Oscar nominations written all over it. The film begins with a bloody conflict between a group of fur trappers and a marauding bunch of native Indians; Emmanuel Lubezki's dazzling photography not only captures its bloodiness but sets it against the washed-out colors of a barren landscape, making us painfully aware of how the elements remain indifferent to human activity. The standards of cinematography are excellent throughout: Lubezki is particularly fond of the lengthy panning shot in which the human characters are depicted as mere specks on landscapes that almost seem to swallow them up.

And then there is the stellar central performance of Leonardo DiCaprio as Hugh Glass. He does not have many lines, but director Irritu concentrates on his sufferings as he quite literally rises from the dead on at least two occasions while trying his best to cope with the exigencies of a harsh winter. There are some memorable moments - for example, when Glass takes the guts out of a dead horse and crawls inside its corpse, thereby creating a cocoon to protect himself against the snow. In another sequence he manages to evade a posse of native Indians by concealing himself against a river bank, and then swimming out towards the rapids. Although buffeted by an apparently inexorable tide, he manages to cling on to some driftwood and thereby ensure his survival. We have to admire the actor's courage as he (or his stunt doubles) subject themselves to a series of almost unendurable tests of physical and mental courage. It is hardly surprising that DiCaprio won the Best Actor Oscar at the 2016 ceremonies.

But lush photography and stellar performances do not necessarily make a great movie. THE REVENANT is 156 minutes long; the plot unfolds at a leisurely (some might say almost a snail's) pace, with plenty of attention given to the central conflict between Glass and his arch-rival Fitzgerald (Tom Hardy). The first half of the movie offers a convincing depiction of the trappers' existence, and how they struggle to survive while trying to make a buck. Unfortunately the second half turns into a rather hackneyed revenge thriller set on an unforgiving landscape. One can't help but remember that classics such as George Stevens's SHANE (1953) told the same story in a much more economical (and dramatically effective) way.

In the end we are left with the feeling that, while THE REVENANT has a historically convincing story to tell, director Irritu somehow missed the opportunity to do so.

Was a total wast of two hours, no man can heal that fast ( broken ankle! ) nothing in this movie is close to real I guide for a living and caught every mistake the film maker had from the Moutain river ride scene where it ended in the planes with no mountains in the background, no one could survive that water for that amount of time you WILL drown. And that was just one of many throughout the film.

The first thing I took away from this film was how amazing Cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki used his "brushes" as a constant reminder that BEAUTY, often unobserved, is always the overseer of BRUTALITY. Secondly, this is this first film I have ever seen where CGI is an absolute neccesity. The bear attack, while not the most violent thing I've ever seen, is certainly the scariest thing I've ever seen. It's realism is sublime.

This is a movie where one can feel everything. The cold. The fire. The injuries. Pain. Loss. Death. Depth. A huge portion of that goes to both DiCaprio and Hardy, but Domhnall Gleeson and Will Poulter deserve a bit of credit as well. Casting was top notch here and everyone delivered/suffered to bring these characters to life.

I didn't know a story so exciting, could be a movie so boring.  And, I actually think director Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu is not very good. There, I said it.  So I don't know what all the hubub is about. Dicaprio has had several better performances than this. He was due an Oscar, so I guess they just gave him one real quick for this.  But the best thing about this movie is Tom Hardy's performance.

I am a sucker for any movie that sets its local above 8,000 feet because I have always gone to the mountains to get
their "good tidings," as did John Muir.  For those who thought the film was too slow or too long, well that is what life
always is ... moments of frenzy followed by long periods of boredom. The Revenant captured that perfectly. For me,
it could have gone on for another two and a half hours. Too violent for you?  Life in those years and those places was
nothing if not all about survival. Even today, you can trek alone for a week across Alaska or even Yellowstone to get a sense of
what the wilderness is about.  Leo did it without GoreTex... as did all those mountain men 150 years ago. I cannot
imagine how any movie could do a better job of capturing that feeling of life in the mountains a couple centuries ago.
If you did not appreciate what the director, Lubezki, gave to you, go see a movie with car chases, zombies, outer space, etc.
And if you liked this masterpiece, you gotta' love the Hateful Eight ... another historical period piece with tons of
violence ( but only movie effects, folks ) and a spectacular cast and story.
  One more for you, if you missed it ... Jeremiah Johnson, with Bob Redford. Really special.

This Is A Good Movie Without A Doubt , But One Of The Greatest Wilderness Movie I've Ever Seen And Will Always Be The Best Is " Death Hunt " . Charles Bronson , Lee Marvin , Carl Weathers , Angie Dickinson , And Other Great Actors Made This A All Time Classic That's Not To Be Looked Upon As A Mere Movie Of Chance . If You See This Classic You Will Agree Hands Down , And The Revenant Will Be Look At Much Differently . Come On True Movie Critics ! ! !

DiCaprio plays Hugh Glass, with a deep determination and a whirlwind command.
The Oscar winning team behind Birdman (Chivo & Iarritu) frame The Revenant in a very traditional approach of filmmaking. At times it feels like Platoon, and other times it evokes the great David Lean. From the Indian attack to the bear mauling, Tension keeps building up until the very end, when Glass and Fitzgerald hack each other to pieces in the best directed sequence in Iarritu's career, evoking Robert Altman's McCabe & Mrs Miller and The Shinning. The score becomes as important as the photography at times.
DiCaprio delivers a deeply believable  performance of fatigue and heartbreak, while Tom Hardy creates a wholly original villain, whose worst enemy is his fright. The Closing sequence of this film is nothing short of miraculous.
Saw it in the theatre and had to buy the movie for my personal library.

Great story and beautiful scenery. Other than that this movie is 10 minutes of action and over two hours of grunting and crawling on the ground. I was so happy when this ended so I could get the hell out of the theater.

Oscar winner for best actor (Leonardo DiCaprio), best director (Alejandro G. Iñárritu, and best cinematography (Emmanual Lubezki), THE REVENANT is an epic production and in truth Nature is the leading character. The film is a visual spectacle, the themes of survival and for love between a father and son are moving, but this is a long song and requires endurance on the part of the viewer for sitting through 156 minutes of repetitious gore and raw natural elements. The film is based in part on a novel by Michael Punke, and the screenplay is by Mark L Smith and Alejandro G. Iñárritu.

The film may be excessively long but the story can be quickly summarized: While exploring the uncharted wilderness in 1823, legendary frontiersman Hugh Glass (Leonardo DiCaprio) sustains injuries from a brutal bear attack. When his hunting team leaves him for dead, Glass must utilize his survival skills to find a way back home to his beloved family (his son Hawk - Forrest Goodluck  dies on the same trip). Grief-stricken and fueled by vengeance, Glass treks through the wintry terrain to track down John Fitzgerald (Tom Hardy), the former confidant who betrayed and abandoned him.

The hunting troops are well portrayed by Tom Hardy (very difficult to understand his mumbling accent), Domhnall Gleeson. Will Pouster (a very talented young actor), Forrest Goodluck et al. But the overwhelming power of the film is the depiction of man in Nature and the concept of survival against all odds. For that aspect alone the film is well worth seeing. Grady Harp, March 16
By far the best movie of the year... the bear seen was amazing and the movie was unforgettable! The picture is beautiful, from beginning to end!
Pulls you in and keeps you there. A gift to those who appreciate a slice of history. Very authentic to period also. Even in behavior. Top notch acting and directing.

Nine Things About the Film "The Revenant"

1. In case your vocabulary is rusty, a "revenant" is a person who leaves for a long time, and then comes back. They may even come back from the dead.

2. This is a fictional story, but was inspired by a real man. The movie is about Hugh Glass, a tracker for a group of trappers and hunters in the 1800s. They get attacked by members of the Arikara Native American tribe, who are looking for the people that kidnapped one of their girls.

3. Shortly after that, the movie splits up into four different stories, which weave in and out of each other. The main pivot for these splits is a guy named John Fitzgerald, who is the very definition of "every man for himself."

4. It was directed by Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu. This is his sixth film. He's known for his "Death Trilogy" as well as 2014's Birdman. I've seen all of his films, and he's one of my favorite directors, because he has the rare talent to find beauty in the horror of life, and to find horror in the beauty of life. This movie illustrates that talent perfectly.

5. Leonardo diCaprio gives his most intense performance ever in this movie. It's even more impressive because he hardly ever talks. And Tom Hardy is one of the most versatile actors around (he was Mad Max, he was Bane. He was riveting in Locke, which was just him driving in a car for two hours. And here's a fun fact - Hardy and diCaprio first acted together in Inception). The two men serve as dual tentpoles around which the rest of this movie hangs.

6. The movie will become famous for it's bear attack scene. That scene required months of rehearsal, and Irritu watched footage from about 100 bear attacks in order to make it as realistic as possible.

7. Emmanuel Lubezki is the cinematographer here, and his work on this film is astonishing. The shots are lush and haunting. He's filmed Terrence Malik's last three movies (and his upcoming two), and some of Alfonso Cuarn's, such as Gravity.

8. The movie is respectful of Native Americans without making them look like the sanitized and helpless stereotypes that are commonly seen. Everybody contributed to the tensions of the time, and took resources wherever they could be found.

9. Despite some crazy action sequences, this is not an action movie. It's a three-hour exploration of human endurance and revenge. Some people will be captivated by this movie; others will find it to be too long and depressing. In either case, on a technical level this is a masterwork of film-making.

Adapting the mostly true experiences of fur trapper Hugh Glass that took place in Montana and South Dakota in 1823, "The Revenant" is an amazing existential tale of survival and revenge that'll leave you feeling gutted and skinned, thanks to the remarkable vision and cinematic artistry of the great Alejandro G. Irritu, the director of last year's multi-Oscar-winning "Birdman", and who has just won his second Best Director Oscar for "The Revenant".  He was also the Mexican genius who gave us three narrative-juggling films of great humanism: "Amores Perros", "21 Grams" and "Babel", the latter I consider his masterpiece.

Forget the stories of its difficult production (being filmed in authentic remote and bitter cold locations), and how star Leonardo DiCaprio  actually suffered throughout by being immersed in freezing water, stuffed into a horse carcass or actually consuming a bison liver, what you'll bear witness to on the screen will pull you completely into its stark, ruthless, primal world and hold you there, thanks to DiCaprio's career-best performance as the film's protagonist which justifiably earned him his first Best Actor Oscar. The film is long (arguably too long) and unrelentingly slow, but few viewers will find themselves bored due to its calculated hypnotic pull, completely enwrapping viewers in its frozen world almost as much as Lean's "Lawrence of Arabia" put us in the desert.  Above all, it has two sequences that will stay with you forever: the grizzly bear attack which occurs, as do many sequences, in one seemingly single long take -- but I found even more effective the first Indian assault.  That scene delivers such brutal realism I actually felt terrified as never before in a movie theater due to the scene's directorial staging of the trappers' panicking while the Indians' arrows frenetically strike the men's flesh with the force of stinging missiles.  This scene makes every other Indian attack I've ever seen in a film postured and artificial.

Irritu is a Mexican genius, born in 1963, who managed to build up an extensive amount of cultural experiences through early travels, beginning at age 17 by crossing the Atlantic on a cargo ship then working his way across Europe and Africa. After his journeys, he returned to Mexico City, majored in communication, then began a career as a radio station host interviewing rock stars and hosting live concerts while single-handedly building WFM into the number one station in Mexico.  All these experiences apparently became the source of his eclectic filmography, beginning with writing and directing a famous Mexican TV pilot, "Behind the Money", and making a few short films before beginning his feature career with "Amores Perros" in 2000.  His best work conveys a cinematic exuberance close to a Mahler symphony in its scope, forming a synthesis of despair and joyfulness in rendering the human experience.  "The Revenant" finds him at his most obsessive and committed during its long shoot in a way reminiscent of the epics of David Lean: an 80-day principal photographic schedule in the coldest weather at locations so remote it required more than nine months in unbearably torturous conditions, all due to Irritu's refusal to use computer-generated imagery (saving the few effects scenes that necessitated it).  The director's monomania for realism became so intolerable that many crew members walked off the project (or were fired), and Tom Hardy wound up attacking the director, nearly strangling him.  The efforts of Irritu (and his collaborators) can be seen in the final production.

Cinematographer Emmaunuel Lubezki (whose nickname is 'Chivo' which means 'goat' in Spanish) has an affinity with this director (he won an Oscar for Irritu's "Birdman" before winning one for "The Revenant"). After tests on 35mm and 65mm film stock, Lubezki and director Irritu decided to shoot "The Revenant" on 6K high-resolution digital to be able to schedule one more hour of shooting time per day, almost exclusively in natural light for authenticity.  And since lensing Alfonso Cuarn's "Children of Men", Chivo has been justifiably famous for long unbroken takes (in fact, most of "Birdman" is constructed as if its entire drama is uninterrupted by a cut), and he continues that tradition, if in a less obvious fashion, with "The Revenant" in its Indian assault and grizzly bear attack..

Though the film ultimately does not attain formal perfection, I left the theater carrying a new life experience unlike anything I'd seen before, achieved through Irritu's singular vision conveying a quintessential portrait of the American wilderness with great cinematic poetry.  One of the year's most significant achievements in film.

Hmm,breathtaking visuals,truly authentic performances by the greatest actors of their(my)generation..for what?The movie itself was a bummer,I read the book and I loved it,Michael Punke's prose was so easy to follow,his imagery so vivid and characters so three dimensional and real in my mind's eye I almost salivated,expecting faithful rendering of my favorite read..after all,so much was said about the literal crucible of making the movie as realistic as possible-torturing the extras,globetrotting in search of the perfect locations(Chile,apparently),freezing most of the cast in rivers etc....and then slapping that hideous CGI bear right in the middle of it! I know ,people will always say, never work with kids and animals,plus Leo is big time treehugger and PETA  says that using animated animals is better for the real beasts of cinematic burden...It sounded flat -the movie lost its magic to me,the herd of CGI bisons hunted down by CGI wolves didn't help either;I know those are just cosmetic grievances most people can live with ,but the story itself was completely  butchered,the murdered son the kidnapped girl  and all that magical realism-none of that needed to be in the movie,Glasses story as quirky as it was didn't needed all that to be compelling and entertaining.

Inarrittau has directing a film so brilliant and striking that he now belongs in the esteemed company of great filmmakers like Welles, Hitchcock, Kubrick, Spielberg, Malick and Scorsese. Hands down, best movie of the year

Normally when stories of production woes emerge it spells inevitable doom, but twice in 2015 we've seen two of the year's best films emerge unscathed, if not better for having struggled to completion. One was George Miller's Mad Max: Fury Road; the other is Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's unforgiving, poetic tale of reflection and icy revenge, The Revenant. As a follow-up to his upbeat and brisk Oscar-winner, Birdman, Inarritu couldn't have gone in a more stark direction. As wondrous to behold as it is punishing to endure, The Revenant is Inarritu staking his claim to the most unique movie of the year. Nothing else looks quite like it; no other film puts you through the emotional wringer quite like it, either.

Maybe it's the merciless weather Leonardo DiCaprio, Tom Hardy, and much of the crew were put through, but everything about this film is brutal. The only thing more chilling than the raging blizzard are the chilling acts of barbarism in a world without mercy; where surviving is the only thing that can and ever will matter. DiCaprio, looking shaggier than ever in his career, plays Hugh Glass, a tracker and frontiersman in 1820 Wyoming, working for a fur company in the snowy Rocky Mountains. When a Native American tribe attacks, it's every man for himself...as long as he doesn't forget his bale of bear pelts. In fact, pelts are the only thing that seem to matter to the cruel John Fitzgerald (Tom Hardy), a nasty, racist piece of work who has a special dislike for Glass and his half-Pawnee son, Hawk (Forrest Goodluck). The crew barely survives the attack, which is captured in fluid chaos by DP Emmanuel Lubezki (winner of two Oscars for Gravity and Birdman), and it's up to Glass to navigate everyone home.

Cruelty on top of cruelty is heaped upon Glass, but it all begins when he's viciously mauled by a raging bear. The attack itself might be one of the grizzliest scenes captured on film. But for all of its ferocity, there's something beautiful about it, as well. The technical wizardry of it, as DiCaprio is literally battered from tree to tree, pummeled, bitten, and clawed, is remarkable. You'll spend the rest of the film wondering how they pulled it off. With Glass near death, the scrupulous captain (Domhnall Gleeson, who is in everything this season) figures they can't outrun the pursuing Natives and carry him along. So he offers up a ton of money to anyone that will stay behind with him until they can return with reinforcement. The opportunistic Fitzgerald agrees, along with Hawk and the innocent youngster, Jim Bridger (Will Poulter). But it isn't long after they are left alone that Fitzgerald commits a heartless act, captured right in front of the immobile Glass, which demands vengeance.

And vengeance is what he seeks; it boils in Glass's savage blood. This is a DiCaprio we've never seen before, feral and unwavering, agony and fury captured in his burning eyes. The level of commitment he brings to the role is extraordinary, but the same goes for Hardy who at this point can mumble villainy with the best of them. Both actors look like they have an extra layer of bark on their rugged skin. Not everyone could have endured the rigors Innaritu put them all through, shooting only a few hours a day to capture the most natural light he possibly could. Much of the crew quit; the delays stretched into weeks and months, but the results made it all worth it.

Admittedly, The Revenant sticks to such a grim note throughout that it may be tough for some to handle. It's an endurance test, for sure, but the darkness is broken up by Malick-ian dream sequences capturing the expansive vistas in which Glass makes his painful journey. These scenes are what drives him further than any man should be capable to go; to survive wounds that would fell a regular man, to move on despite starvation and freezing temperatures. They're key to the story even if they feel somewhat separated from the narrative.  DiCaprio gives this film its beating heart, while a surprisingly good Poulter provides the slim strand of goodness coursing through it.

The film ends exactly as it should, with the promise of more violence. The Revenant gives no quarter; it's a challenging, brilliant film that proves once again that Inarritu is unparalleled when at the top of his game, and fortunately for us he always is.
Agree with the review by Historynut.

This film was a disappointment for me because of the numerous historical inaccuracies, the old well worn formula of a person wronged seeking revenge, the lack of era definition and an almost complete absence of character development. Way too much time focusing on endless vistas which I can see for free either on PBS or not far from my burg. The stereotypes are all there geared for the masses including wise, mysterious indians, stupid bumbling trappers, hand and long muskets fired like semi-automatics, and the seemingly irresistible inclination by producers and directors today to inaccurately infuse 21st century dialogue and occasional perspectives either because they think the audience is too stupid to catch on or they themselves are too ignorant to understand the period piece they are dealing with. The bear attack scene was the highlight and reasonably well done but not perfect.

If one pushes all these complaints off the table and simply wants pure fantasy entertainment and don't mind that they're really paying for the boisterous soundtrack, special effects and visual violence then I gave it two stars to account for that. DiCaprio does a decent acting job as he usually does depicting the sheer intensity of his character's circumstances even though some of the character's actions are incomprehensible. The supporting cast ranges from lame to acceptable. If you want to see an improvement on this subject then the '71 film "Man in the Wilderness" does a much better job as does a close-to-topic mountain man film like "Jeremiah Johnson". Both do not have today's special effects nor are they completely historically accurate either but at least they have character development and a human interest story.

The best thing I can say about the film is that it has beautiful cinematography.

The rest was one hard to watch movie. Also, I felt they could have at least shaved 30-50 minutes off it off and not much would have been missing.

I should have checked up more on what I was going to watch, because man is this ever a gore-fest! Brutal, bloody, violent, heartbreaking and gory. There is a rape scene also. If those things don't bother you, then you'll be fine (but really? they don't??) But if you're like me-a deeply sensitive person-this will bother you.

The revenant the title refers to is a pelt hunter named Glass, the storys most important and most annoying character. After being attacked and almost killed by a bear, an early peak as far as memorable scenes go, hes left injured for most of the movie. His constant grunting and sighing is what irks to the point of nearly ruining an otherwise thrilling adventure.

The cinematography and choreography of the first ten minutes or so, the Indian ambush, are particularly engaging. There are underlying themes of love and war; nostalgic endearment and bitter revenge are more like it; but The Revenant is mainly a tale of survival as protagonist Hugh Glass, left for dead in the cold and snowy wilderness, fights to survive.

I can't even put into words how incredible this movie really is. Leonardo DiCaprio aboslutely nails it this time. He put up with so much trial throughout this movie, trying to survive after being mauled by a bear. I felt I was watching a real person and not an actor. It's one of the best performances of all time. The music is very simple, but nails the mood of the film, similar to Jaws' simple music. I could go on and on praising this film, but I'm just here to say you NEED to see it for yourself. It's one of the best films of the last thirty or so years.

I personally am not into slasher films because most are violence for the sake of violence.  I enjoyed this movie because the Cinematography is amazing and the story was good. I would describe this movie as a beautiful and violent.  Leonardo DiCaprio is awesome in the role and performs everything you see in the film.  He actually eats the liver and that is really him vomiting on film, the water scenes are also really him in that water.

My wife and I liked the movie,  one couple that are our friends felt it was long and boring and turned it off.  A second group of friends thought it was good but they didn't think it would be that violent.  So our friends have mixed reviews on this one.

The Good:
If you haven't heard by now, or if you've been living under a rock for the past decade, Leonardo DiCaprio is a phenomenal actor. His dedication to his roles can never be questioned seeing as though he actually did a lot of things to prepare for this film. (Click here to find out the crazy things he literally did.)  I also wouldn't be surprised if Tom Hardy didn't get some "Best Supporting Male Actor" nominations as well. He played a great antagonist to counter Leo.

Director Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu delivered captivating and suspenseful scenes throughout the film. Similar to how he did in Birdman, some of the most intense scenes were shot all in one entire take. Shooting in the natural elements really made the scenes appear that much more authentic. To top it all off, the action, hunting and gory survival sequences were intense to watch. (*Semi-Spoilerish* It even made some people walk out of some of the screenings.)

The Bad:
While the movie starts off with some really intense and suspenseful scenes, it slows down for quite a while afterwards. You almost feel like the movie is crawling at the same pace as Leo crawls along the ground. (It picks up during the end though)

So this can go either way, but this movie was pretty gory. I don't believe that it was senseless gore like in Hostel or Saw, for example. But I wouldn't be surprised if some people get turned off by it either.

The Reason:
Seriously, the Academy better give Leo an Oscar before he kills himself. If this performance doesn't earn him one, I don't know what else could possibly be done to get one. I don't think this is the type of film that everyone will flock to, but if you saw it, I don't think it would disappoint. Fans of Leo will definitely appreciate this film of "man vs nature" and revenge. I think this movie will make for a good matinee viewing on a weekend, or maybe even a decent watch at home.

The Rating: 8.5/10

For more reviews, visit EmansMovieReviews .com

The Premise:
Hugh Glass and his son, Hawk, are fur trappers in the wilderness of the unsettled Louisiana Purchase working for the Rocky Mountain Fur Company under the command of Captain Andrew Henry. The enterprize disintegrates when the group meets hostility and violence from the local Native Americans. Having to abandon their goods, the survivors begin a perilous trip back. While scouting ahead, Glass is savagely mauled by a bear and barely survives. His companions patch his wounds and try to travel with him but find it impossible. They leave Glass behind in the hands of his son and his fellow hunters Jim Bridger and John Fitzgerald, to heal or be buried when he dies.
Fitzgerald, a self-centered racist of a man, kills Hawk and tricks Bridger into abandoning Glass to die in a shallow grave. They then proceed back to the fort. Glass, however, is not dead and has vengeance in mind. What follows is a harrowing tale of survival and revenge across the American wilderness.

The Short of It:
This is an intense movie, done with an artistic style and a sense of poignancy. The plot is interesting and captivating with a satisfying conclusion, carried by excellent performances by everyone involved, but none more so than Leonardo DiCaprio as Hugh Glass. It is not fun, and it is not packed with action. If you go into the film expecting that, then you might very well be bored. However, if you go in on the films terms and can handle violent imagery, it is highly entertaining. I recommend it.
