Not really my cup of tea... The plot was good an interesting, but the movie was just too long for that plot. They had several scenes where you can tell that DiCaprio was only interested in trying to get an award. In those scenes he was trying so hard that it made the acting look fake.
Interesting film non the less.

Saw it in a theater. After reading the promos and the critics, I expected a really exciting film and ended very disappointed. The story is so simple-minded that it fails to be a movie plot. Glass, hired as a guide for a fur-trappers' trek on the American-French Canadian border, clashes with Fitzgerald, a low-life trapper who has better ideas about the route, about avoiding the scalping Indians, about getting paid, etc, etc. You add to it Glass's half-caste son (hated by Fitzgerald) and his dead Indian wife (killed by a French soldier, but communicating regularly with Glass in his dreams and hallucinations), and you get the standard Holywood prescription of a drama for the masses. When Glass meets a grizzly and seems to be dying from the terrible wounds, Fitzgerald volunteers to stay with him until he either dies or help comes. Fitzgerald then kills Glass's son, buries Glass alive and goes back to the frontier town fort to get his reward. But Glass refuses to die. Fortified by his rage and thirst for revenge, he faces all the terrible dangers and trials that nature and man can throw his way. Eventually, he gets back to square the account with Fitzgerald in a High Noon fashion. On the cons side - the movie is too long, to slow, too melodramatic. In a word, it is darn boring and primitive in its script and direction. DiCaprio, a really great actor, is reduced to playing a role of a groaning and crawling coach. He does his coaching well, but it's very tedious nevertheless. The music is bad, too. On the pros side - some beatiful shots of a winter country in the north and a great sequence of the grizzly mauling DiCaprio. If you leave immediately after, you'll save yourself a couple of hours of boredom.

I must say that this is a really terrific film! The directing, the acting, the photography are quite impressive and there are many downbeat thrills and wondrous moments. The scene of the bear attack is quite astonishing, a sequence of vicious, haunting beauty, one of the most shockingly realistic scenes I have ever seen on screen! It's a story of greed, crime, violence, survival after an endless string of gruesome trials, and horrible revenge, full of suspense and with powerful emotions, but I think the real protagonist is Nature itself - beautiful snowy landscapes, virgin forests, icy cold rivers, snowstorms, days and nights, wild life in every form and in every size, from ants to horses. Indians are both evil and merciful at different times, and survival on the mountains in the coldest of the winter is pictured in fascinating detail. In my opinion Alejandro Inarritu clearly deserves to win a second Director's Academy Award in a row for this magnificent achievement.

{4.5 stars} First off, THE REVENANT is, of course, a remake of 1972's Man in the Wilderness, so if you consider remakes bad by nature, you probably don't want to see this. Ive also noticed some complaints about its length (2.5 hours), and while it has its share of unexpected twists, if you want non-stop action with constant thrills and spills, you'll probably find it too draggy. Finally, while it's "based on" a true story, it does depart a great deal from historical fact and should be taken as fiction rather than docudrama. All that being said, I was utterly entranced for the entire length of this long, sad, and starkly beautiful film and didn't want it to end. The action sequencesbear attack, attacks by hostile Indians, struggles with other natural elements, etctruly take the audience Right There with their ultra-realistic cinematography, costume design, and sound effects. Very good, often splendid acting by just about everyone, with special kudos going to Will Poulter as young Jim Bridger, and, of course, DiCaprio as protagonist Hugh Glass. Tom Hardy is also great as antagonist John Fitzgerald, a character who, no matter how much the bad guy he is, is still given a sprinkling of sympathetic qualities. The way that Glass and Fitzgerald resemble each other in both appearance and certain mannerisms is another interesting effect. The main reason why I cant quite give it five full shiners is that its plot follows the same basic pattern of so many other western vengeance dramas, particularly in its rather predictable ending. Still, the unique details and twists keep this from really hurting the film. The sheer number of supporting characters makes it hard to place whos who; nevertheless, this was obviously hard to avoid and also leaves room for multiple viewingsIm sure many will be as eager as I am to watch it again. Finally, some of the script/dialogue is rather flat and does not convincingly evoke the 1820s; e.g., Yep, the Indians are always stealing our s__t! Some other notable things about THE REVENANT: --Wonderful use of parallels in details such as the bear cubs left motherless, the lone buffalo abandoned by the herd as its devoured by stalking wolves, and the old Indian left behind in the abandoned village. --Amazing visuals of the Rocky Mountain setting and Glasss dream sequences. --The fact that THE REVENANT is based upon a true story (taking many liberties, of course) and that most of its primary characters were actual people leaves room to read-up and dig a little deeper.

I loved the cinematography in this movie. Beautiful yet dangerous country. Leo actually says very little but his story was still so interesting to watch. Tom Hardy was outstanding as the bad guy. I loved hating him. Every character felt true to form.
I only wish the director had delved into Glass's previous life just a bit more so you could feel the attachment he had for his son and loss of his wife. Also, a loose timeline (or a passing reference to time) would have been helpful. When he finally gets back to civilization, was he gone for
several weeks? Several months? We don't know.
As another reviewer said, don't be late when the movie starts and be ready to stay til the end. It is fast paced and the fight scenes are fairly realistic. The camera makes sure you are right in the scene with the actors.
I can't wait for this movie to come out on DVD. Once again, DiCaprio proves he is a great all around actor - Academy award or not.
what abot tom hardy. this is by far his best movies other than mad max. great wester
Definitely one of Leo's best performances.

Saw this movie twice and liked it much better the second viewing. The bear scene is probably one of the coolest and most lifelike animal attack ever seen on film and for that it is a huge achievement. It really is more like a virtual reality bear attack experience than it is a scene in a movie and I couldn't wait to see it again. The first time I saw this I just really couldn't get over the seeming absurdity of Glass's survival in scene after scene of his death-defying experiences. I think the point was that as long as you are breathing, you will fight to stay alive no matter how dire the circumstances. However, there are some forces that no strong will to survive can topple. Hypothermia being one. How did he not freeze to death?? He is in the river in freezing temperatures and emerges soaking wet from water. How does he dry off in time or stay warm enough not to have his body temperature plunge from the ice and snow? A wet bearskin coat is not going to protect him. These small details bugged me the first time I saw it. The second time, I just accepted that he was stronger than the elements.  Another problem I had was how quickly his wounds healed. Why? One day he is lying in a ditch unable to move at all, and the next he is swimming like Michael Phelps in a raging river. And how is it that none of those nearly fatal wounds gets infected or seem to cause him much distress as he is climbing on horses and doing all kinds of stunts while fighting off Indians?  You really, really need to suspend your disbelief for a lot of it. As for the creepy voices that are continually haunting him (his wife?), I found these extremely odd and annoying. Why did she sound like the ghost from the Grudge? And why do they always portray Native Americans as having deeper wisdom than everybody else? It felt extremely forced and stereotypical that whenever the wind blows he hears her talking about strong roots etc. etc. Tom Hardy was a super bad guy, Leo was the hero you rooted for but overall I wanted something more emotional or heartwrenching. All in all, this felt like Dances with Wolves Part 2, minus the love story.

It's just a rehash of "Man in the Wilderness", starring Richard Harris and John Huston, filmed in 1971. I respect DiCaprio's talent, but Hollywood is pumping a dry well. I liked Sarafian's film much better.

I bet people would really like this film if it was 100% violent instead of 90% violent that it is. This country is the most violent in the world and so used to it and part of it's make-up, the people don't see a word of truth in that statement.

PLOT...
Inspired by true events, THE REVENANT captures one man's epic adventure of survival and the extraordinary power of the human spirit. In an expedition of the uncharted American wilderness, legendary explorer Hugh Glass (Leonardo DiCaprio) is brutally attacked by a bear and left for dead by members of his own hunting team. In a quest to survive, Glass endures unimaginable grief as well as the betrayal of his confidant John Fitzgerald (Tom Hardy). Guided by sheer will and the love of his family, Glass must navigate a vicious winter in a relentless pursuit to live and find redemption.

The Revenant is nothing less than a masterpiece, a hell of a way to start the new year, this is an emotional suspenseful thrill ride from beginning to end unlike any film we have had in a while, the story is great, everything looks authentic for the time its set, the costumes and locations are good, the music is great, the cast is stunning, im not the biggest Leonardo DiCaprio fan but the guy deserves an award for this movie, Tom Hardy as always shines too, two fantastic actors at the peak of their abilities once again, the movies support cast is good too, Domhnall Gleeson also stars, last seen in Star Wars The Force Awakens, for a 2 and a half hour film its paced out so well and keeps you drawn in the whole time, the movie is very violent and quite graphic at times, the infamous bear attack scene is very well done, long and very cringe worthy! This comes highly recommended to almost anyone really who loves watching something that's big on suspense and hugely dramatic, a very well crafted story of survival and revenge, this is one movie you can really dig your teeth into the realism, plus the fact its based on true events makes it even better.

Running time 2hr-36mins, made 2015.
I think it could be a good movie if it was 1 1/2 hours long. 2 1/2 hours I lost focus to much dead time.
Amazing film that will stay with your forever.  So much to love here:  the story, the acting, the cinematography, the soundtrack, everything works in this film.  Only a fool would skip this!
Really good movie! That bear attack though....omg
Amazing

This tedious movie is a humorless, monotonous, pretentious music video that occasionally feels like a Leonardo DiCaprio showreel. It is distractingly directed by the gimmicky showman Inarritu, whose Birdman is possibly the least dramatically interesting movie ever to win an Oscar.

And while a movie does not need to have have likable characters, it should at least have interesting characters, and The Revenant has neither. DiCaprio certainly looks uncomfortable in the snow, but since there is nothing to his character but his affection for the young native--a relationship that does not last very long--most of the movie has a zero dimensional character struggling with the elements with elaborate, gimmicky, cg-enhanced set pieces. Despite being played by a talented actor, the lead is completely uninteresting and his quest for revenge dull.

This is the worst movie I've seen in the theater since the similarly humorless, monotonous, and self-important movie, Precious. The politics are very patronizing and simple minded and lacking any depth other than the typical "we are all to blame" rehash that so many guilty and self loathing people love, as exemplified by the "you are to blame!" and truly laughable final shot.

A feature length music video full of cg tricks, but wholly lacking in characters, drama, humor, heart, and depth. Self-congratulatory, egotistic garbage masquerading as important art that will unfortunately fool a lot of people.
Never has a film devastated me like this one.
very intense movie....

Say hello to the biggest AAA budget stinker of the year. There is literally 5 minutes worth watching in the entire movie; the fight with the bear near the beginning. Rest, complete garbage. DiCaprio hasn't made a stinker like that since.. the beach?
Terrible boring movie, simply terrible.

Come on now - it's a good movie but not that good. If I was grading it on realism it would be 1 star. When a person gets wet in the winter in that country you are dead  in 15 minutes without a change of clothes and immediate fire / shelter. The bear scene was very well done and reasonably accurate if you've read stories by people who have been mauled. Two shots from a single shot pistol while riding a horse? Why is Hollywood rarely accurate in movies? It's an insult to us all.

When the credits rolled all of us in the theater couldn't believe the film was over. That is when you know you have seen a great film. Don't be late and don't be in the line to get popcorn when the film opens, and don't plan to take a restroom break once it starts. This movie rolls out like a freight train from scene one and doesn't slow down until the last scene fades to black.

The bear attack scene is better than you have heard. The fight scenes are intense and realistic and brutal. The portrayal of ruthlessness of the frontiersmen and the Native Americans is unparalleled in any film I have seen, here played out in graphic detail. Men are shown at their worst, and a few at their heroic best.

Once you see the film you won't be able to imagine anyone but Leonardo DiCaprio as the lead. Also of note is Domhnall Gleeson who is in Star Wars and Ex Machina, and quickly becoming one of my favorite actors. Of course Tom Hardy, who immortalized Bane in The Dark Knight Rises, once again plays the antagonist to a fault. Well worth seeing and well worth the accolades it has been receiving.

The Revenant exists only as Oscar-bait, and I have no doubt that DiCaprio deserves the award for such a brutal role in tough conditions. However, the rest of the film serves absolutely zero purpose, has no deeper meaning, barely any story beyond the struggle for survival, and almost collapses under the weight of its own self-importance. This is not the first time that the story of Hugh Glass has been brought to life, but its certainly the most alienating and depressing.

We've seen this struggle done before. Tom Hanks in Cast Away is a lasting example of an actor putting their body through hell and going full-on cave man. Cast Away also dealt with the themes of loneliness, sanity, and the need for direction. In the Revenant I knew almost nothing of the inner workings of Glass or Fitzgerald (a rather over-rated Tom Hardy performance). Glass seems to cope just fine with being alone (the pretentious hallucinations of his family only puzzled me), but I have a feeling that this was not the intention. As for direction (within the movie, I mean) it is noble that all of it was shot on location but there is no sense of space or place. We never know where any of these characters are in relation to each other. Every new location looks different from the last but we never have any orientation or a grasp of the greater landscape. All it would have taken is a five second shot of a map with any random character saying "here we are, and this is where we are going".

Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu's pompous style of long, long takes is completely inappropriate for this material and it took me out of the movie every time he tried to pull it off. I don't want to believe I am watching a documentary. I want to be excited and feel tension. The bear attack scene was brutal, but I would have felt more fear and anxiety had it actually be edited than done in one long shot. This kind of direction is not the antidote to Michael Bay's 1000 cuts in a minute nonsense. It was a mistake to shoot the film like this. Totally unnecessary.

As for the cinematography, a lot of people are praising it but it left me unimpressed. I admire the fact that they fought to shoot it all under natural light but almost every shot was wide and flat, wide and flat, wide and flat, wide and flat. Not once was I in awe of any spectacle or breathtaking natural beauty. Attenborough documentaries are shot better than this and spend less time indulgent cutaways. Perhaps the grain and texture of 35mm could have fixed this.

If you want a one man against nature story of survival then watch Cast Away. If a grisly tale of genocide against a new world backdrop is what you are after then Apocalypto is much better. The Revenant bored me and I walked out of the cinema immensely disappointed.

This movie is proof positive of how a skilled director can keep your mind 100% on his film. Now, I'm telling you, if you are searching for a heavy-duty plot line, you'd best pick up on a Spaghetti Western. This I would've loved to have done a book report on in 6th grade. Half a page, I could have wrapped this thing up.

Now, I know this movie will wind up with a zillion reviews, some of them exceedingly long, longer than the story, and that's fine. As for me, I come here for nuts and bolts and ZERO giveaways. HATE that! So, despite the petty haters slapping me with a "no help" review, I stick to my pelts, grizzlies and rifles.

Good movie. Very enjoyable. Has the potential for dragging in that some of the scenes are quite long with little action, but, that's where the incredible camera placements come in. WARNING: Not for the squeamish (of which I am one--hadda turn my head several times).

Multiple 100% fatal experiences prove to be as just annoying irritants for Di caprio and what MUST be his Kevlar epidermis.
Being attacked and mauled by a large Grizzly Bear seemingly requires only a 'bit of a camp'- before embarking on a 100 kilometer long journey in near freezing-point water- And in no ordinary river.
Di caprio variously floats past dangerous jagged rocks, viscous rapids, over Niagara falls and past the Sydney opera house. But at the end of his trip, a few hot breaths into the hands is all that required to revive a body core-temperature approaching a size 9 chook in the freezer section at Woolies.
Based on a true story- but only in as far as- there WAS a man, there ARE things called bears and there IS a river...the movie shortly then wanders totally into the minefield of plot device, fabrication and utter cow-plop.
Di caprio's part is that of a Glaswegian, Hugh Glass, a fur trapper mauled by a bear and thought to be dying. Two young men are left behind by the trapping party (one 18 and the other 20) to stay with Glass until he dies- and then to bury him.
However, after two days these men are frightened off by paroling Indians and so gradually make their way back to civilization. Glass does indeed then undertake the river journey, but on a makeshift raft.
He eventually recovers and later catches up with the two young men, but revenge is not undertaken and he even goes on further hunting trips with one of them.
But back to Di caprio's interpretation.
Utterly consumed by an incandescent desire for revenge on the two kids, for not taking on a platoon of Indians and having their scalps removed, or not humping his carcass over the Himalayas and back to some backwoods Barber/Surgeon- Di caprio pursues and then unleashes merciless Hell on these two poor buggers.
All I can say is, Hugh Glass is fortunate he didn't go hunting with a bunch of Australians.
They would have just worked out the logistics- and shot the turkey

As long as you can still grab a breath, you fight. Hugh Glass (DiCaprio) is leading a group of fur trappers through treacherous territory with the help of his son. While out scouting he comes across a pair of bear cubs, then the mother finds him. When he is found he is barely alive. Not wanting to leave him behind the group attempts to carry him to their destination but the mountains prove to be a obstacle. Two men agree to stay behind with him, but for different reasons. John Fitzgeralds (Hardy) greed gets the better of him and he kills Glasss son and leaves him for dead. Glass fights back and is now on a quest for revenge. There is only one thing to say about this movie. WOW. Intense, nerve wracking, infuriating, hopeful and inspiring all at the same time. DiCaprio is just incredible in this. He is captivating even though he doesnt speak for a lot of it. This is a movie I could just go on and on about but this is a film that just needs to be viewed and not talked about. The only real negative thing I can say about this is I don't think I could watch it again, it is just really too intense for repeated viewings. When you watch it yourself you will see what I mean. Overall, One of the best movies of the year along with possibly the best performance of DiCaprios career. He has come a long way since Titanic. I give this an A.
This is nothing but a blood bath!  Worst movie I've seen in years, don't waste your money!  Won awards because of Leo's name..what a waste!
This movie is a remake of " Man In the Wilderness " with Richard Harris and John Huston made in 1972 . BOO in hollywood

like most of hollywoods releases, this is just ok. could have been 1hr shorter lots of grunting is not acting , slow and boring thru most of it. don't understand the hype on this one. the bear stepping on his head is the best part

This is a remarkable and extraordinary film.  It raises the filmmaking art to a different level.  The direction, cinematography, editing, and sound are exceptional.  From the astonishing opening sequence and throughout Inarritu's direction is fluid, surprising and alternately grand and intimate.  Much has been made of the cinematography using only natural light, and rightly so.  It is stunningly beautiful, and the harsh majesty of the wintertime  Pacific Nothwest has never been captured like this.  The sound editing was completely immersive and had the sharp clarity and snap of frozen timber.  I didn't care that much for Birdman, although it too had some complex and mystifying sequences.  But what Innaritu has done here is an whole other experience.  Frankly, he and his crew deserve any and all accolades coming their way, even that bonfire of the vanities the Academy Awards. Yeah, he won the Oscar last year.  Tough.  Technically and artistically this film is peerless.

A simple story of survival and revenge told in straightforward terms with incredible attention to detail and authenticity, it is brutal and direct, just like life in the early 19th Century was brutal and direct.  Leonardo Dicaprio does a fine job, ably supported by an unrecognizable Tom Hardy, that brilliant chameleon who here has a different voice and a rural accent that feels exactly 1800's Americana.  Hardy goes so deep into character only Daniel Day Lewis could find him.

This movie won't be for everyone.  It is harsh and graphic and it is exactly what it purports to be: the story of a man mauled by a grizzly and left for dead who survives and makes his way back hundreds of miles to safety and to exact his revenge; and, how he does that and who and what he meets on the way.  Not a lot of story, transformed by the magic of Innaritu's camera moving from majestic long shots to closeups so intimately close they breathe on you.  It is grueling, agonizing and harrowing, and it takes its time.  Fine by me.

Interestingly, this story has been filmed before as Man in the Wilderness (1971), starring Richard Harris and John Huston.  That was a good film.  This one is sublime.

Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu must be the most visionary and unappreciated enough by American public filmmaker of the past decade.  From Babel (2005)--to Butiful (2009)--to Birdman (2014)-- to The Revenant (2015) he has created a masterpiece after masterpiece.  He is truly a filmmaker of the highest artistic quality.  If I had to summarize The Revenant in only few words, I would ask one to picture:The Last of The Mohicans (1992) or The New World (2005) set in snowy wilderness with heavy Terrence Malick's undertones.  The Revenant closely resembles the plot of The Man in the Wilderness (1971).

Of course note worthy are the performances of Leonardo Di Caprio as the protagonist Hugh Glass and Tom Hardy as the antagonist Fitzgerald.  The film is based on authentic historical persona a trapper and frontiersman Hugh Glass (1780-1833).

I must say De Caprio must have went through some physically grueling filming repertoire...just watching him constantly crawling in snow, covered with freezing soil, and nearly drowning in ice cold rocky river stream---can make one catch pneumonia. My favorite scenes include the opening battle scene between Indians and fur trappers, the bear attack scene, the horse chase scene with DiCaprio landing in a snow covered gorge where he uses his survival skill set to stay warm (horse enthusiasts will not be happy viewing the scene) and the final fight scene between the two main characters, which reminded me of Gangs of New York (2002).  Two other scenes from the film-- reminded me of Rambo: First Blood (1982), namely the one with Glass using gun powder to heal his cut and the fall from cliff on-to-a pine tree.  Glass himself as a survivalist stuck in the deadly wilderness and woods is reminiscent of the cult--film character --- John Rambo.

My wife and I just viewed this feature at the theater yesterday evening. I can tell many people are raving about this movie but all I can say is (for me) it was just ok. The movie was to long that it dragged and though his acting in the part is very good, this is not Dicaprio's best. Remember Arnie Grape ? In "What's Eating Gilbert Grape"? I've seen no one beat it. Not even Tom Hanks in "Forrest Gump" or Sean Penn in "I Am Sam" which was pretty close. Both Great Movies and performances. Oh Man! and I'm sorry but you would think the special effects would have gotten better by now. If you can't do CGI animals any better than that don't do it. It might as well be an animated cartoon!. Remember Bart the Bear attacking Harold Perrineau as Stephen in The Edge? Wow!! now that was fantastic. Oh! and as far as arrows and Indians? I've still not seen anything better than Dances with Wolves. Sorry folks! but for this Native American (Chickasaw Proud) the Flick just didn't cut it.

This movie is without a doubt, one of Leo's finest performances to date, and just as with Tom Hanks in Cast Away, he has very little dialogue to carry his role as frontiersman/mountain man Hugh Glass, who was an actual historical person in those days. But this role doesn't require tons of talking for him to be fully immerse himself in it, as it's essentially a survival story with strong elements of revenge where he simply has to survive in the barren, brutal wilderness of the American frontier until he can exact his revenge. It's a very physical role, which is perfectly suited for the time period and background depicted. It could have easily been titled Man vs Nature: The Movie! Of course Leonardo DiCaprio is not the only actor in this film worth noting, Tom Hardy as the main villain Fitzgerald is just as memorable, despite being in many ways the polar opposite of Glass. Will Poulter also puts in a fine performance as a younger frontiersman, or boy, if you prefer, who also suffers from Fitzgerald's wrath and malice. The film itself it very raw and grim, with hardly any sunlight or warmth to be found in the desolate mountain wilderness. Some people call it ugly and dreary, and they may have a point, but just as the people that inhabit this time period, it's all works very well together. What I didn't like was how easily Glass seemed to survive every life-threatening situation he was put through, after being mauled by a giant grizzly bear, exposed to the elements for days as he recovered from being mauled, and if that wasn't bad enough he then got caught in a freezing cold river, was thrown off a cliff at one point, which succeeded in killing his horse but somehow not him, and was stabbed and had his bones broken numerous times, yet still survived it all. I understand he was a frontiersman and had been exposed to the wilderness for years beforehand, but still, that borders on superhuman. All in all though, a dark but well told tale of vengeance and betrayal.
An excellent survival movie with breathtaking cinematography and good acting. I was disappointed by the CGI bear. The late Bart the Bear or Bart the Bear II (Little Bart) would have been better.

I've seen this movie twice
I'm not a fan of bloody violent movies but this one although it is one, and a very "raw" one feels different, perhaps because
every character has depth.

I can't change history and all it's cruel facts during it's time period (people being killed, Europe's insatiable demand for fur and all it's luxuries)  I know that the movie had to depict such cruelty and oh boy! did they do it, and how!

The movie doesn't feel like just some western revenge male movie, to me it felt very human, very real portraying
all the emotions a human being can feel; love, hope, jealousy, revenge, hate and compassion.

The cons I read is that the movie was too long, that's a matter of preference.
For me even the times Leonardo was alone were entertaining because there was so much going on around him, I feel if the movie had been shorter it would have been ruined completely. Why do people need action every minute?

--synchronicity--

After the movie I pondered on how "something" becomes what it is that makes people "feel" with so much force, how a painting makes people stare to it's beauty, how music makes us listen. It also makes me think about the "golden ratio", that perfect mathematical formula that all beautiful things have, then there's the math of music.

Well if it's difficult creating one perfect golden ratio painting, I can't imagine orchestrating (directing) a "moving" one! with music and actors; people so in tune with themselves and others that they create such amazing performances, while the exact music tone is playing at the right time, for the right amount of time, creating sounds that mix in with those of nature, while a camera appears to just be swirling around people.... wow.

For the 1-2 stars reviews, yes there are some parts that drag in the movie, but when you're confronted w/ surviving some horrible event, time seems to slow down, esp if ur waiting either to be rescued, or getting to a place for refuge. So, in those respects, I think the movie conveyed that part of surviving correctly.  Overall, I enjoyed the movie, Decaprio will definitely get the Oscar, even though he doesn't speak much. But I knew Tom Hardy wud be great as the bad guy, I hope someday he'll get an Oscar. Also,  I love that the director didn't glamorize the conditions of the severe cold environment  & not making ppl look like models, esp the Indians. Everyone looked like they were trying to survive, but back in those frontier days, when there's was no Costco or Walmt,  hunting for a living wasn't easy. Whaling, fishing, crabbing, fur trade - all hard work! It was based on a book, but Glass has NO kid, Hollywood spruced it up to promote more sentiment. And that it did, ppl can understand revenge for a murdered child.  Revenge for his own life wasn't enough drama.

This movie could have easily spared maybe 45 minutes and been vastly improved. As it stands, the film is generally great, though it suffers a bit from numerous slow and lethargic lulls.

The meditative tranquility in this film is beautiful. Shot in all natural light, the wintry outdoors has rarely looked so enchanting. A minimalist score and quieter tone all help to emphasize the loneliness of the heros journey through the harsh countryside. Yet oftentimes, the filmmakers become overindulgent in these shots, lingering far too long in an otherwise unimportant moment. The first few times are peaceful asides, but the lazy editing begins testing the viewers patience.

Understand that the plot is already as simple as can be, so to continuously tease the viewer away from the inevitable conclusion dilutes the characters power and motivation. Instead of focusing upon hard-charging revenge to drive the narratives emotion and action, the director has opted for the leisurely scenic route where vengeance waits to enjoy the view and watch snow melt.

Much has been made of lead Dicaprios acting. While it is certainly not bad, it is quite simple. The character mainly relies upon the same set of expressions of fear, suffering and rage, only growling a few lines of dialog throughout the film. Beyond one emotional scene, the actors repeated punishment in the frozen elements is more admirable than any bombastic display of theatrics. Far more impressive is Hardys rambling and shifty scoundrel. Once a few tin-earred logistical conversations pass in the beginning, the film settles into its groove of desperate men crossing a punishing wilderness.

The film ultimately misses the mark when trying to tread an odd line between quiet zen melancholy and fiery, bloodthirsty passion. The movie looks amazing with some nice flourishes of humanity and adventure, but the repeated losses of urgency and momentum from so many aimless asides diminish the storys overall power and heart.

NOT based on a true story!  I read the real story in the "Cowboys & Indians" magazine and most of the stuff in this movie did NOT happen.

SPOILER ALERT

1. This movie crawls, the bear attack (fake looking as Hell CGI bear. Where was Bart the Bear from all the other movies? A living bear?)  does not come till almost an hour into the movie. Fellow trappers Fitzgerald and Bridge were picked(paid) to stay with the injured Glass. If Glass had a half-breed Indian son, he was not with Glass when he was injured, therefore Fitzgerald could not have killed him which he does in the movie!

2. Glass vowed to get even with them both and hunt them down. First of all he went several hundred miles in the OPPOSITE direction to a fort where he knew he'd be healed, then went several hundred more miles to the fort where he knew Fitzgerald and Bridger were. This would take a lot of time and the seasons would change. This stupid movie takes place all in one winter.

3. When Glass finally found Fitzgerald and Bridger, he'd had a change of mind and spared them. It's not the stupid fight-to-the-death cliche snoozer fight like in the end of this movie.

To be honest, I just kept looking at my watch praying for it to just be OVER!!  I gave it 2 stars simply for the cinematography that started to repeat itself less than half way through the film. Save your money.  But it'll win Best Picture, you'll see!

The short version is, this movie tells an interesting (though historically inaccurate) story, but loses a lot in my eyes because of unrealistic details.

As most people will now know, this is based very loosely on the true story of Hugh Glass, who survived being attacked by a bear and being abandoned by his comrades. Those two points are about the limit of the similarity between the film and the real history.

It is a long movie, but I personally love long movies so that was fine with me.

I see the word "beautiful" pop up frequently in describing this movie. To my eye there was very little beauty... just one or two scenes where the sun came out, plus a few shots with large mountains in the background. For the most part this was the ugliest, dreariest looking movie I ever saw. Where there was bare ground it was mud; where there was snow the snow was dirty. Everywhere the ground looked filthy and worn, as if trampled by a herd of farm animals. I have not spent time in the region depicted by this movie, but in my experience the wilderness in general does not look this way.

Lots of other details in this movie seemed unrealistic to me as well, which was a distraction from enjoying the story of it. Some were minor, like a tree falling completely over after having its upper foliage burned off by a fire that lasted just a few minutes. Now why/how could that happen? Or the behavior of these experienced mountain men... they are constantly slogging through swamps and rivers, without making the slightest effort to keep their footwear or other clothing dry. I should think that in such long term exposure to cold, with no place to escape from it, keeping one's clothing dry would be of tremendous importance. Better to walk barefoot in the ice water but have your dry shoes to put on when you reach the other side. Granted, in one scene Glass has no choice but to plunge into an icy river to escape immediate death at the hands of hostile Indians. But he survives the episode far too easily. Even healthy, well-fed men will die of hypothermia after 20 or 30 minutes of such exposure, unless immediately given warmth and other care afterwards. Another thing that would have had real mountain men laughing themselves sick was how these people build fires. First they gather dry grass and other fast-burning tinder. Then they strike flint against steel to make sparks and create a flame. THEN they go off into the woods to look for sticks and logs to burn. Oh, then there is the unbound guy who not only stands still and knowingly lets an Indian cut off his testicles, but hardly lets out a peep during the process to boot. And the scene where Glass keeps warm by climbing inside the carcass of a horse that has already been dead for quite a while before he gutted it. I do not believe in any case that a gutted horse carcass is massive enough to retain useful heat for more than 2 or 3 hours under winter conditions... after that you end up not only cold but wet and disgusting as well. There was a clever twist near the end of the movie that initially caught me off guard. But really, it ain't going to work that way. It was a cute idea but ultimately only contributed further to the unrealistic "city boy's fantasy" aspect of the film.

As far as acting goes, Leonardo DiCaprio did not seem to be acting so much as just toughing things out. I guess that was all that was required. I did like Domhnall Gleeson's character, even if his behavior/judgement was incredibly bizarre. I thought Tom Hardy did an excellent job as the primary bad guy. His character had a logical selfishness that seemed quite realistic to me.
Very good movie.

I just saw this movie at the local theater.  After all the glowing reviews I had high hopes and was expecting a movie similar to Dances with Wolves or Last of the Mohicans - both of which I really enjoyed.  The bear attack which comes near the beginning of the movie was pretty exciting.  After that it got boring fast.  It was way too long and drawn out and was basically two and a half hours of hearing Leonardo DiCaprio groan and grunt.  I never thought it would end and by the time it did I didn't really care who survived.  I was just glad it was over.
Leonardo DiCaprio and Tom Hardy deserve the accolades they are receiving for this film. Go and see it! On Oscar night it will win several awards!

OMG is all i got to say !!!!!!  This was one of the most brutal movies i have ever seen !!!! The bear scene !!!!! HOLY HECK !!! Wont say no more for those who haven't seen but if you like fast paced , on edge of your seat throughout the whole movie, this is your movie to watch! Inspired by true events, my GOD that poor man!!!! Talk about a survivor !!!!!

Ok.  Leo is good in it and I'm glad he won an oscar but I think Tom Hardy stole the show.  I think Leo had better performances than this.  He weezed and screamed like he was going through puberty for 2 hours.  This film should of been cut at least by 40 minutes.  It was just too darn long!!!  I didn't need to see Leo looking at an avalance for 5 minutes or watch the trees bend for 10 minutes.  Then I heard that this is the director of that crap movie Birdman and it made sense so he got a pass...lol.  It takes too long to get to the end.  However, you do wake up and pay attention to the Tom Hardy parts in the film.  It had been reported that Hardy based his performance off of Tom Berenger's character in Platoon, so cool.  If you are going to give this movie a try, just note that it is an artsy fartsy movie that lingers on and on and on and on and on and on and on....lol.  At one point, I looked back at the audience in the theater and they were half asleep.  Other people are seeing the film in a different way and that's cool.  I don't need a film class lesson.  Just keep the story going.  But, this film is way better than that awful Spotlight!
Best movie of 2015, nuff said.
I'm glad that Leonardo's performance in this movie is spectacular.
This is one of the best movies Ive ever seen on the subject of human survival. Great Story, acting and ending. Oscar worthy in my book and Leos best work to date EASY! Highly recommended

Physical endurance test stars a wearied but clearly driven DiCaprio as he plays a bear trapper roaming the wilderness (just after the Louisiana Purchase) and manages to draw down on the wrong cub, with dire consequences. Eventually left for dead and colder than a democrat in the upcoming 2016 election, DiCaprio's Hugh Glass nears death and is aided by his son Hawk (an "adopted" child from a Native American woman, who Glass raised into adulthood himself) as he is abandoned by the crew of trappers and hunters who have vowed to give him a rightful death when the time comes. But when something nasty happens to Glass's son, the iceman ultimately vows to take revenge, no matter how many dead animal carcasses he has to sleep inside of to keep warm along his way back into town...
Simple and tiresome revenge tale is elevated somewhat by the beautiful, washed out (and chilling) period scenery (shot in 2.35:1 aspect ratio by the talented Emmanuel Lubezki) which no doubt takes us deep within the world that the Glass character inhabits...but this is all terribly overlong and probably not a solid choice for a film to begin with! I did not see the movie "Birdman" with Michael Keaton (a picture with an idiotic premise) but I can clearly see that director Inarritu has his eyes on the Oscar gold and little else. I'll bet that when Leo was sinking on Cameron's Titanic that he didn't envision himself chomping on the bloody ass of a freshly killed buffalo (with a hungry Indian who throws him a bone) all these years later (he does spit up a bit after eating the thing, but humans simply don't have the guts to handle eating raw meat with it being cooked...but I'll bet that a few people back in these days did just what we see here in this movie). To call the film ambitious is correct, but it is far too much of an endurance test to count for much (in my opinion). The problem with these "good" movies is that after they win the coveted golden statue the pictures themselves are often forgotten (I'll be watching and enjoying B-movies long after pictures such as this one have fallen into the wastebasket of the public's short memory), and as a result all of the charm, humor, and interesting side stories of these tales are pushed aside so that viewers can enjoy watching the star suffer. Because suffering is all that this movie is about. I suppose Leo enjoys being tortured like this (he is an actor, after all), but the movies have become all about torture and suffering in the hope that they are creating what they hope is "art"...but we all have to suffer when this kind of suffering takes precedence over everything else. And nobody knows about suffering more than today's movie reviewer. So while it is a pretty joyless and simple affair, it might be interesting to you if you like Westerns, but make no mistake in understanding that this movie will quickly be forgotten after the Oscar ceremony. D+
P. S. And know that the movie reviewer today must be discriminate. There are far too many offerings coming out today that are just waiting to burn holes in our sensitive little eyes, and I for one have difficulty taking it all in (and certainly in taking it all seriously). I refuse to see the new Tarantino movie because I think the man is a morally confused personality whose comments about our brave police officers are too hateful for me to ingest seriously...but I digress. Only see "The Revenant" if you want to feel how cold that the movie theater has gotten as of late.

A gripping and intense drama about a man's quest for revenge takes a toll after a fatal bear attack. With a great performance by Leonardo DiCaprio and an awesome supporting role in Tom Hardy, it was an incredible movie from start to finish. If you'd like to read more please visit thecinemascore.com

I have been looking forward to The Revenant since I first read about it in 2014. Tom Hardy(you are gonna love what I have to say about him) was going to play in this year's anticipated movie "Suicide Squad", but dropped out due to the fact that he was still filming The Revenant.

And truthfully, there is so much to say about The Revenant. I want to first applaud director Alejandro G. Irritu for making such a marvelous movie. What he has done here, is capture the beauty of nature in the 1800s in a very unique way. The way he is able to guide the actors through such a richly detailed landscape is definitely worthy of all the praise. There haven't been very many movies that make me appreciate nature and allow you to absorb the attention to detail the way The Revenant has. Quite simply, The Revenant has some of the best cinematography I've ever witnessed.

I am going to be honest, I am one of those people that has long wanted to see actor Leonardo DiCaprio win an Oscar. I had the pleasure of watching What's Eating Gilbert Grape for the first time last month, and after the movie was over I sat and thought about all the numerous films he has delivered unforgettable performances in.

  2016 may very well be the time for Leonardo DiCaprio to win that golden statue. Everything about The Revenant is memorable in my opinion, but Leonardo DiCaprio's performance is both intense and as wondrous as he as ever been. Make no mistake, you will not only remember The Revenant as a movie, you will DEFINITELY remember Leonardo DiCaprio's performance in The Revenant.

 And adding to his already impressive list of performances is Tom Hardy. If Leonardo DiCaprio does a fantastic job at being the guy to root for, Tom Hardy literally plays John Fitzgerald with a shameless tour de force. I am very glad to see that he is up for Best Supporting Actor at this year's Oscars, because his portrayal is just as impressive(if not more) to watch as Leonardo's. After this movie, I decided that every movie/tv show that Tom Hardy stars in, I will ALWAYS watch it.

Moreover, Will Poulter, Domhnall Gleeson, and Forrest Goodluck all do well in their supporting roles. Each character feels necessary to The Revenant's story. As beautiful as The Revenant is to watch, the story keeps you entertained thoroughly. It is not only a movie about survival, but it also explores the theme of revenge. And thanks to the performances, and the gorgeous scope captured by director Alejandro G. Irritu, it achieves what it sets out to accomplish as a movie.

I've only seen The Revenant once, and I am already ready to see it again. It is absolutely a Superb film.

When I left the theater after watching this film, I knew that I had watched a masterpiece.  I gave it 4 out 5, because it did not make a perfect  grade for a few reasons.  I did enjoy the creative use of the camera, with the camera moving with the actors, and close up scenes on the actors, so you could see their facial expressions.  The film used natural lighting, which gave an intense realism to mother nature.  You can't have perfect sunshine every day. The realism was incredible, especially with the arrows striking the hunters during the attack scenes.  The clothing, weapons, and portrayal of the Indians was spectacular.
The plot was simple - a grizzly bear attack, a mother protecting her cubs, murder and abandonment, and then revenge, all wrapped up into the folds of wild and spectacular mother nature.
The theme was revenge, the tone was survival against all odds when the elements, Indians, and friends want to kill you in a heartbeat.
Many symbols were used in the flashbacks to Glass's wife and his young son.  These scenes gave him the courage to go on, when human nature is to take the path of least resistance. The trunk of the tree is greater than the branches, yet the branches, when piled together to make a shelter, saved his life.  The shelter was like a Yuwipi ceremony, where rocks are heated, and then steamed inside the shelter, so the spirits will appear. The rocks have spiritual power.  The religious themes cannot be ignored in this film and were very powerful. When Glass sees(vision) himself inside a broken down stone church, with the Savior clearly painted on the wall, one must look deeper into the meaning of the sacrifice of the Savior, and Glass's son Hawk.  Did Hawk sacrifice himself so Glass can ultimately seek revenge? How does sin play a role in this theme?  When Fitzgerald recounted the story about a man who believed that God was a squirrel, and then killed and ate the squirrel, are we seeing the face of evil, or the theme of absolute necessity to kill the good to survive in the evil wilderness? You be the judge....Also, when the Pawnee Indian saved Glass by giving him some Bison liver, he mentioned to Glass that revenge was the realm of the creator.  I believe this is a purely Christian concept, and not something that is purely a Native American belief system. These scenes were similar to the original movie, Man in The Wilderness, with Richard Harris and John Huston. In this movie, Glass is presented (flashbacks) with scenes of his wife and his child, and realizes the futility of revenge, and his epic survival effort rewards him with the gift of forgiveness. But this is not evident in The Revenant.  This movie is all about revenge.
I also like to look at other theater goers during the movie, and some people were absolutely bored about midway through the movie.  Then the movie picked it up in the end, and the rest is history.  Absolutely go see the movie, and it may take two tries, but it is, in the end, a true masterpiece.  Well done, my friend.
Amazing film! Acadamy award winning performances from Leonardo DiCappreo & Tom Hardy! Stayed cold through the whole film!

If you've never hear the term "art through adversity", you'll have a clear understanding after watching this film. While there are for sure plenty of visual effects at play, the truly brutal environment and conditions that this film was shot in make for a very real and visceral feel to the story. It is  based off a true story out of history, of a man who kept on going when many of us regular folks would surely have long since given up.

It's not a movie for everyone, a good friend of mine really can't watch films that have a lot of violence, and this film does have its fair share. The most talked about scene is the bear attack, and it's both incredible and tough to watch. The effects work is very believable, as is DiCaprio's performance.

It did start to lose me a bit, when they show the main character that torn apart and barely able to do anything, then start to push through and then become very capable at not only moving on, but then going on the attack. Some people might see that as a great character break through, but it seemed a bit of a stretch to me

Overall, it's really an incredible film, and i do tend to be pretty critical. It's the kind of film that just draws you in and keeps you engaged (a bit like Castaway does).

Please, don't watch it on a small screen without surround sound

great film making.great acting. a long cold walk. A need to see it again. The viewer catches glimpses of things. Were those appendages really lost? The lens is fogged, keep going. Was that blood, keep going. How cold was that water, keep going. Was that really a 360 shot, come back and see. What an experience.

I just saw The Revanent today and like many people, I loved it!! I don't need to go into detail about what the movie is all about cuz I've read alot of descriptions here already. But I will say The Revanent was amazing! Leo was amazing as always, but it seems he went a step further (if that's possible lol) of impressing me. The Revanent is the first movie I've seen where the main character (Leo) says less than the supporting actor (Hardy), none the less Leo had me totally captivated for 2 and a half hours! His acting and facial expressions were so believable. I love how he is able to convey just what's needed without uttering a word. The relationship between he and his son really tugged at my heartstrings and definitely a highpoint of the movie:)) Leo is bound to win the Oscar this time around and its way past due. Definitely in my top 5 favorite actors. Tom hardy was outstanding as well. I've seen him in quite a few movies and I can tell that he's bound for an Oscar as well. I saw him in a movie recently called Locke where the whole movie is focused on him in a car for 2 hours. Such good acting I wasn't a bit bored, now that's some serious skills there! Finally the director Alejandro Inarritu. What can I say? I've loved him since Biutiful. He has an eye for for cinematography in a movie. It was shot so beautifully, that I felt I was there with them on the frontiers, with the bears and all lol. I can definitely see why this movie was nominated for 12 Oscars and when it comes out on DVD, I'll be sure to buy it.  Simply amazing....

"The Revenant" (2015 release; 156 min.) brings the story of Hugh Glass (played by Leonardo DiCaprio). The movie opens to a short introductory scene of an Indian tribe (only later will we understand what we were watching there), and then shifts to today (being the early 1800s), where Hugh Gals and his co-hunters and trappers are soon under attack by the native Indians, and barely can escape on their boat, albeit with heavy losses. It's not long thereafter that Glass, while on a morning stroll, gets savagely attacked by a grizzly bear, barely surviving. While the other trappers initially carry him on a stretcher, eventually they abandon him, believing he cannot survive. What will become of Hugh Glass? To tell you more would spoil your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Couple of comments: first, this is the latest movie from writer-director Alejandro G. Iñárritu, who just last year won the Best Director and Best Picture Oscar for "Birdman". With "The Revenant", he goes into something completely different, namely an epic survivor tale the likes of which we rarely haven't seen before. This ain't "The New World", let alone "Pocahontas". Instead, we get treated (if that's the right word) to a brutal but intriguing film that will glue you to your seat from start to finish. The grizzly bear attack scene must be seen to be believed (I read somewhere that Iñárritu refused to use CGI for the film, making me wonder how in the world that scene was accomplished). But that is just one example. As he has done before, Iñárritu frequently uses seemingly endless shots (the initial attack by the Indians looks to be shot in a single take lasting about 10 min. or so). The acting performances are top-notch, with Leonardo DiCaprio, surely this generation's leading actor, providing a tour-de-force (just hand him the Beast Actor Oscar already), but Tom Hardy (as the villain trapper) is equally impressive (he is nominated for the Best Supporting Actor Oscar). Add in the gorgeous photography and a wonderful orchestral score (from Japanese composer Ryuichi Sakamoto), and what you end up with is one of the very best movies of the year, period. Beware: this movie is not for the faint of heart...

I finally saw the movie last night (Friday evening) here in Cincinnati and that particular screening was completely sold out down to the very last seat. I imagine that this movie will do great business on the basis of wonderful word of mouth and the expected coronation at the Oscars next month, and all very much deservedly so. This is big Hollywood at its very best, and the type of film that begs to be seen on the big screen to get its full intended effect. Bottom line: "The Revenant" is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

Believe it or not, this movie bears a strong resemblance to a movie made in the 70's known as, "Man In The Wilderness".  It starred Richard Harris and John Huston!  The story line involves Harris being a guide for Huston, is attacked by a rogue bear and Huston considers Harris dying anyway and leaves Harris along with two other members of Huston's group to bury Harris after he dies.  However, both of the two members are spooked by an Indian raiding party and they leave Harris to the elements.  Harris does not die and in doing so, he survives with one desire; revenge against Huston for leaving him.  In the end, Harris's anger is kindled against Huston and he(Harris) leaves the group and heads on to his home!  Another fine movie as well!

amazing scenery.  amazing story telling.  I really felt like i'm there in the cold mountains at 1850, truely amazin.  If you are intelligent you won't waste your time here though this is a long movie, its good enough for me to watch this movie for the pictures of the wild mountants this is a good enough reason to watch this movie even if it had no plot.

The Revenant - After the Golden Globes I must mention two more movies, this one, a survival drama about a mountain man/fur trapper in the early 1820's northern Louisiana Purchase area with flintlock rifles. On one hand it is unbelievably well acted, a tour-de-force, by Leonardo DiCaprio. Despite special effects and stunt doubles, I cannot fathom how many of the scenes could possibly have been shot. Hugh Glass, the DiCaprio character, gets attacked and viciously mauled by a grizzly bear and this is not a man in a bear suit, but seems like the real thing.  It is shot in Wyoming, Argentina and California all in the pristine 1800's landscape winter in incredible snow cold , mud. An incredible achievement both acting and  technically. That having been said it is NOT for the faint of heart. There is very very graphic and gruesome killings. Hunters kill game for hides, hunters  kill Indians/ Native Americans. French trappers kill Indians. Indians kill French. Everybody, man and beast, slaughters everyone else with little forethought, etc .  Glass tries to survive, eating anything he can, alone in the wilderness. also starring Domhnall Gleeson ...DiCaprio,  Best Actor. By the director of last year's "Birdman",  Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu. "Inspired by a True story"

on my top10 for 2015

This is a rather average sort of film based on a second-rate book. Its main problem is that its about a third longer than it should be. Its secondary problem is that the novel it was based on is not very good.  Frederick Manfred wrote a better novel (Lord Grizzly) several decades ago. Why they didn't go to that book as the source material is a good question. Michael Punke's writing isn't great and his book can't help be derivative of the ground Manfred already covered.

The film gets alot wrong. Starting with the all the visuals. The historical story happened along the Missouri River in South Dakota. On the great plains. The film sets the story seeming on the tops of mountains in Argentina and Canada.

The problem in the film is that everything is "amped up". Rather than go for realism, they end up creating another one of those films where the conditions depicted are "better than real". You can kind of tell that nobody involved in the thing has spent much time outdoors or is familiar with the areas in question. Emmanuel Lubezki's cinematography is seemingly based around making everything look like the worst trip ever taken in the history of the world. Every day is the worst and darkest day in human history. I suppose it works with those who have never been outside a city or who don't do much beyond video games, but for me the look of it was so absurd that it reduced it to something like a cartoon. The worst of it is that while they had a huge location budget and the director was constantly ranting about "authenticity", they picked locations (Canada, Argentina) that were not consistent with the actual story. The director often seemed more concerned with portraying cold than he did with accurately portraying the setting the story.

I have to give them some credit for the bear mauling scene. Both the acting, the construction of the scene and the special effects
were beyond anything I can remember seeing in a film.

The film plays fast and loose with the actual history. What should be a simple revenge story is overloaded with all sort of redundant stuff. The film ends up being perhaps an hour too long. The director was also trying way too hard to be Terrence Malick. The ending is as pointless and depressing as one would expect. The violence is as amped up as everything else.

As far as the acting, there was nothing spectacular. Leonardo DiCaprio's performance was uninspired. In this telling of the story, Tom Hardy's character is reduced to an archtype villian which doesn't give him much to play with in the role. The film isn't great, but it will give most people what they want today.

The trailers for this movie were phenomenal, I just wish the movie was as exciting as the trailers led me to believe it would be. The movie is beautifully shot don't get me wrong, but the movie is very dark and drab, and just left me feeling cold, and underwhelmed. I do appreciate the amount of work that had to have gone into the making of this movie but I just wish I liked it more.

The Revenant is an amazing film. As movies go it had every reason not to work. Being a period piece is always tough to make appear authentic. Having to tell a revenge story through a man who doesn't enjoy speaking with others in the best of circumstances (Dicaprio's Hugh Glass). Depicting a bear mauling that in no way comes off as hokey or fake. Finally, capturing the feel of the Rocky mountains in the gloom and ferocity of winter. Any one of these factors could have scalped this movie if done wrong, but they were all done with excellence. This is a brutal and beatiful movie but so is life. Relax and watch a man have a tougher go than you, i can garuntee it!

I have had a life long interest in "men in the wilderness" type stories, whether real, fiction or (like The Revenant) a little of both. I really wanted this to be as good as Jeremiah  Johnson and The Last of the Mohicans.
WOW...  Way beyond my expectations. Other Amazon reviewers do an excellent job of describing the qualities of this film of which there are many so I will not be repetitive.
A word of advisement on this movie: the violence is very graphic and plentiful.
 More than some may expect. Example: before the lights dimmed in the theater, two teenage girls giggled as they walked down the aisle eagerly anticapating another movie starring that cute Leonardo DiCaprio... when the move was over they slowly walked up the aisle, very quiet and white as a sheet. This movie is not for everyone.
However, that said, it is an impressive, spectacular film.  I highly recommend it.

Theatrical review.  I pretty much had my Top 10 movies of the year list ready, but wanted to see this late arrival which just opened locally.  Now Im going to have to make a few adjustments.  In fact, Im guessing you're going to see a few awards at the Oscars in February land in director Alejandro Inarritus lap.  Again.

Based on real events surrounding 1820s frontier guide, Hugh Glass (brilliantly played by Leonardo DiCaprio), the story finds Glass leading a band of trappers somewhere in present day South Dakota.  Dozens of frontiersmen under the command of Capt. Andrew Henry (ubiquitous Domhnall Gleeson) are confronted by native Arikaras resulting in most being killed.  The survivors attempt to reach Ft. Kiowa, with the tribe on their tail.

Getting attention from the opening scenes is the wondrous cinematography constructed by Emmanuel Lubezki.  It is truly breathtaking with the characters nearly frozen exhale fogging up the camera lens.  The vast openness of the wilderness is at times eerily silent and at other times enhanced by a wonderful musical score.

In the most talked about scene from the movie, Glass is hunting for game when he is attacked by a mama grizzly bear.  In a remarkable feat of filmmaking we see the bear toy with Glass, whipping him side to side like a rag doll.  Obviously film trickery is used here but damn, it sure looked real.  And credit to DiCaprio as well for playing the scene to the hilt.  For that matter, his performance will surely get him an Oscar nomination and most likely a win.

Speaking of acting, Ill point out a couple more credible performances, not counting the bear.  Gleeson until the last year or so, may be best known for the romantic comedy, About Time.  In the past year hes had major roles in 4 of the best films of 2015 including Ex Machina, Star Wars: The Force Awakens, and Brooklyn in addition to this film.  His characters are hugely different in each case.  And while the attention for this film is rightly focused on DiCaprio, Tom Hardy (Mad Max: Fury Road) as the opportunistic John Fitzgerald is perfect.  Fitzgerald is a villainous foil for Glass and the subject of his revenge.  Glass, left for dead, crawls out of his shallow grave encouraged by the ghosts of his wife and son.

After seeing the movie, I was convinced the story seemed familiar.  And sure enough, Glasss story had been told before on the big screen.  In 1971, Richard Harris starred in a film called Man in the Wilderness.  I haven't seen the movie in decades.  My memory of such movies is that they were either good or not good and I remember it being good for whatever thats worth.

As far as The Revenant, it is technical perfection, with astounding performances in harsh weather and ecological conditions.  It is supported by visceral story-telling and a fine script (Inarritu and Mark Smith).  It is also one of the best movies of the year.  Highly recommended.

I know it's early in the year, but 2016 has already provided us with its potentially best movie. The Revenant is a phenomenal film that pulls no punches and delivers one of the best cinematic experiences in years.

Essentially a simple revenge story at its core, The Revenant explores very interesting themes regarding race, intercultural relationships, and how far someone will go to survive and exact revenge. The acting is phenomenal, the directing is possibly the best I've ever seen, the score is hauntingly beautiful, and the writing is pretty damn good, as well.

Do yourselves a favor, and don't miss this one!

I just saw it in theaters and was very impressed. The scenery is absolutely breathtaking. This film somehow manages to make you physically feel extreme pain and cold. The bear scene is like nothing I've ever seen. This film is a lock for several Oscars including Best Picture, Cinematography, Best Director, Best Actor and especially strong is Tom Hardy for Best Supporting Actor. De Caprio's character actually has little dialogue in the film and still manages to give one of his best performances. Warning, this movie is not for the meek.

This is epic story telling at it's best.  Great cinematography.  All who braved nature's harsh elements and wonderful beauty to bring Revenant to the Big Screen, deserve our most hearty thanks and congratulations.  I enjoyed every minute of the movie and will be seeing it again soon.  Star Wars, the Avengers and Avatar, etc. make great use of modern technology and create memorable movie going experiences.  However, nothing compares to seeing nature and man's interactions with it like the real thing, brought to us by many hours, weeks and months of hard work and devotion!  If it doesn't clean up at the Oscars, shame on the Oscars selection committee.

Dicaprio reportedly said that this movie was intensely grueling to make.  Well, right back atcha', as it was certainly grueling to watch . . . and I don't mean all the gore, which was amazingly well-staged and -filmed and was the only real highlight of this survival saga.

The series of near-death experiences the hero endures and miraculously survives are the formulaic stuff of action thrillers.  In this movie they are simply slowed down, strung out, masterfully filmed, and given a Frenchified title in the apparent hope of ascending to cinematic art.  Unfortunately it was a long, long climb that never made it to the top and left my entire viewing party, as well as surrounding viewers, tired and somewhat bored.

The plot is about as simple as it gets.  A bad man kills the hero's son, leaves the hero for dead in the snow-packed northern Rockies, and heads off to steal a few things to get himself to . . . Texas.  To his consternation, the hero survives and comes after him.  It does not end well for the bad man.  From this 10-minute story line is wrested a two-and-a-half-hour movie.

Enjoy.

The Revenant is a film loosely based on the story of Hugh Glass.  Having just watched this in the theater, this movie is about 3 1/2 stars.  It is a decent film, but, ultimately, falls short of being one of the new year's better films.

To not give too much of the story away, it is about a man who is attacked by a bear and then how he tries to survive after being abandoned and left for dead by his hunting party.  It is a watchable film, but it could have been about 45 minutes shorter.  It did not need to be two and a half hours long.  There are times when this movie drags and that is mainly in the middle of the film.  The beginning and ending of the movie are action packed and fun to watch.

Also, based on the amount of times Glass gets hurt in this film, it could have been called "Ouch!!!  That Hurts!!!"
Seriously...who cares if this movie is a remake or deviates from some truth or whatever.  It's Awesome!

The Revenant
 Writer, director, producer Alejandro Inarritu has made perhaps the most ambitiously artistic artistic film of 2015.  He also made the most ambitiously artistic film of 2014," Birdman".  He brought home Oscars for "Birdman" for best director, best picture and best writer.  To top it off, "Birdman" also turned a very nice profit for the producers.  "The Revenant" cuts a new farrow and has nothing to compare it to "Birdman" except ambition, skillful work and in this case, wonder.
 It is a wonder that a movie filmed with such consistent gloom holds our attention throughout, and that a film which has as its center the grotesque suffering of Hugh Glass can hold us in thrall.  The buzz in Hollywood says that this will at least get a passel of nominations and the Leonardo DiCaprio may finally get his Academy Award after his four nominations.  I'd say that is a safe bet.
 DiCaprio plays mountain man/fur trapper Hugh Glass, living in the world far beyond the frontier in 1820-1830 era.  He has a Indian son and mourns the murder of his wife.  The tale of misfortune which befalls this poor tortured soul stretches our incredulity to the breaking point.  Only the magnificent performance by DiCaprio convinces us that any one could possibly survive his experiences.  Hard to believe, but the events draw from the true life horrors which befell the actual Hugh Glass.  DiCaprio manages to star in the two hour plus movie with perhaps three pages of dialog.  All the rest of his performance consists of close ups of his face as various terrible things happen to him.  Astonishing acting.
 Also outstanding is Tom Hardy as the despicable  frontiersman John Fitzgerald, the Nemesis to Glass.  Fitzgerald might be a coward, a liar and a murderer but he suffers for his sins, feeling (and Hardy showing) his turmoil making the great enemy more authentic than most Hollywood bad guys.  Young Will Poulter continues his career arc playing a young Jim Bridger, another historical personage who went on to great fame.
 Director Inarritu let not a single ray of sunshine to mar the mood of the film.  The winter skies of the Yellowstone country never show bright and blue.  Well, this is a film about just how much pain Glass can endure without giving up, so grey skies seem to be in order.  The film has one of the very best battle scenes ever.  In the first part of the film a large and angry band of Ree Indians (more commonly known as Arikara Indians) suddenly attack about 50 American fur trappers.  The carnage comes thick and fast but without any of the tricks directors often use-no slow-motion killing, no exploding heads or the like.  The fighting might be furious but it seems very very realistic to the time and place.  Inarritu carries this theme throughout the film.  Brutal reality filmed up close so we can see it plainly but not stage dressed for shock effect.  The simple brutality is quite enough.  The hard "R" rating comes with this movie for this reason, not for any sexual stuff at all.
 "The Revenant" runs for two horror filled hours and 31 minutes.  Box Office Mojo reports a budget of $135 million and box office receipts thus far of $60 million world wide.  Inarritu and his fellow producers should have a lovely reward for making this monumental movie.  The audience in the full theater with me could no more take their eyes from the screen that I could.
 Fun fact-in 1971 Richard Harris made another version of the Hugh Glass sage called "Man in the Wilderness".  It isn't as good.

Alejandro Gonzalez Irritu brings the partially fictionalized story of Hugh Glass' journey for revenge alive with frightening realistic results. Leonardo Dicaprio has never been better than he is in this film bringing to life a character who barely speaks yet emotes enough emotion to carry the film with minimal dialogue. Tom Hardy is also extremely good playing John Fitzgerald who without spoiling the plot becomes a key component to this layered tale of revenge. The Revenant is the best film of 2015 and will stand for years to come as being Leonardo Dicaprio's crowning achievement.
